Bidarkee: A portable boat made of skins stretched on a frame.
Bogie: A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around a vertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railway track.
B\u00e6nopod: One of the thoracic legs of Arthropods.
bistroic: of or pertaining to a bistro.
Barbaresque: Barbaric in form or style; as, barbaresque architecture.
boilersuit: a loose protective smock worn over ordinary clothing for dirty work.
black hole: A dungeon or dark cell in a prison; a military lock-up or guardroom; -- now commonly with allusion to the cell (the Black Hole) in a fort at Calcutta (called the Black Hole of Calcutta), into which 146 English prisoners were thrust by the nabob Suraja Dowla on the night of June 20, 1765, and in which 123 of the prisoners died before morning from lack of air.
Boultel: A molding, the convexity of which is one fourth of a circle, being a member just below the abacus in the Tuscan and Roman Doric capital; a torus; an ovolo.
Boulter: A long, stout fishing line to which many hooks are attached.
Black letter: The old English or Gothic letter, in which the Early English manuscripts were written, and the first English books were printed. It was conspicuous for its blackness. See Type.
benday: to reproduce by the Benday method.
Blade: To put forth or have a blade.
Black Spanish: One of an old and well-known Mediterranean breed of domestic fowls with glossy black plumage, blue legs and feet, bright red comb and wattles, and white face. They are remarkable as egg layers.
basics: a statement of fundamental facts or principles.
Brachiolaria: A peculiar early larval stage of certain starfishes, having a bilateral structure, and swimming by means of bands of vibrating cilia.
Bacon:
Francis Bacon. A celebrated English philosopher, jurist, and statesman, son of Sir Nicholas Bacon.
   Born at York House, London, Jan. 22, 1561: died at Highgate, April 9, 1626, created Baron Verulam July 12, 1618, and Viscount St. Albans Jan. 27, 1621: commonly, but incorrectly, called Lord Bacon. 
    He studied at Trinity College, Cambridge, April, 1573, to March, 1575, and at Gray's Inn 1575; became attached to the embassy of Sir Amias Paulet in France in 1576; was admitted to the bar in 1582; entered Parliament in 1584; was knighted in 1603; became solicitor-general in 1607, and attorney-general in 1613; was made a privy councilor in 1616, lord keeper in 1617, and lord chancellor in 1618; and was tried in 1621 for bribery, condemned, fined, and removed from office. A notable incident of his career was his connection with the Earl of Essex, which began in July, 1591, remained an intimate friendship until the fall of Essex (1600-01), and ended in Bacon's active efforts to secure the conviction of the earl for treason. (See Essex.)   His great fame rests upon his services as a reformer of the methods of scientific investigation; and though his relation to the progress of knowledge has been exaggerated and misunderstood, his reputation as one of the chief founders of modern inductive science is well grounded.  His chief works are the "Advancement of Learning," published in English as "The Two Books of Francis Bacon of the Proficience and Advancement of Learning Divine and Human," in 1605; the "Novum organum sive indicia vera de interpretatione naturae," published in Latin, 1620, as a "second part" of the (incomplete) "Instauratio magna"; the "De dignitate et 
augmentis scientiarum," published in Latin in 1623; "Historia Ventorum" (1622), "Historia Vitae et Mortis" (1623), "Historia Densi et Rari" (posthumously, 1658), "Sylva Sylvarum" (posthumously, 1627), "New Atlantis," "Essays" (1597, 1612, 1625), "De Sapientia Veterum" (1609), "Apothegms New and Old," "History of Henry VII." (1622). 
Works edited by Ellis, Spedding, and Heath (7 vols. 1857); Life by Spedding 
(7 vols. 1861, 2 vols. 1878). See Shakspere.
basidial: of or pertaining to a basidium.
broiled: cooked by direct exposure to radiant heat.
Bulimus: A genus of land snails having an elongated spiral shell, often of large size. The species are numerous and abundant in tropical America.
Binocle: A dioptric telescope, fitted with two tubes joining, so as to enable a person to view an object with both eyes at once; a double-barreled field glass or an opera glass.
buirdly: strong and heavily built; -- of people.
Blinding: A thin coating of sand and fine gravel over a newly paved road. See Blind, v. t., 4.
boogie: to do a lively dance, often with the two partners not touching, to the accompaniment of rock music.
bioflavinoid: a vitamin that maintains the resistance of cell and capillary walls to permeation; -- called also vitamin P and citrin.
Barrage: An artificial bar or obstruction placed in a river or watercourse to increase the depth of water; as, the barrages of the Nile.
Bedrabble: To befoul with rain and mud; to drabble.
Bilinguous: Having two tongues, or speaking two languages.
Borrow: Something deposited as security; a pledge; a surety; a hostage.
Blandness: The state or quality of being bland.
Blanch holding: A mode of tenure by the payment of a small duty in white rent (silver) or otherwise.
baldy: a person who has a bald head; -- a deprecatory term.
Biflagellate: Having two long, narrow, whiplike appendages.
Babylonish: Of or pertaining to, or made in, Babylon or Babylonia.
Blueback: A trout (Salmo oquassa) inhabiting some of the lakes of Maine.
Basis: The foundation of anything; that on which a thing rests.
Blubbered: Swollen; turgid; as, a blubbered lip.
Basic: Relating to a base; performing the office of a base in a salt.
Basil: The skin of a sheep tanned with bark.
Bifid: Cleft to the middle or slightly beyond the middle; opening with a cleft; divided by a linear sinus, with straight margins.
Ballastage: A toll paid for the privilege of taking up ballast in a port or harbor.
Balzacian: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Honore Balzac.
bearcat: an arboreal civet of Asia (Arctictis bintourong) having a long prehensile tail and shaggy black hair.
Belomancy: A kind of divination anciently practiced by means of marked arrows drawn at random from a bag or quiver, the marks on the arrows drawn being supposed to foreshow the future.
Bighorn: The Rocky Mountain sheep (Ovis montana or Caprovis montana); called also bighorn sheep.
Benignity: The quality of being benign; goodness; kindness; graciousness.
Balsamorhiza: genus of coarse West American herbs with large roots containing an aromatic balsam.
Bob-cherry: A play among children, in which a cherry, hung so as to bob against the mouth, is to be caught with the teeth.
Buoy: To float; to rise like a buoy.
Bursten: p. p. of Burst, v. i.
Brome grass: A genus (Bromus) of grasses, one species of which is the chess or cheat.
Bluecoat: One dressed in blue, as a soldier, a sailor, a beadle, etc.
Bilocation: Double location; the state or power of being in two places at the same instant; -- a miraculous power attributed to some of the saints.
battlefront: the line along which opposing armies face each other.
busyness: the state of being or appearing to be actively engaged in an activity; as, they manifested all the busyness of a pack of beavers.
Bogus: A liquor made of rum and molasses.
Briolette: An oval or pearshaped diamond having its entire surface cut in triangular facets.
Bedding: A bed and its furniture; the materials of a bed, whether for man or beast; bedclothes; litter.
Burial: A grave; a tomb; a place of sepulture.
Bill book: A book in which a person keeps an account of his notes, bills, bills of exchange, etc., thus showing all that he issues and receives.
bassine: Coarse leaf fiber from palmyra palms used in making brushes and brooms.
Bike: A nest of wild bees, wasps, or ants; a swarm.
Bikh: The East Indian name of a virulent poison extracted from Aconitum ferox or other species of aconite: also, the plant itself.
Bioplasmic: Pertaining to, or consisting of, bioplasm.
Barkers mill: A machine, invented in the 17th century, worked by a form of reaction wheel. The water flows into a vertical tube and gushes from apertures in hollow horizontal arms, causing the machine to revolve on its axis.
Boxing day: The first week day after Christmas, a legal holiday on which Christmas boxes are given to postmen, errand boys, employees, etc. The night of this day is boxing night.
brassard: an armor plate that protects the arm.
Bickford fuse: A fuse used in blasting, consisting of a long cylinder of explosive material inclosed in a varnished wrapping of rope or hose. It burns from 2 to 4 feet a minute.
Burgrass: Grass of the genus Cenchrus, growing in sand, and having burs for fruit.
Bated: Reduced; lowered; restrained; as, to speak with bated breath.
baggage: The clothes, tents, utensils, and provisions of an army.
backdrop: the scenery hung at back of stage.  Also called in Britain backcloth.
bolete: any fungus of the family Boletaceae.
Bedsite: A recess in a room for a bed.
Barbed: Furnished with a barb or barbs; as, a barbed arrow; barbed wire.
Brassicaceae: a natural family of plants with four-petaled flowers.
Barbet: A variety of small dog, having long curly hair.
Barber: A storm accompanied by driving ice spicules formed from sea water, esp. one occurring on the Gulf of St. Lawrence; -- so named from the cutting ice spicules.
beaut: an outstanding example of its kind; as, when I make a mistake it's a beaut.
Bed-molding: The molding of a cornice immediately below the corona.
Bounteous: Liberal in charity; disposed to give freely; generously liberal; munificent; beneficent; free in bestowing gifts; as, bounteous production.
Borne: Carried; conveyed; supported; defrayed. See Bear, v. t.
Bistort: An herbaceous plant of the genus Polygonum, section Bistorta; snakeweed; adderwort. Its root is used in medicine as an astringent.
Begem: To adorn with gems, or as with gems.
Blushless: Free from blushes; incapable of blushing; shameless; impudent.
Butterbur: A broad-leaved plant (Petasites vulgaris) of the Composite family, said to have been used in England for wrapping up pats of butter.
Biaxal: Having two axes; as, biaxial polarization; biaxial crystals.
Brayer: One that brays like an ass.
Beget: To procreate, as a father or sire; to generate; -- commonly said of the father.
blinded: deprived of one's sight; rendered blind.
backgammon: In the game of backgammon, to beat by ending the game before the loser is clear of his first “table”.  When played for betting purposes, the winner in such a case scores three times the wagered amount.
Bicarbonate: A carbonate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid is replaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportion of the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in the normal carbonates; an acid carbonate; -- sometimes called supercarbonate.
broad-minded: incapable of being shocked.  Opposite of shockable.
Basement: The outer wall of the ground story of a building, or of a part of that story, when treated as a distinct substructure.  (See Base, n., 3 (a).)  Hence: The rooms of a ground floor, collectively.
Blast pipe: The exhaust pipe of a steam engine, or any pipe delivering steam or air, when so constructed as to cause a blast.
Boldo: A fragrant evergreen shrub of Chili (Peumus Boldus). The bark is used in tanning, the wood for making charcoal, the leaves in medicine, and the drupes are eaten.
Barbaric: Of, or from, barbarian nations; foreign; -- often with reference to barbarous nations of east.
Bejuco: Any climbing woody vine of the tropics with the habit of a  liane; in the Philippines, esp. any of various species of Calamus, the cane or rattan palm.
Bifoliolate: Having two leaflets, as some compound leaves.
Blastodermatic: Of or pertaining to the blastoderm.
bagful: The quantity that a bag will hold; as, he ate a bagful of popcorn.
Barbarity: The state or manner of a barbarian; lack of civilization.
Blaubok: The blue buck. See Blue buck, under Blue.
Brontograph: A tracing or chart showing the phenomena attendant on thunderstorms.
Bliss: Orig., blithesomeness; gladness; now, the highest degree of happiness; blessedness; exalted felicity; heavenly joy.
Bornite: A valuable ore of copper, containing copper, iron, and sulphur; -- also called purple copper ore (or erubescite), in allusion to the colors shown upon the slightly tarnished surface.
balloonfish: A fish of the genus Diodon (such as Diodon holocanthus) or the genus Tetraodon, having the power of distending its body by taking air or water into its dilatable esophagus.  It is similar to but smaller than the porcupinefish.  See Globefish, and Bur fish.
Bobtailed: Having the tail cut short, or naturally short; curtailed; as, a bobtailed horse or dog; a bobtailed coat.
Bridle: To hold up the head, and draw in the chin, as an expression of pride, scorn, or resentment; to assume a lofty manner; -- usually with up.
Back door: A door in the back part of a building; hence, an indirect way.
beanie: a small skullcap; formerly worn by schoolboys and college freshmen.
Beautiful: Having the qualities which constitute beauty; pleasing to the sight or the mind.
Bedpiece: The foundation framing or piece, by which the other parts are supported and held in place; the bed; -- called also baseplate and soleplate.
Bhang: An astringent and narcotic drug made from the dried leaves and seed capsules of wild hemp (Cannabis Indica), and chewed or smoked in the East as a means of intoxication. See Hasheesh.
Bisection: Division into two parts, esp. two equal parts.
Blencher: One who, or that which, scares another; specifically, a person stationed to prevent the escape of the deer, at a hunt. See Blancher.
Blastoderm: the early stage of an embryo after the first cleavages of the ovum; also, the layer of cells of which the early embryo is composed;
Blandly: In a bland manner; mildly; suavely.
Bane: To be the bane of; to ruin.
Banc: A bench; a high seat, or seat of distinction or judgment; a tribunal or court.
Bank: To tilt sidewise in rounding a curve; -- said of a flying machine, an aërocurve, or the like.
Bromize: To prepare or treat with bromine; as, to bromize a silvered plate.
Beehive: A hive for a swarm of bees. Also used figuratively.
Barytone: A male voice, the compass of which partakes of the common bass and the tenor, but which does not descend as low as the one, nor rise as high as the other.
Barkbound: Prevented from growing, by having the bark too firm or close.
Brills: The hair on the eyelids of a horse.
bodybuilder: someone who does special exercises to develop the musculature.
Bitstock: A stock or handle for holding and rotating a bit; a brace.
Breakup: Disruption; coming apart; a separation and dispersion of the parts or members; as, a break-up of a meeting, assembly, or dinner party; the break-up of a spacecraft on re-entry into the atmosphere.
Babyish: Like a baby; childish; puerile; simple.
Beeswax: The wax secreted by bees, and of which their cells are constructed.
Barefoot: With the feet bare; without shoes or stockings.
Babyism: The state of being a baby.
Brand goose: A species of wild goose (Branta bernicla) usually called in America brant. See Brant.
Bookmaker: One who writes and publishes books; especially, one who gathers his materials from other books; a compiler.
Bathyergidae: a natural family inclusing the mole rats and sand rats.
Belated: Delayed beyond the usual time; too late; overtaken by night; benighted.
break dancing: a type of solo dancing in which the dancer performs elaborate footwork, pantomime, and various acrobatic movements, such as spinning head stands or spinning on the back, and usually containing much improvization.  It was first performed by male teenagers in the 1970's, in small informal groups on the streets, and is often performed to the accompaniment of rap music or other rock music with a rapid, strong beat.
Barracan: A thick, strong stuff, somewhat like camlet; -- still used for outer garments in the Levant.
B\u00e6nomere: One of the somites (arthromeres) that make up the thorax of Arthropods.
Bistoury: A surgical instrument consisting of a slender knife, either straight or curved, generally used by introducing it beneath the part to be divided, and cutting towards the surface.
Bdellometer: A cupping glass to which are attached a scarificator and an exhausting syringe.
Blocking course: The finishing course of a wall showing above a cornice.
Bacchic: Of or relating to Bacchus; hence, jovial, or riotous, with intoxication; riotously drunken; -- used of revelrous gatherings.
Bottling: The act or the process of putting anything into bottles (as beer, mineral water, etc.) and sealing the bottles, as with a cork or a bottle cap.
Billingsgate: A market near the Billings gate in London, celebrated for fish and foul language.
Butting joint: A joint between two pieces of timber or wood, at the end of one or both, and either at right angles or oblique to the grain, as the joints which the struts and braces form with the truss posts; -- sometimes called abutting joint.
Bathorse: A horse which carries an officer's baggage during a campaign.
Billycock: A round, low-crowned felt hat; a wideawake.
Backdown: A receding or giving up; a complete surrender.
Baudekin: The richest kind of stuff used in garments in the Middle Ages, the web being gold, and the woof silk, with embroidery; -- made originally at Baghdad.
brainwashed: subjected to intensive forced indoctrination resulting in the rejection of old beliefs and acceptance of new ones.
bushbuck: antelope with white harnesslike markings and twisted horns.
boughless: having no limbs.  Opposite of limbed.
Bulker: A person employed to ascertain the bulk or size of goods, in order to fix the amount of freight or dues payable on them.
Bonapartist: One attached to the policy or family of Bonaparte, or of the Bonapartes.
Bletonism: The supposed faculty of perceiving subterraneous springs and currents by sensation; -- so called from one Bleton, of France.
Blessed: Hallowed; consecrated; worthy of blessing or adoration; heavenly; holy.
Bragget: A liquor made of ale and honey fermented, with spices, etc.
Boselaphus: A genus of Indian antelopes; the nilgais.
Brunswick green: An oxychloride of copper, used as a green pigment; also, a carbonate of copper similarly employed.
Bonapartism: The policy of Bonaparte or of the Bonapartes.
Blesser: One who blesses; one who bestows or invokes a blessing.
Beakiron: A bickern; a bench anvil with a long beak, adapted to reach the interior surfaces of sheet metal ware; the horn of an anvil.
Burler: One who burls or dresses cloth.
Balky: Apt to balk; as, a balky horse.
Bosky: Woody or bushy; covered with boscage or thickets.
Brassica: A genus of plants embracing several species and varieties differing much in appearance and qualities: such as the common cabbage (Brassica oleracea), broccoli, cauliflowers, etc.; the wild turnip (Brassica campestris); the common turnip (Brassica rapa); the rape or coleseed (Brassica napus), etc.
Bookbindery: A bookbinder's shop; a place or establishment for binding books.
Botryose: Having the form of a cluster of grapes.
Breechcloth: A cloth worn around the breech.
Bequeathment: The act of bequeathing, or the state of being bequeathed; a bequest.
Browbound: Crowned; having the head encircled as with a diadem.
bizonal: relating to or concerned with the combined affairs of two administrative zones.
Biter: One who, or that which, bites; that which bites often, or is inclined to bite, as a dog or fish.
Boswellia: a genus of incense-yielding trees of North Africa and India.
Beware: To avoid; to take care of; to have a care for.
Bloodstroke: Loss of sensation and motion from hemorrhage or congestion in the brain.
basinal: of or pertaining to a basin.
Bureaucrat: An official of a bureau; esp. an official confirmed in a narrow and arbitrary routine.
browallia: any of several herbs of the genus Browallia cultivated for their blue or violet or white flowers.
Bespangle: To adorn with spangles; to dot or sprinkle with something brilliant or glittering.
Blink beer: Beer kept unbroached until it is sharp.
bistred: colored with or as if with bister.
Boothose: Stocking hose, or spatterdashes, in lieu of boots.
Besee: To see; to look; to mind.
Buccinal: Shaped or sounding like a trumpet; trumpetlike.
Belluine: Pertaining to, or like, a beast; brutal.
Beset: To set or stud (anything) with ornaments or prominent objects.
backhanded: Stroked with a backhand{2}; as, a backhanded drive.
Butylene: Any one of three metameric hydrocarbons, C4H8, of the ethylene series. They are gaseous or easily liquefiable; -- called also butene.
Buzz: A continuous, humming noise, as of bees; a confused murmur, as of general conversation in low tones, or of a general expression of surprise or approbation.
Bier: A handbarrow or portable frame on which a corpse is placed or borne to the grave.
Bifocals: eyeglasses whose lenses have two foci, allowing the wearer to see both far and nearby objects clearly.  The lenses are partitioned horizontally, the upper and lower parts having different focal lengths.
Bushelman: A tailor's assistant for repairing garments; -- called also busheler.
baronduki: same as baranduki; the terrestrial Siberian squirrel.
Bezant: A gold coin of Byzantium or Constantinople, varying in weight and value, usually (those current in England) between a sovereign and a half sovereign. There were also white or silver bezants.
Broiler: One who broils, or cooks by broiling.
Barroom: A room containing a bar or counter at which liquors are sold.
Badger-legged: Having legs of unequal length, as the badger was thought to have.
Bravely: In a brave manner; courageously; gallantly; valiantly; splendidly; nobly.
Beray: To make foul; to soil; to defile.
Bugginess: The state of being infested with bugs.
Ballotage: In France, a second ballot taken after an indecisive first ballot to decide between two or several candidates; a runoff election.
battlefield: a region where a battle is fought.
Bespew: To soil or daub with spew; to vomit on.
Bears-foot: A species of hellebore (Helleborus fœtidus), with digitate leaves. It has an offensive smell and acrid taste, and is a powerful emetic, cathartic, and anthelmintic.
bolshevism: a form of communism based on the writings of Marx and Lenin.
Bicameral: Consisting of, or including, two chambers, or legislative branches.
Belcher: One who, or that which, belches.
Bur fish: A spinose, plectognath fish of the Allantic coast of the United States (esp. Chilo mycterus geometricus) having the power of distending its body with water or air, so as to resemble a chestnut bur; -- called also ball fish, balloon fish, and swellfish.
bize: a dry cold north wind in southeastern France.
Badaud: A person given to idle observation of everything, with wonder or astonishment; a credulous or gossipy idler.
bridgeable: capable of being connected by a bridge or as if by a bridge.
Bungling: Unskillful; awkward; clumsy; as, a bungling workman.
Basion: The middle of the anterior margin of the great foramen of the skull.
Bow net: A trap for lobsters, being a wickerwork cylinder with a funnel-shaped entrance at one end.
barrelhouse: A cheap drinking and dancing establishment.
Billhook: A thick, heavy knife with a hooked point, used in pruning hedges, etc. When it has a short handle, it is sometimes called a hand bill; when the handle is long, a hedge bill or scimiter.
Botany Bay: A harbor on the east coast of Australia, and an English convict settlement there; -- so called from the number of new plants found on its shore at its discovery by Cook in 1770.
Battologize: To keep repeating needlessly; to iterate.
Bicrescentic: Having the form of a double crescent.
Blacks: The name of a kind of in used in copperplate printing, prepared from the charred husks of the grape, and residue of the wine press.
Brassiere: A form of woman's undergarment, often stiffened with wire or whalebones, or the like, and worn to cover and support the breasts; -- also called bra.  It usually has straps which support it from the shoulders, but strapless variants are also made.
battledoor: An instrument, with a handle and a flat part covered with parchment or crossed with catgut, used to strike a shuttlecock in play; also, the play of battledoor and shuttlecock.
Bisulphite: A salt of sulphurous acid in which the base replaces but half the hydrogen of the acid; an acid sulphite.
Belief: Assent to a proposition or affirmation, or the acceptance of a fact, opinion, or assertion as real or true, without immediate personal knowledge; reliance upon word or testimony; partial or full assurance without positive knowledge or absolute certainty; persuasion; conviction; confidence; as, belief of a witness; the belief of our senses.
better-looking: more pleasing in appearance especially by reason of conformity to ideals of form and proportion.
Blackfish: A small kind of whale, of the genus Globicephalus, of several species. The most common is Globicephalus melas.  Also sometimes applied to other whales of larger size.
Bedust: To sprinkle, soil, or cover with dust.
Broussonetia: a genus of shade trees including the paper mulberry (Broussonetia papyrifera) of East Asia.
Brecciated: Consisting of angular fragments cemented together; resembling breccia in appearance.
Booly: A company of Irish herdsmen, or a single herdsman, wandering from place to place with flocks and herds, and living on their milk, like the Tartars; also, a place in the mountain pastures inclosed for the shelter of cattle or their keepers.
Bullion: Uncoined gold or silver in the mass.
Bumper: That which bumps or causes a bump.
Badiaga: A fresh-water sponge (Spongilla), common in the north of Europe, the powder of which is used to take away the livid marks of bruises.
Boletic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the Boletus.
Barberry: A shrub of the genus Berberis, common along roadsides and in neglected fields.  Berberis vulgaris is the species best known; its oblong red berries are made into a preserve or sauce, and have been deemed efficacious in fluxes and fevers. The bark dyes a fine yellow, esp. the bark of the root.
bouncy: readily regaining its original shape or position after stretching, compression, or other deformation; as, clean bouncy hair.
biloculate: divided into or containing two cells or chambers; as, having a biloculate capsule.
Bromoform: A colorless liquid, CHBr3, having an agreeable odor and sweetish taste. It is produced by the simultaneous action of bromine and caustic potash upon wood spirit, alcohol, or acetone, as also by certain other reactions. In composition it is the same as chloroform, with the substitution of bromine for chlorine. It is somewhat similar to chloroform in its effects.
Brelan: A French gambling game somewhat like poker.
Barbiton: An ancient Greek instrument resembling a lyre.
Basicity: The quality or state of being a base.
Barnabite: A member of a religious order, named from St. Barnabas.
Beggar: To reduce to beggary; to impoverish; as, he had beggared himself.
Barpost: A post sunk in the ground to receive the bars closing a passage into a field.
Bellyband: A band that passes under the belly of a horse and holds the saddle or harness in place; a girth.
bumpkinly: unsophisticated in a manner resembling a lifelong resident of rural areas; as, bumpkinly country boys.
Baptismal: Pertaining to baptism; as, baptismal vows.
bortsch: a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.
Birthroot: An herbaceous plant (Trillium erectum), and its astringent rootstock, which is said to have medicinal properties.
Basi-: A combining form, especially in anatomical and botanical words, to indicate the base or position at or near a base; forming a base; as, basibranchials, the most ventral of the cartilages or bones of the branchial arches; basicranial, situated at the base of the cranium; basifacial, basitemporal, etc.
Bank bill: In America (and formerly in England), a promissory note of a bank payable to the bearer on demand, and used as currency; a bank note.
Bez-antler: The second branch of a stag's horn.
Bridgeboard: A notched board to which the treads and risers of the steps of wooden stairs are fastened.
Brownback: The dowitcher or red-breasted snipe. See Dowitcher.
Brigandage: Life and practice of brigands; highway robbery; plunder.
Bardship: The state of being a bard.
Brooch: To adorn as with a brooch.
balled: formed or gathered into a ball.
Bookstore: A store where books are kept for sale; -- called in England a bookseller's shop.
Believe: To have a firm persuasion, esp. of the truths of religion; to have a persuasion approaching to certainty; to exercise belief or faith.
Bandicoot: A species of very large rat (Mus giganteus), found in India and Ceylon. It does much injury to rice fields and gardens.
Barret: A kind of cap formerly worn by soldiers; -- called also barret cap. Also, the flat cap worn by Roman Catholic ecclesiastics.
Burdock: A genus of coarse biennial herbs (Lappa), bearing small burs which adhere tenaciously to clothes, or to the fur or wool of animals.
Beblubber: To make swollen and disfigured or sullied by weeping; as, her eyes or cheeks were beblubbered.
butacaine: a white crystalline ester (C18H30N2O2) that is applied to mucous membranes as a topical anesthetic.  Chemically it is 3-(di-n-butylamino)-1-propanol 4-aminobenzoate (H2N.C6H4.CO.O.(CH2)3N(C4H9)2).  It is usually used as the sulfate salt.
Barrel: To put or to pack in a barrel or barrels.
baby-walker: a framework on small wheels or casters designed to support small children while they are learning to walk, and usually having a fabric support that permits the child to sit.  Called also walker and go-cart.
Beholding: The act of seeing; sight; also, that which is beheld.
bilges: in a vessel with two hulls, an enclosed area between the frames at each side.
Brambling: The European mountain finch (Fringilla montifringilla); -- called also bramble finch and bramble.
Bloodwite: A fine or amercement paid as part of a settlement for the shedding of blood; also, a riot wherein blood was spilled.
Bibliographer: One who writes, or is versed in, bibliography.
bastardisation: An act that debases or corrupts.
Ballooning: The art or practice of managing balloons or voyaging in them; the sport of riding in balloons.
Beebread: A brown, bitter substance found in some of the cells of honeycomb. It is made chiefly from the pollen of flowers, which is collected by bees as food for their young.
Ballotin: An officer who has charge of a ballot box.
Belittle: To make little or less in a moral sense; to speak of in a depreciatory or contemptuous way.
Banish: To condemn to exile, or compel to leave one's country, by authority of the ruling power.
Brown thrush: A common American singing bird (Harporhynchus rufus), allied to the mocking bird; -- also called brown thrasher.
Bos: A genus of ruminant quadrupeds, including the wild and domestic cattle, distinguished by a stout body, hollow horns, and a large fold of skin hanging from the neck.
Belled: Hung with a bell or bells.
Boogeyman: Something frightful, as a specter; anything imaginary that causes needless fright; something used to excite needless fear; also, something really dangerous, or an imaginary monster, used to frighten children, etc.
Bon ton: The height of the fashion; fashionable society.
Birthright: Any right, privilege, or possession to which a person is entitled by birth, such as an estate descendible by law to an heir, or civil liberty under a free constitution; esp. the rights or inheritance of the first born.
Bibliopolic: Of or pertaining to the sale of books.
Bort: Imperfectly crystallized or coarse diamonds, or fragments made in cutting good diamonds which are reduced to powder and used in lapidary work.
Betitle: To furnish with a title or titles; to entitle.
Ballistite: A smokeless powder containing equal parts of soluble nitrocellulose and nitroglycerin.
Bourbonist: One who adheres to the house of Bourbon; a legitimist.
Bastioned: Furnished with a bastion; having bastions.
bloviate: To orate pompously; -- used especially of politicians and news commentators.
blackwater: any of several human or animal diseases characterized by dark urine resulting from rapid breakdown of red blood cells; -- used especially of blackwater fever, a severe form of malaria caused by the blood parasite Plasmodium falciparum.
Blendwater: A distemper incident to cattle, in which their livers are affected.
Bourbonism: The principles of those adhering to the house of Bourbon; obstinate conservatism.
Beneficed: Possessed of a benefice or church preferment.
Braze: To cover or ornament with brass.
Brinishness: State or quality of being brinish.
bottlecap: a cap that seals a bottle.
Becks scale: A hydrometer scale on which the zero point corresponds to sp. gr. 1.00, and the 30°-point to sp. gr. 0.85. From these points the scale is extended both ways, all the degrees being of equal length.
Bibbs: Pieces of timber bolted to certain parts of a mast to support the trestletrees.
biotypic: of or pertaining to a biotype.
Bankia: a genus consisting of giant shipworms.
Browsewood: Shrubs and bushes upon which animals browse.
Biddery ware: A kind of metallic ware made in India. The material is a composition of zinc, tin, and lead, in which ornaments of gold and silver are inlaid or damascened.
balaclava: close-fitting and woolen and covers all of the head but the face.
Barrack: To live or lodge in barracks.
Branchiura: A group of Entomostraca, with suctorial mouths, including species parasitic on fishes, as the carp lice (Argulus).
Backheel: A method of tripping by getting the leg back of the opponent's heel on the outside and pulling forward while pushing his body back; a throw made in this way.
Bichloride: A compound consisting of two atoms of chlorine with one or more atoms of another element; -- called also dichloride.
Befuddle: To becloud and confuse, as with liquor.
biocatalytic: of or pertaining to a biocatalyst.
Become: To suit or be suitable to; to be congruous with; to befit; to accord with, in character or circumstances; to be worthy of, or proper for; to cause to appear well; -- said of persons and things.
Bedstead: A framework for supporting a bed.
Blackwork: Work wrought by blacksmiths; -- so called in distinction from that wrought by whitesmiths.
Bedtime: The time to go to bed.
blue moon: The second full moon occurring in the same month; -- derived from the expression once in a blue moon; as, we had a blue moon on January 31, 1999, and another in March.
Baroscopic: Pertaining to, or determined by, the baroscope.
battle-hardened: Experienced in combat, and therefore more effective at fighting; -- used mostly of infantry troops; as, battle-hardened veterans.
Bespice: To season with spice, or with some spicy drug.
Bulblet: A small bulb, either produced on a larger bulb, or on some aërial part of a plant, as in the axils of leaves in the tiger lily, or replacing the flowers in some kinds of onion.
Bailpiece: A piece of parchment, or paper, containing a recognizance or bail bond.
Biggon: A cap or hood with pieces covering the ears.
Bryozoum: An individual zooid of a bryozoan coralline, of which there may be two or more kinds in a single colony. The zoœcia usually have a wreath of tentacles around the mouth, and a well developed stomach and intestinal canal; but these parts are lacking in the other zooids (Avicularia, Oœcia, etc.).
brainwave: rapid fluctuations of voltage between parts of the brain.
Bewhore: To corrupt with regard to chastity; to make a whore of.
Bequeath: To give or leave by will; to give by testament; -- said especially of personal property.
broodmare: a female horse used for breeding.
Buck-basket: A basket in which clothes are carried to the wash.
bonehead: a person of low intelligence; a dunce; a blockhead; -- used deprecatingly to express a low opinion of someone's intelligence or capabilities.
Bosporian: Of or pertaining to the Thracian or the Cimmerian Bosporus.
Buttonwood: The Platanus occidentalis, or American plane tree, a large tree, producing rough balls, from which it is named; -- called also buttonball tree, and, in some parts of the United States, sycamore. The California buttonwood is Platanus racemosa.
Basidiospore: A spore borne by a basidium.
Badigeon: A cement or distemper paste (as of plaster and powdered freestone, or of sawdust and glue or lime) used by sculptors, builders, and workers in wood or stone, to fill holes, cover defects, finish a surface, etc.
backbend: an acrobatic feat in which the trunk is bent backward from a standing position until the hands touch the floor.
Braille: A system of printing or writing for the blind in which the characters and numerals are represented by patterns of raised tangible points or dots. It was invented by Louis Braille, a French teacher of the blind.
Bonny: A round and compact bed of ore, or a distinct bed, not communicating with a vein.
Bilifuscin: A brownish green pigment found in human gallstones and in old bile. It is a derivative of bilirubin.
Bercy: a sauce prepared from butter creamed with white wine, shallots, parsley and fish stock; -- also called Bercy sauce.
Basicerite: The second joint of the antennæ of crustaceans.
blue-pencil: to change, delete, or abridge (a portion of a text) with a blue pencil (or as if with a blue pencil), as in the editing process; -- of books, etc.
Bespeckle: To mark with speckles or spots.
Ballot: To vote for or in opposition to.
Backbond: An instrument which, in conjunction with another making an absolute disposition, constitutes a trust.
Blanch: Ore, not in masses, but mixed with other minerals.
Bedim: To make dim; to obscure or darken.
Bravura: A florid, brilliant style of music, written for effect, to show the range and flexibility of a singer's voice, or the technical force and skill of a performer; virtuoso music.
blueweed: a coarse prickly European weed (Echium vulgare) with spikes of blue flowers; naturalized in the U. S.
Brazilin: A substance contained in both Brazil wood and Sapan wood, from which it is extracted as a yellow crystalline substance which is white when pure. It is colored intensely red by alkalies.
Bdellomorpha: An order of Nemertina, including the large leechlike worms (Malacobdella) often parasitic in clams.
ballet master: a man who trains ballet dancers.
Belonging: That which belongs to one; that which pertains to one; hence, goods or effects.
Bawd: To procure women for lewd purposes.
Bilander: A small two-masted merchant vessel, fitted only for coasting, or for use in canals, as in Holland.
Buggy: A light one horse two-wheeled vehicle.
bedaubed: ornamented in a vulgar or showy fashion.
Bawl: A loud, prolonged cry; an outcry.
Berattle: To make rattle; to scold vociferously; to cry down.
Buster: Something huge; a roistering blade; also, a spree.
Burmanniaceae: a natural family of chiefly tropical herbs with basal or bractlike leaves and small flowers.
Baromacrometer: An instrument for ascertaining the weight and length of a newborn infant.
Bouget: A charge representing a leather vessel for carrying water; -- also called water bouget.
Blue blood: a member of the nobility or aristocracy, or a person of high social status.
Bowknot: A knot in which a portion of the string is drawn through in the form of a loop or bow, so as to be readily untied.
Brassy: A wooden club soled with brass.
Beeswing: The second crust formed in port and some other wines after long keeping. It consists of pure, shining scales of tartar, supposed to resemble the wing of a bee.
Balsamic: Having the qualities of balsam; containing, or resembling, balsam; soft; mitigative; soothing; restorative.
bacilli: plural of bacillus; usually designating aerobic rod-shaped spore-producing bacteria; they often occur in chainlike formations.
buried: covered from view; as, her face buried (or hidden) in her hands; buried in the smoke of many rifles.
Betrothment: The act of betrothing, or the state of being betrothed; betrothal.
Basylous: Pertaining to, or having the nature of, a basyle; electro-positive; basic; -- opposed to chlorous.
Brasse: A spotted European fish of the genus Lucioperca, resembling a perch.
Beaufet: A niche, cupboard, or sideboard for plate, china, glass, etc.; a buffet.
Biogenesis: A doctrine that the genesis or production of living organisms can take place only through the agency of living germs or parents; -- called also biogeny; -- opposed to abiogenesis.
Bishoply: In the manner of a bishop.
Belike: It is likely or probably; perhaps.
Bandmaster: The conductor of a musical band.
Bareback: On the bare back of a horse, without using a saddle; as, to ride bareback.
black fly: In the United States, a small, venomous, two-winged fly of the genus Simulium of several species, exceedingly abundant and troublesome in the northern forests; -- called also buffalo gnat. The larvæ are aquatic.  It sucks the blood of birds as well as humans and other mammals.
Biocellate: Having two ocelli (eyelike spots); -- said of a wing, etc.
buffer: to add a buffer{5} to (a solution), so as to reduce unwanted fluctuation of acidity.
Belie: To show to be false; to convict of, or charge with, falsehood.
Boone: Daniel Boone, a noted American frontiersman, 1734-1820.
Birdwatch: to watch birds, especially in their natural habitats, for enjoyment or as a hobby; to bird{3}.
batik: A dyed fabric with designs drawn on by applying a removable wax where the dye is not wanted.
Bigwig: A person of consequence; as, the bigwigs of society.
Barnstormer: An itinerant theatrical player who plays in barns when a theatre is lacking; hence, an inferior actor, or one who plays in the country away from the larger cities.
Blue: To make blue; to dye of a blue color; to make blue by heating, as metals, etc.
Bishop sleeve: A wide sleeve, once worn by women.
Banat: The territory governed by a ban.
Breathe: To inhale and exhale in the process of respiration; to respire.
Blub: To swell; to puff out, as with weeping.
Betoken: To signify by some visible object; to show by signs or tokens.
Bearable: Capable of being borne or endured; tolerable.
Bluebird: A small song bird (Sialia sialis), very common in the United States, and, in the north, one of the earliest to arrive in spring. The male is blue, with the breast reddish. It is related to the European robin.
Bongrace: A projecting bonnet or shade to protect the complexion; also, a wide-brimmed hat.
Bishopric: A diocese; the district over which the jurisdiction of a bishop extends.
Backfall: A fall or throw on the back in wrestling.
Bunker: To drive (the ball) into a bunker.
Bypath: A private path; an obscure way; indirect means.
Boycott: The process, fact, or pressure of boycotting; a combining to withhold or prevent dealing or social intercourse with a tradesman, employer, etc.; social and business interdiction for the purpose of coercion.
Bimembral: Having two members; as, a bimembral sentence.
Bayou State: Mississippi; -- a nickname, from its numerous bayous.
buy out: to take over ownership of; -- of corporations and companies.
Babingtonite: A mineral occurring in triclinic crystals approaching pyroxene in angle, and of a greenish black color.  It is a silicate of iron, manganese, and lime.
Bocal: A cylindrical glass vessel, with a large and short neck.
bio-: a prefix meaning of or pertaining to life, produced by living things, etc.
bootleg: to sell illicit products such as drugs or alcohol.
Bookful: As much as will fill a book; a book full.
buffalo soldier: A black soldier of the United States army who served in the American west in the late 1800's, often as an indian fighter, and usually as part of an all-black troop; -- the name was given by the indians due to their their kinky hair, and the name was believed also to be a compliment on their courage.
Bimedial: Applied to a line which is the sum of two lines commensurable only in power (as the side and diagonal of a square).
Beteela: An East India muslin, formerly used for cravats, veils, etc.
Brittle: Easily broken; apt to break; fragile; not tough or tenacious.
backpack: to hike while carrying a backpack; -- often used in the form go backpacking; as, to backpack through the forest.
Bedlam: Belonging to, or fit for, a madhouse.
Buansuah: The wild dog of northern India (Cuon primævus), supposed by some to be an ancestral species of the domestic dog.
Botuliform: Having the shape of a sausage.
Bovate: An oxgang, or as much land as an ox can plow in a year; an ancient measure of land, of indefinite quantity, but usually estimated at fifteen acres.
Bell animalcule: An infusorian of the family Vorticellidæ, common in fresh-water ponds.
brainwashing: the process of forcible indoctrination into a new set of attitudes and beliefs.
By-wipe: A secret or side stroke, as of raillery or sarcasm.
Berber: A member of a race somewhat resembling the Arabs, but often classed as Hamitic, who were formerly the inhabitants of the whole of North Africa from the Mediterranean southward into the Sahara, and who still occupy a large part of that region; -- called also Kabyles. Also, the language spoken by this people.
Brights disease: An affection of the kidneys, usually inflammatory in character, and distinguished by the occurrence of albumin and renal casts in the urine. Several varieties of Bright's disease are now recognized, differing in the part of the kidney involved, and in the intensity and course of the morbid process.
Bargeman: The man who manages a barge, or one of the crew of a barge.
Bogwood: The wood of trees, esp. of oaks, dug up from peat bogs. It is of a shining black or ebony color, and is largely used for making ornaments.
Bobsled: A short sled, mostly used as one of a pair connected by a reach or coupling; also, the compound sled so formed.
Brehon: An ancient Irish or Scotch judge.
blowfish: a fish eaten as a delicacy, especially in Japan.  It is highly dangerous because of a potent nerve poison (tetrodotoxin) in its ovaries and liver.  Chefs require special training to learn how to remove the poisonous parts, and in Japan they must be licensed.
Bravery: The quality of being brave; fearless; intrepidity.
Bas-relief: Low relief; sculpture, the figures of which project less than half of their true proportions; -- called also bass-relief and basso-rilievo. See Alto-rilievo.
Bottleholder: One who attends a pugilist in a prize fight; -- so called from the bottle of water of which he has charge.
Buckle: To bend permanently; to become distorted; to bow; to curl; to kink.
Biscutate: Resembling two bucklers placed side by side.
Backbite: To censure or revile the absent.
Backsliding: The act of one who backslides; abandonment of faith or duty.
Bragly: In a manner to be bragged of; finely; proudly.
Bhutanese: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Bhutan.
Bloom: A mass of wrought iron from the Catalan forge or from the puddling furnace, deprived of its dross, and shaped usually in the form of an oblong block by shingling.
Bondholder: A person who holds the bonds of a public or private corporation for the payment of money at a certain time.
Braxy: A disease of sheep. The term is variously applied in different localities.
Bolter: A kind of fishing line. See Boulter.
Bespawl: To daub, soil, or make foul with spawl or spittle.
Blackguardism: The conduct or language of a blackguard; ruffianism.
Bungo: A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kind of boat used in the Southern United States.
Betide: To come to pass; to happen; to occur.
big-ticket: same as expensive, but in an absolute sense; -- referring to items of a type which are all expensive, such as automobiles, refrigerators, or large-screen television sets.
Burlap: A coarse fabric, made of jute or hemp, used for bagging; also, a finer variety of similar material, used for curtains, etc.
Bipyramidal: Consisting of two pyramids placed base to base; having a pyramid at each of the extremities of a prism, as in quartz crystals.
Battle-ax: A kind of broadax formerly used as an offensive weapon.
Bloodshed: The shedding or spilling of blood; slaughter; the act of shedding human blood, or taking life, as in war, riot, or murder.
Boshvark: The bush hog. See under Bush, a thicket.
Bibracteate: Furnished with, or having, two bracts.
Baltic: Of or pertaining to the sea which separates Norway and Sweden from Jutland, Denmark, and Germany; situated on the Baltic Sea.
Biro: a pen with small metal ball as point of transfer of ink to paper;  same as ballpoint pen.
Blatter: To prate; to babble; to rail; to make a senseless noise; to patter.
Bondmaid: A female slave, or one bound to service without wages, as distinguished from a hired servant.
Baptizable: Capable of being baptized; fit to be baptized.
Brighten: To grow bright, or more bright; to become less dark or gloomy; to clear up; to become bright or cheerful.
britt: the young of a herring or sprat or similar fish.
Brashy: Resembling, or of the nature of, brash, or broken fragments; broken; crumbly.
biocatalyst: a biochemical catalyst such as an enzyme.
belly up: defunct; bankrupt; -- used mostly of commercial organizations; often used in the phrase go belly-up, i. e. to go bankrupt.
Baronial: Pertaining to a baron or a barony.
Blue-veined: Having blue veins or blue streaks.
Benzyl: A compound radical, C6H5.CH2, related to toluene and benzoic acid; -- commonly used adjectively.
Bulla: A bleb; a vesicle, or an elevation of the cuticle, containing a transparent watery fluid.
Buffle: To puzzle; to be at a loss.
Bondman: A man slave, or one bound to service without wages.
brasslike: resembling the sound of a brass instrument.
bimodal: having or occurring with two modes{9}; having two maxima; -- of a curve or distribution.
Bufonite: An old name for a fossil consisting of the petrified teeth and palatal bones of fishes belonging to the family of Pycnodonts (thick teeth), whose remains occur in the oölite and chalk formations; toadstone; -- so named from a notion that it was originally formed in the head of a toad.
Birds-eye: A plant with a small bright flower, as the Adonis or pheasant's eye, the mealy primrose (Primula farinosa), and species of Veronica, Geranium, etc.
Bronze steel: A hard tough alloy of tin, copper, and iron, which can be used for guns.
Birthmark: Some peculiar mark or blemish on the body at birth.
Backwardation: The seller's postponement of delivery of stock or shares, with the consent of the buyer, upon payment of a premium to the latter; -- also, the premium so paid. See Contango.
Balancereef: The last reef in a fore-and-aft sail, taken to steady the ship.
Blatant: Bellowing, as a calf; bawling; brawling; clamoring; disagreeably clamorous; sounding loudly and harshly.
Bearing rein: A short rein looped over the check hook or the hames to keep the horse's head up; -- called in the United States a checkrein.
Beater: One who, or that which, beats.
Brigandine: A coast of armor for the body, consisting of scales or plates, sometimes overlapping each other, generally of metal, and sewed to linen or other material. It was worn in the Middle Ages.
benight: To involve in darkness; to shroud with the shades of night; to obscure.
Broadpiece: An old English gold coin, broader than a guinea, as a Carolus or Jacobus.
Baton: A staff or truncheon, used for various purposes; as, the baton of a field marshal; the baton of a conductor in musical performances.
back up: to serve as a backup{3} for (another person or persons); as, the patrolmen backed up the detectives as they went inside to make the arrest; the center fielder backed up the shortstop on the play.
Brusque: Rough and prompt in manner; blunt; abrupt; bluff; as, a brusque man; a brusque style.
Babery: Finery of a kind to please a child.
Blazing: Burning with a blaze; as, a blazing fire; blazing torches.
Bicentennial: The two hundredth year or anniversary, or its celebration.
Breasted: Having a breast; -- used in composition with qualifying words, in either a literal or a metaphorical sense; as, a single-breasted coat.
buying: the act of buying; as, buying equipment for the trip took several hours.
Bannerol: A banderole; esp. a banner displayed at a funeral procession and set over the tomb. See Banderole.
Blue-john: A name given to fluor spar in Derbyshire, where it is used for ornamental purposes.
Baldhead: A person whose head is bald.
Bordure: A border one fifth the width of the shield, surrounding the field. It is usually plain, but may be charged.
Bayad: A large, edible, siluroid fish of the Nile, of two species (Bagrina bayad and Bagrina docmac).
Blackmailing: The act or practice of extorting money by exciting fears of injury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation.
Bellwether: A wether, or sheep, which leads the flock, with a bell on his neck.
Bronzite: A variety of enstatite, often having a bronzelike luster. It is a silicate of magnesia and iron, of the pyroxene family.
Blessedness: The state of being blessed; happiness; felicity; bliss; heavenly joys; the favor of God.
Bibitory: Of or pertaining to drinking or tippling.
Bullhead: A fresh-water fish of many species, of the genus Uranidea, esp. Uranidea gobio of Europe, and Uranidea Richardsoni of the United States; -- called also miller's thumb.
Banteng: The wild ox of Java (Bibos Banteng).
Bias: To incline to one side; to give a particular direction to; to influence; to prejudice; to prepossess.
Bijou: A trinket; a jewel; -- a word applied to anything small and of elegant workmanship.
Bridesman: A male friend who attends upon a bridegroom and bride at their marriage; the “best man.”
Biddy: An Irish serving woman or girl.
Buckboard: A four-wheeled vehicle, having a long elastic board or frame resting on the bolsters or axletrees, and a seat or seats placed transversely upon it; -- called also buck wagon.
Buskin: A strong, protecting covering for the foot, coming some distance up the leg.
Beplaster: To plaster over; to cover or smear thickly; to bedaub.
Bondager: A field worker, esp. a woman who works in the field.
Bichromatize: To combine or treat with a bichromate, esp. with bichromate of potassium; as, bichromatized gelatine.
beggarwoman: a woman who is a beggar.
Boustrophedonic: Relating to the boustrophedon made of writing.
Bismillah: An adjuration or exclamation common among the Mohammedans.
blue-blooded: of aristocratic birth and refined upbringing.
Brambly: Pertaining to, resembling, or full of, brambles.
Beadhouse: An almshouse for poor people who pray daily for their benefactors.
Berseem: An Egyptian clover (Trifolium alexandrinum) extensively cultivated as a forage plant and soil-renewing crop in the alkaline soils of the Nile valley, and now introduced into the southwestern United States. It is more succulent than other clovers or than alfalfa. Called also Egyptian clover.
Bequeathal: The act of bequeathing; bequeathment; bequest.
Bramble: Any plant of the genus Rubus, including the raspberry and blackberry. Hence: Any rough, prickly shrub.
Blore: The act of blowing; a roaring wind; a blast.
Bouri: A mullet (Mugil capito) found in the rivers of Southern Europe and in Africa.
Bagreef: The lower reef of fore and aft sails; also, the upper reef of topsails.
Bude burner: A burner consisting of two or more concentric Argand burners (the inner rising above the outer) and a central tube by which oxygen gas or common air is supplied.
Business: That which busies one, or that which engages the time, attention, or labor of any one, as his principal concern or interest, whether for a longer or shorter time; constant employment; regular occupation; as, the business of life; business before pleasure.
Breastbone: The bone of the breast; the sternum.
Boy scout: Orig., a member of the “Boy Scouts,” an organization of boys founded in 1908, by Sir R. S. S. Baden-Powell, to promote good citizenship by creating in them a spirit of civic duty and of usefulness to others, by stimulating their interest in wholesome mental, moral, industrial, and physical activities, etc.  Hence, a member of any of the other similar organizations, which are now worldwide. In “The Boy Scouts of America” the local councils are generally under a scout commissioner, under whose supervision are scout masters, each in charge of a troop of two or more patrols of eight scouts each, who are of three classes, tenderfoot, second-class scout, and first-class scout.
Boracous: Relating to, or obtained from, borax; containing borax.
Beslobber: To slobber on; to smear with spittle running from the mouth. Also Fig.: as, to beslobber with praise.
Bimarginate: Having a double margin, as certain shells.
Bal\u00e6noidea: A division of the Cetacea, including the right whale and all other whales having the mouth fringed with baleen. See Baleen.
Bagpiper: One who plays on a bagpipe; a piper.
Brachygrapher: A writer in short hand; a stenographer.
Bourdon: A drone bass, as in a bagpipe, or a hurdy-gurdy. See Burden (of a song.)
Bronchia: The bronchial tubes which arise from the branching of the trachea, esp. the subdivision of the bronchi.
Baste: To sew loosely, or with long stitches; -- usually, that the work may be held in position until sewed more firmly.
Basto: The ace of clubs in quadrille and omber.
Birthnight: The night in which a person is born; the anniversary of that night in succeeding years.
Basset: To incline upward so as to appear at the surface; to crop out; as, a vein of coal bassets.
Bordlode: The service formerly required of a tenant, to carry timber from the woods to the lord's house.
Brownist: One who advocates the Brunonian system of medicine.
Berried: Furnished with berries; consisting of a berry; baccate; as, a berried shrub.
Brownism: The doctrines of the Brunonian system of medicine. See Brunonian.
Bracket: To place within brackets; to connect by brackets; to furnish with brackets.
Bongo: one of a pair of attached small drums, each tuned to a different pitch, played by striking with the hands.
Bocca: The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory through which the fused glass is taken out.
broadcasting: the medium that disseminates via telecommunications; radio and television.
Blacktail: A fish; the ruff or pope.
Bolster: To support with a bolster or pillow.
Buna: a synthetic rubber made by copolymerizing butadiene with another substance such as acrylonitrile or styrene.
Balistidae: a natural family comprising the triggerfishes.
Benjamin: A kind of upper coat for men.
blackberry-lily: garden plant whose capsule discloses when ripe a mass of seeds resembling a blackberry.
Bloodletter: One who, or that which, lets blood; a phlebotomist.
bummer: An idle, worthless fellow, who is without any visible means of support; a loafer; a dissipated sponger; one who bums.
Brussels: A city of Belgium, giving its name to a kind of carpet, a kind of lace, etc.
backache: an ache localized in the back.
Bellyful: As much as satisfies the appetite. Hence: A great abundance; more than enough.
Betumble: To throw into disorder; to tumble.
Bahai: A member of the sect of the Babis consisting of the adherents of Baha (Mirza Husain Ali, entitled “Baha 'u 'llah,” or, “the Splendor of God”), the elder half brother of Mirza Yahya of Nur, who succeeded the Bab as the head of the Babists.  Baha in 1863 declared himself the supreme prophet of the sect, and became its recognized head.  There are upwards of 20,000 Bahais in the United States.
Bahar: A weight used in certain parts of the East Indies, varying considerably in different localities, the range being from 223 to 625 pounds.
babassu: a tall feather palm of northern Brazil (Orbignya barbosiana) with hard-shelled nuts yielding a valuable oil (babassu oil) and a kind of vegetable ivory.
Barrowist: A follower of Henry Barrowe, one of the founders of Independency or Congregationalism in England.  Barrowe was executed for nonconformity in 1593.
Black-eyed Susan: The coneflower, or yellow daisy (Rudbeckia hirta).
Birdseed: Canary seed, hemp, millet or other small seeds used for feeding caged birds.
Bipartible: Capable of being divided into two parts.
Bendy: Divided into an even number of bends; -- said of a shield or its charge.
Beaverteen: A kind of fustian made of coarse twilled cotton, shorn after dyeing.
Boulangerite: A mineral of a bluish gray color and metallic luster, usually in plumose masses, also compact.  It is a sulphide of antimony and lead.
Brandling: Same as Branlin, fish and worm.
Bunt: To strike or push with the horns or head; to butt; as, the ram bunted the boy.
Bluing: The act of rendering blue; as, the bluing of steel.
Balmy: Having the qualities of balm; odoriferous; aromatic; assuaging; soothing; refreshing; mild; as, balmy weather.
Blamable: Deserving of censure; faulty; culpable; reprehensible; censurable; blameworthy.
Bedfellow: One who lies with another in the same bed; a person who shares one's couch.
blues: a type of folk song that originated among Black Americans at the beginning of the 20th century; has a melancholoy sound from repeated used of blue notes.
Byzantinism: The doctrine that the state is supreme over the church in ecclesiastical matters.
Bonchr\u00e9tien: A name given to several kinds of pears. See Bartlett.
Bumboat: A clumsy boat, used for conveying provisions, fruit, etc., for sale, to vessels lying in port or off shore.
butyl mercaptan: A volatile liquid, C4H9.SH, having a strong odor like that of a skunk; also called butanethiol.  All three isomers, normal, sec-, and tert-butanethiol possess the skunk odor.
BMW: any automobile manufactured by the German firm BMW AG (from the German Bayerische MotorWerke); -- sometimes referred to colloquially as a beemer.
Builder: One who builds; one whose occupation is to build, as a carpenter, a shipwright, or a mason.
bungled: performed poorly or inadequately; as, a bungled job; the Watergate scandal started with a bungled burglary.
bottom-up: planning or building the smallest parts first; as, bottom-up programming.  Opposite of top-down.
Bo\u00f6tes: A northern constellation of stars near Ursa Major, containing the bright star Arcturus.
Barite: Native sulphate of barium, a mineral occurring in transparent, colorless, white to yellow crystals (generally tabular), also in granular form, and in compact massive forms resembling marble. It has a high specific gravity, and hence is often called heavy spar. It is a common mineral in metallic veins.
Biologist: A student of biology; one versed in the science of biology.
Backwater: Water turned back in its course by an obstruction, an opposing current, or the flow of the tide, as in a sewer or river channel, or across a river bar.
bronchiolitis: inflammation of the membranes lining the bronchioles.
Belemnite: A conical calcareous fossil, tapering to a point at the lower extremity, with a conical cavity at the other end, where it is ordinarily broken; but when perfect it contains a small chambered cone, called the phragmocone, prolonged, on one side, into a delicate concave blade; the thunderstone. It is the internal shell of a cephalopod related to the sepia, and belonging to an extinct family. The belemnites are found in rocks of the Jurassic and Cretaceous ages.
Blunderer: One who is apt to blunder.
brainwash: to persuade completely; as, the propaganda brainwashed many people.
Baryta: An oxide of barium (or barytum); a heavy earth with a specific gravity above 4.
Black snake: A snake of a black color, of which two species are common in the United States, the Bascanium constrictor, or racer, sometimes six feet long, and the Scotophis Alleghaniensis, seven or eight feet long.
bimolecular: Pertaining to, involving, or formed from, two molecules; as, a bimolecular reaction (a reaction between two molecules).
Bosporus: A strait or narrow sea between two seas, or a lake and a seas; as, the Bosporus (formerly the Thracian Bosporus) or Strait of Constantinople, between the Black Sea and Sea of Marmora; the Cimmerian Bosporus, between the Black Sea and Sea of Azof.
bridalwreath: a shrub (Spiraea prunifolia) having copious small white flowers in spring.
Blower: One who, or that which, blows.
Blowen: A prostitute; a courtesan; a strumpet.
Berycoid: Of or pertaining to the Berycidæ, a family of marine fishes.
Burying ground: The ground or place for burying the dead; burial place.
Bague: The annular molding or group of moldings dividing a long shaft or clustered column into two or more parts.
Billowy: Of or pertaining to billows; swelling or swollen into large waves; full of billows or surges; resembling billows.
brach: A bitch of the hound kind.  See also bratchet.
Burgeois: A burgess; a citizen. See 2d Bourgeois.
Buprestidan: One of a tribe of beetles, of the genus Buprestis and allied genera, usually with brilliant metallic colors. The larvæ are usually borers in timber, or beneath bark, and are often very destructive to trees.
Bedrid: Confined to the bed by sickness or infirmity.
Blastula: That stage in the development of the ovum in which the outer cells of the morula become more defined and form the blastoderm.
Balzac: Honore de Balzac, a French novelist; b. 1799, d. 1850.
Brocard: An elementary principle or maximum; a short, proverbial rule, in law, ethics, or metaphysics.
Bescratch: To tear with the nails; to cover with scratches.
Bumbelo: A glass used in subliming camphor.
Bower bird: An Australian bird (Ptilonorhynchus violaceus or Ptilonorhynchus holosericeus), allied to the starling.  The male constructs singular bowers or playhouses of twigs and decorates them with bright-colored objects to attract females; the satin bird.
Betel nut: The nutlike seed of the areca palm, chewed in the East with betel leaves (whence its name) and shell lime.
Basic process: A Bessemer or open-hearth steel-making process in which a lining that is basic, or not siliceous, is used, and additions of basic material are made to the molten charge during treatment. Opposed to acid process, above. Called also Thomas process.
Behold: To direct the eyes to, or fix them upon, an object; to look; to see.
Bast: The inner fibrous bark of various plants; esp. of the lime tree; hence, matting, cordage, etc., made therefrom.
Bass: To sound in a deep tone.
Base: To abase; to let, or cast, down; to lower.
Bacteriolysis: Chemical decomposition brought about by bacteria without the addition of oxygen.
Bask: To warm by continued exposure to heat; to warm with genial heat.
Bash: a forceful blow, especially one that does damage to its target.
bluestem: tall grass with smooth bluish leaf sheaths grown for hay in Western U.S.
Bahadur: A title of respect or honor given to European officers in East Indian state papers, and colloquially, and among the natives, to distinguished officials and other important personages.
Blarina: a genus of mammals consisting of the shrews.
Bice: A pale blue pigment, prepared from the native blue carbonate of copper, or from smalt; -- called also blue bice.
Burundian: a native or inhabitant of Burundi.
Baboo: A Hindu gentleman; a native clerk who writes English; also, a Hindu title equivalent to the English Mr. or Esquire.
Bergstock: A long pole with a spike at the end, used in climbing mountains; an alpenstock.
Buckstall: A toil or net to take deer.
bundling: a former custom, especially in New England, in which unmarried couples occupied the same bed without undressing, especially during courtship.  See bundle{2}, v. i.
backfire: A fire started ahead of a forest or prairie fire to burn only against the wind, so that when the two fires meet both must go out for lack of fuel.
Bass drum: The largest of the different kinds of drums, having two heads, and emitting a deep, grave sound. See Bass, a.
Butterweed: An annual composite plant of the Mississippi valley (Senecio lobatus).
Blinkard: One who blinks with, or as with, weak eyes.
Barred owl: A large American owl (Syrnium nebulosum); -- so called from the transverse bars of a dark brown color on the breast.
black-haired: having black head hair; -- of people.
Branching: The act or state of separation into branches; division into branches; a division or branch.
Browning: The act or operation of giving a brown color, as to gun barrels, etc.
Belee: To place under the lee, or unfavorably to the wind.
Bookwork: Work done upon a book or books (as in a printing office), in distinction from newspaper or job work.
beanball: a baseball deliberately thrown at the batter's head.
Bookworm: Any larva of a beetle or moth, which is injurious to books. Many species are known.
Breton: Of or relating to Brittany, or Bretagne, in France.
Boanerges: Any declamatory and vociferous preacher or orator.
Bezzle: To drink to excess; to revel.
Bovey coal: A kind of mineral coal, or brown lignite, burning with a weak flame, and generally a disagreeable odor; -- found at Bovey Tracey, Devonshire, England. It is of geological age of the oölite, and not of the true coal era.
Brachyura: A group of decapod Crustacea, including the common crabs, characterized by a small and short abdomen, which is bent up beneath the large cephalo-thorax. [Also spelt Brachyoura.] See Crab, and Illustration in Appendix.
blebbed: marred by small bubbles or small particles of foreign material; -- of glass or quartzite.
bitchy: marked by or arising from malice.
Buffle-headed: Having a large head, like a buffalo; dull; stupid; blundering.
bargello: a needlepoint stitch that produces zigzag lines.
Branchiate: Furnished with branchiæ; as, branchiate segments.
Bristliness: The quality or state of having bristles.
Bearish: Partaking of the qualities of a bear; resembling a bear in temper or manners.
Brawniness: The quality or state of being brawny.
Below: In a lower place, with respect to any object; in a lower room; beneath.
Bobolink: An American singing bird (Dolichonyx oryzivorus). The male is black and white; the female is brown; -- called also, ricebird, reedbird, and Boblincoln.
Bloodroot: A plant (Sanguinaria Canadensis), with a red root and red sap, and bearing a pretty, white flower in early spring; -- called also puccoon, redroot, bloodwort, tetterwort, turmeric, and Indian paint. It has acrid emetic properties, and the rootstock is used as a stimulant expectorant. See Sanguinaria.
Brachiata: A division of the Crinoidea, including those furnished with long jointed arms. See Crinoidea.
Brachiate: Having branches in pairs, decussated, all nearly horizontal, and each pair at right angles with the next, as in the maple and lilac.
Bluff: To act as in the game of bluff.
Bielas comet: A periodic coment, discovered by Biela in 1826, which revolves around the sun in 6.6 years. The November meteors (Andromedes or Bielids) move in its orbit, and may be fragments of the comet.
Bawdry: The practice of procuring women for the gratification of lust.
Bedewer: One who, or that which, bedews.
Burring machine: A machine for cleansing wool of burs, seeds, and other substances.
Bord service: Service due from a bordar; bordage.
buffered: containing a buffer{5}; -- of solutions, usually aqueous solutions.
Blather: Voluble, foolish, or nonsensical talk; -- often in the pl.
Biparous: Bringing forth two at a birth.
black-hearted: Having a wicked, malignant disposition; morally bad.
Brokenly: In a broken, interrupted manner; in a broken state; in broken language.
Bermuda grass: A kind of grass (Cynodon Dactylon) esteemed for pasture in the Southern United States.  It is a native of Southern Europe, but is now wide-spread in warm countries; -- called also scutch grass, and in Bermuda, devil grass.
Brandy: A strong alcoholic liquor distilled from wine. The name is also given to spirit distilled from other liquors, and in the United States to that distilled from cider and peaches. In northern Europe, it is also applied to a spirit obtained from grain.
Bergander: A European duck (Anas tadorna). See Sheldrake.
Biweekly: Occurring or appearing once every two weeks; fortnightly.
Biblicism: Learning or literature relating to the Bible.
Blastocarpous: Germinating inside the pericarp, as the mangrove.
Bartizan: A small, overhanging structure for lookout or defense, usually projecting at an angle of a building or near an entrance gateway.
Bote: Compensation; amends; satisfaction; expiation; as, man bote, a compensation or a man slain.
bloodcurdling: causing sudden intense fear due to an apprehension of imminent bodily harm, to oneself or others.
Booting: A kind of torture. See Boot, n., 2.
Bots: The larvæ of several species of botfly, especially those larvæ which infest the stomach, throat, or intestines of the horse, and are supposed to be the cause of various ailments.
Bookmate: A schoolfellow; an associate in study.
Barbotine: A paste of clay used in decorating coarse pottery in relief.
Boned: Having (such) bones; -- used in composition; as, big-boned; strong-boned.
bootlace: a long lace for fastening boots.
bruin: A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.
Bartholomew tide: Time of the festival of St. Bartholomew, August 24th.
Balistraria: A narrow opening, often cruciform, through which arrows might be discharged.
Burman: A member of the Burman family, one of the four great families Burma; also, sometimes, any inhabitant of Burma; a Burmese.
Buoyant: Having the quality of rising or floating in a fluid; tending to rise or float; as, iron is buoyant in mercury.
Bourse: An exchange, or place where merchants, bankers, etc., meet for business at certain hours; esp., the Stock Exchange of Paris.
Beneficialness: The quality of being beneficial; profitableness.
Bedevilment: The state of being bedeviled; bewildering confusion; vexatious trouble.
Borborygm: A rumbling or gurgling noise produced by wind in the bowels.
blood-red: having any of numerous bright or strong colors reminiscent of the color of cherries or tomatoes or rubies or blood.
Barathea: A soft fabric with a kind of basket weave and a diapered pattern.
Beardie: The bearded loach (Nemachilus barbatus) of Europe.
Brimmed: Having a brim; -- usually in composition.
Basilica: A digest of the laws of Justinian, translated from the original Latin into Greek, by order of Basil I., in the ninth century.
Bilbo: A rapier; a sword; so named from Bilbao, in Spain.
Broch\u00e9: Woven with a figure; as, broché goods.
Bilocular: Divided into two cells or compartments; as, a bilocular pericarp.
Belch: The act of belching; also, that which is belched; an eructation.
Bloomery: A furnace and forge in which wrought iron in the form of blooms is made directly from the ore, or (more rarely) from cast iron.
Bordereau: A note or memorandum, esp. one containing an enumeration of documents.
Bauble: A trifling piece of finery; a gewgaw; that which is gay and showy without real value; a cheap, showy plaything.
Bunch: To form into a bunch or bunches.
bully pulpit: An exceptionally advantageous position from which to extol one's ideas; -- applied especially to the presidency of the United States, which was described thus by President Theodore Rossevelt.
Benthamic: Of or pertaining to Bentham or Benthamism.
Butterbird: The rice bunting or bobolink; -- so called in the island of Jamaica.
Brusher: One who, or that which, brushes.
Borrel: Ignorant, unlearned; belonging to the laity.
Boxkeeper: An attendant at a theater who has charge of the boxes.
Bromidiom: A conventional comment or saying, such as those characteristic of bromides{2}; a bromide{3}.
Bowl-legged: Having crooked legs, esp. with the knees bent outward.
Baptism: The act of baptizing; the application of water to a person, as a sacrament or religious ceremony, by which he is initiated into the visible church of Christ. This is performed by immersion, sprinkling, or pouring.
Bristle-pointed: Terminating in a very fine, sharp point, as some leaves.
Brite: To be or become overripe, as wheat, barley, or hops.
Befriend: To act as a friend to; to favor; to aid, benefit, or countenance.
biogenic: produced by living organisms; as, biogenic methane.
Bardish: Pertaining to, or written by, a bard or bards.
Bardism: The system of bards; the learning and maxims of bards.
Boshbok: A kind of antelope. See Bush buck.
big bang theory: The theory that the known universe originated in an explosive event (the big bang) in which all of the matter and energy of the universe was contained in a single point and began to rapidly expand and evolve, starting as high-energy particles and radiation, and, as it cooled over time, evolving into ordinary subatomic particles, atoms, and then stars and galaxies.  According to this theory, the four-dimensional space-time continuum which we perceive as our universe continues to expand to the present time, but it is unknown whether the expansion will continue indefinitely or eventually stop or even reverse, possibly leading to a contraction to a single point sometimes referred to as the “big crunch”.  The competing “Steady-state Theory” gradually lost favor in the 1980's and 1990's.  See also big bang.
Balneal: Of or pertaining to a bath.
Barraclade: A home-made woolen blanket without nap.
Butchers broom: A genus of plants (Ruscus); esp. Ruscus aculeatus, which has large red berries and leaflike branches. See Cladophyll.
balkiness: likely to stop abruptly and unexpectedly.
Buttress: To support with a buttress; to prop; to brace firmly.
Breathful: Full of breath; full of odor; fragrant.
Banlieue: The territory without the walls, but within the legal limits, of a town or city.
Bull-roarer: A contrivance consisting of a slat of wood tied to the end of a thong or string, with which the slat is whirled so as to cause an intermittent roaring noise. It is used as a toy, and among some races in certain religious rites.
Bathybius: A name given by Prof. Huxley to a gelatinous substance found in mud dredged from the Atlantic and preserved in alcohol.  He supposed that it was free living protoplasm, covering a large part of the ocean bed. It is now known that the substance is of chemical, not of organic, origin.
Bl\u00e6: Dark blue or bluish gray; lead-colored.
Bisilicate: A salt of metasilicic acid; -- so called because the ratio of the oxygen of the silica to the oxygen of the base is as two to one. The bisilicates include many of the most common and important minerals.
Bismuth: One of the elements; a metal of a reddish white color, crystallizing in rhombohedrons. It is somewhat harder than lead, and rather brittle; masses show broad cleavage surfaces when broken across. It melts at 507° Fahr., being easily fused in the flame of a candle. It is found in a native state, and as a constituent of some minerals. Specific gravity 9.8. Atomic weight 207.5. Symbol Bi.
Bismuthic: Of or pertaining to bismuth; containing bismuth, when this element has its higher valence; as, bismuthic oxide.
Benumbed: Made torpid; numbed; stupefied; deadened; as, a benumbed body and mind.
Besnow: To scatter like snow; to cover thick, as with snow flakes.
Bromide paper: A sensitized paper coated with gelatin impregnated with bromide of silver, used in contact printing and in enlarging.
brisance: the shattering or crushing effect of a sudden release of energy as in an explosion; -- used especially as a measure of such a shattering power, applied to high explosives.
Basidiomycetes: a phylum of fungi  with the Basidiomycota
Becloud: To cause obscurity or dimness to; to dim; to cloud.
Bankruptcy: The state of being actually or legally bankrupt.
Bantling: A young or small child; an infant.
Bellflower: A kind of apple. The yellow bellflower is a large, yellow winter apple.
Blueness: The quality of being blue; a blue color.
Bushwhacking: Traveling, or working a way, through bushes; pulling by the bushes, as in hauling a boat along the bushy margin of a stream.
