Bonaci: A large grouper (Mycteroperca bonaci) of Florida and the West Indies, valuable as a food fish; -- called also aguaji and, in Florida, black grouper.
Basset horn: An instrument blown with a reed, and resembling a clarinet, but of much greater compass, embracing nearly four octaves; The corno di bassetto.
Bodleian: Of or pertaining to Sir Thomas Bodley, or to the celebrated library at Oxford, founded by him in the sixteenth century.
bratchet: a kind of hound; a brach; -- applied contemptuously to a child.  See also brach.
Blockade: To shut up, as a town or fortress, by investing it with troops or vessels or war for the purpose of preventing ingress or egress, or the introduction of supplies. See note under Blockade, n.
Balkans: The countries occupying the Balkan Peninsula.
Bullionist: An advocate for a metallic currency, or a paper currency always convertible into gold.
Bounding: Moving with a bound or bounds.
Bell process: The process of washing molten pig iron by adding iron oxide, proposed by I. Lowthian Bell of England about 1875.
Brasilia: the capital city of Brazil, built on the central plateau.
Bandala: A fabric made in Manila from the older leaf sheaths of the abaca (Musa textilis).
Birthwort: A genus of herbs and shrubs (Aristolochia), reputed to have medicinal properties.
Barbituric acid: A white, crystalline substance, CH2(CO.NH)2.CO, derived from alloxantin, also from malonic acid and urea, and regarded as a substituted urea.
Buceros: A genus of large perching birds; the hornbills.
Bloody flux: The dysentery, a disease in which the flux or discharge from the bowels has a mixture of blood.
bdellium: An unidentified substance mentioned in the Bible (Gen. ii. 12, and Num. xi. 7), variously taken to be a gum, a precious stone, or pearls, or perhaps a kind of amber found in Arabia.
Britannic: Of or pertaining to Great Britain; British; as, her Britannic Majesty.
Britannia: A white-metal alloy of tin, antimony, bismuth, copper, etc. It somewhat resembles silver, and is used for table ware. Called also Britannia metal.
Baronetage: State or rank of a baronet.
Breeching: A whipping on the breech, or the act of whipping on the breech.
Beauforts scale: A scale of wind force devised by Sir F. Beaufort, R. N., in 1805, in which the force is indicated by numbers from 0 to 12.
Bombast: To swell or fill out; to pad; to inflate.
Bidder: One who bids or offers a price.
Bandle: An Irish measure of two feet in length.
Busket: A small bush; also, a sprig or bouquet.
Belime: To besmear or insnare with birdlime.
Bibliopegistic: Pertaining to the art of binding books.
bullhorn: a portable loudspeaker with built-in microphone and amplifier.
Blackfriar: A friar of the Dominican order, so named becaise wearing wearing the black mantle of the Dominicans; -- called also predicant and preaching friar; in France, Jacobin. Also, sometimes, a Benedictine.
Bachelry: The body of young aspirants for knighthood.
Breastwork: A defensive work of moderate height, hastily thrown up, of earth or other material.
Blastema: The structureless, protoplasmic tissue of the embryo; the primitive basis of an organ yet unformed, from which it grows.
Blanket stitch: A buttonhole stitch worked wide apart on the edge of material, as blankets, too thick to hem.
Birdlime: To smear with birdlime; to catch with birdlime; to insnare.
Bookland: Charter land held by deed under certain rents and free services, which differed in nothing from free socage lands. This species of tenure has given rise to the modern freeholds.
Bactrian: Of or pertaining to Bactria in Asia.
bastardization: An act that debases or corrupts.
Beaconage: Money paid for the maintenance of a beacon; also, beacons, collectively.
Blanquillo: A large fish of Florida and the W. Indies (Caulolatilus chrysops). It is red, marked with yellow.
burled: having an irregular pattern from the grain of a tree burl{2}, or one resembling such a pattern, in contrast to the regular wood grain consisting of parallel or concentric lines; -- of wood.
Basketful: As much as a basket will contain.
Bolling: A tree from which the branches have been cut; a pollard.
bedaze: to cause to be senseless, groggy, or dizzy; cause to lose ability to respond normally; desensitize.
Beardless: Without a beard. Hence: Not having arrived at puberty or manhood; youthful.
Bacteriology: The branch of microbiology relating to bacteria.
Bourgeon: To sprout; to put forth buds; to shoot forth, as a branch.
Brassiness: The state, condition, or quality of being brassy.
butterflower: any of various plants of the genus Ranunculus.
Blaster: One who, or that which, blasts or destroys.
Bromyrite: Silver bromide, a rare mineral; -- called also bromargyrite.
Brettice: The wooden boarding used in supporting the roofs and walls of coal mines. See Brattice.
Bailiwick: The precincts within which a bailiff has jurisdiction; the limits of a bailiff's authority.
Bespeak: A bespeaking. Among actors, a benefit (when a particular play is bespoken.)
bellyland: to land on the underside without the landing gear; -- of airplanes.
breathalyzer: a device that measures alcohol content of a person's breath.
Bladder: To swell out like a bladder with air; to inflate.
Balker: A person who stands on a rock or eminence to espy the shoals of herring, etc., and to give notice to the men in boats which way they pass; a conder; a huer.
Bow-pen: Bow-compasses carrying a drawing pen. See Bow-compass.
Bluebell: A plant of the genus Campanula, especially the Campanula rotundifolia, which bears blue bell-shaped flowers; the harebell.
Bennettitis: the type genus of the Bennettitales.
Bordeaux mixture: A fungicidal mixture composed of blue vitriol, lime, and water. The formula in common use is: blue vitriol, 6 lbs.; lime, 4 lbs.; water, 35 -- 50 gallons.
Bromptons mixture: A mixture containing morphine and cocaine, and sometimes other narcotic substances, such as heroin, in an alcoholic solution, administered mostly to terminally ill patients, especially cancer patients, to relieve severe pain.  Its use is not universally accepted as good medical practice.
Bletting: A form of decay seen in fleshy, overripe fruit.
Blackwood: A name given to several dark-colored timbers. The East Indian black wood is from the tree Dalbergia latifolia.
Byard: A piece of leather crossing the breast, used by the men who drag sledges in coal mines.
Belles-lettres: Polite or elegant literature; the humanities; -- used somewhat vaguely for literary works in which imagination and taste are predominant.
Breast: To meet, with the breast; to struggle with or oppose manfully; as, to breast the storm or waves.
Bushwhacker: One accustomed to beat about, or travel through, bushes.
Bheesty: A water carrier, as to a household or a regiment.
Bloodwort: A plant, Rumex sanguineus, or bloody-veined dock. The name is applied also to bloodroot (Sanguinaria Canadensis), and to an extensive order of plants (Hæmodoraceæ), the roots of many species of which contain a red coloring matter useful in dyeing.
busbar: an electrical conductor that makes a common connection between several circuits.
Bondslave: A person in a state of slavery; one whose person and liberty are subjected to the authority of a master.
Boustrophedon: An ancient mode of writing, in alternate directions, one line from left to right, and the next from right to left (as fields are plowed), as in early Greek and Hittite.
brownout: darkness resulting from the extinction of lights (as in a city invisible to enemy aircraft).
beachwear: clothing to be worn at a beach.
Bobber: One who, or that which, bobs.
Bonce: A boy's game played with large marbles.
Backstairs: Private; indirect; secret; conducted with secrecy; intriguing; -- as if finding access by the back stairs; as, backstairs gossip.
Belleek ware: A porcelainlike kind of decorative pottery with a high gloss, which is sometimes iridescent. A very fine kind is made at Belleek in Ireland.
Black-footed ferret: a weasellike mammal (Mustela nigripes) inhabiting the western North American prairie, having dark feet, a dark-tipped tail, and a dark face on a yellowish-brown coat.  It is an endangered species.
Basal: Relating to, or forming, the base.
Bellyache: to complain, especially in a whining or grumbling manner; to gripe.
Bachelor: A man of any age who has not been married.
baldheaded: Having a bald head; lacking hair on all or most of the scalp; -- alsp called bald and bald-pated; as, a bald-headed gentleman.
Brutalization: The act or process of making brutal; state of being brutalized.
Bottle-nosed: Having the nose bottle-shaped, or large at the end.
buttocks: the fleshy part of the human body  at the back of the hip,  on which a person sits.
Bouilli: Boiled or stewed meat; beef boiled with vegetables in water from which its gravy is to be made; beef from which bouillon or soup has been made.
Bismuthine: Native bismuth sulphide; -- sometimes called bismuthite.
briefing: giving detailed instructions, as for a military operation.
Brushiness: The quality of resembling a brush; brushlike condition; shagginess.
Badge: To mark or distinguish with a badge.
Bronchotomy: An incision into the windpipe or larynx, including the operations of tracheotomy and laryngotomy.
Bronchotome: An instrument for cutting into the bronchial tubes.
barber pole: a pole with red and white spiral stripes; -- usually found outside a barbershop.
bloodsucking: drawing blood from the body of another; as, a plague of bloodsucking insects.
Bouncer: One who bounces; a large, heavy person who makes much noise in moving.
Broadmouth: One of the Eurylaimidæ, a family of East Indian passerine birds.
better-known: more familiar or renowned than the other of two.  Antonym of lesser-known.
Beach comber: A long, curling wave rolling in from the ocean. See Comber.
Bellbird: A South and Central American bird of the genus Casmarhincos, and family Cotingidæ, of several species; the campanero.
Bascinet: A light helmet, at first open, but later made with a visor.
bolometric: of or pertaining to a bolometer.
Blabber: one who blabr; a tattler; a telltale.
Byword: A common saying; a proverb; a saying that has a general currency.
Bagworm: One of several lepidopterous insects which construct, in the larval state, a baglike case which they carry about for protection. One species (Platœceticus Gloveri) feeds on the orange tree. See Basket worm.
Bywork: Work aside from regular work; subordinate or secondary business.
Black bass: An edible, fresh-water fish of the United States, of the genus Micropterus.  The small-mouthed kind is Micropterus dolomieī; the large-mouthed is Micropterus salmoides.
Budget: A bag or sack with its contents; hence, a stock or store; an accumulation; as, a budget of inventions.
Bride-ale: A rustic wedding feast; a bridal. See Ale.
Bird-witted: Flighty; passing rapidly from one subject to another; not having the faculty of attention.
Buttonweed: The name of several plants of the genera Spermacoce and Diodia, of the Madder family.
backswept: aligned from front to back; slanted toward the back; -- used of hair.
Bodied: Having a body; -- usually in composition; as, able-bodied.
Bargain: To transfer for a consideration; to barter; to trade; as, to bargain one horse for another.
Bottle-nose: A grey cetacean of the Dolphin family, of several species, as Delphinus Tursio and Lagenorhyncus leucopleurus, of Europe.
Because: By or for the cause that; on this account that; for the reason that.
Birrus: A coarse kind of thick woolen cloth, worn by the poor in the Middle Ages; also, a woolen cap or hood worn over the shoulders or over the head.
bathhouse: a building containing dressing rooms for bathers.
Bloodshot: Red and inflamed; suffused with blood, or having the vessels turgid with blood, as when the conjunctiva is inflamed or irritated.
Brookweed: A small white-flowered herb (Samolus Valerandi) found usually in wet places; water pimpernel.
Bloedite: A hydrous sulphate of magnesium and sodium.
Buffoonism: The practices of a buffoon; buffoonery.
Buffoonish: Like a buffoon; consisting in low jests or gestures.
Belswagger: A lewd man; also, a bully.
Bilimbi: The berries of two East Indian species of Averrhoa, of the Oxalideæ or Sorrel family. They are very acid, and highly esteemed when preserved or pickled. The juice is used as a remedy for skin diseases.
Brillancy: The quality of being brilliant; splendor; glitter; great brightness, whether in a literal or figurative sense.
Bloodflower: A genus of bulbous plants, natives of Southern Africa, named Hæmanthus, of the Amaryllis family. The juice of Hæmanthus toxicarius is used by the Hottentots to poison their arrows.
borscht: a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.
Buck fever: Intense excitement at the sight of deer or other game, such as often unnerves a novice in hunting.
Blackguard: Scurrilous; abusive; low; worthless; vicious; as, blackguard language.
bentonite: an absorbent aluminum silicate clay formed from volcanic ash.
Boar: The uncastrated male of swine; specifically, the wild hog.
-blast: A suffix or terminal formative, used principally in biological terms, and signifying growth, formation; as, bioblast, epiblast, mesoblast, etc.
bear jam: A traffic jam caused by tourists stopping to look at bears near the road; -- a phenomenon once common in Yellowstone Park, Wyoming.
Botanomancy: An ancient species of divination by means of plants, esp. sage and fig leaves.
Budding: The act or process of producing buds.
Brasier: A large metal pan for holding burning coals or charcoal; it is used to warm people who must stay outside for long times.
barndoor: An opaque adjustable flap on a lamp fixture; used in photography to cut off light from particular areas.
Beneficence: The practice of doing good; active goodness, kindness, or charity; bounty springing from purity and goodness.
Bonniness: The quality of being bonny; gayety; handsomeness.
Bayou: An inlet from the Gulf of Mexico, from a lake, or from a large river, sometimes sluggish, sometimes without perceptible movement except from tide and wind.
Bunyon: An enlargement and inflammation of a small membranous sac (one of the bursæ muscosæ), usually occurring on the first joint of the great toe.
Branchiostege: The branchiostegal membrane. See Illustration in Appendix.
Belladonna: An herbaceous European plant (Atropa belladonna) with reddish bell-shaped flowers and shining black berries. The whole plant and its fruit are very poisonous, and the root and leaves are used as powerful medicinal agents. Its properties are largely due to the alkaloid atropine which it contains. Called also deadly nightshade.
Bilestone: A gallstone, or biliary calculus. See Biliary.
Bazaar: In the East, an exchange, marketplace, or assemblage of shops where goods are exposed for sale.
Bethlehem: A hospital for lunatics; -- corrupted into bedlam.
Brabantine: Pertaining to Brabant, an ancient province of the Netherlands.
Becard: A South American bird of the flycatcher family. (Tityra inquisetor).
Bradypus: type genus of the Bradypodidae, comprising the three-toed sloths.
Bluff-bowed: Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
Bottomed: Having at the bottom, or as a bottom; resting upon a bottom; grounded; -- mostly, in composition; as, sharp-bottomed; well-bottomed.
Brucine: A powerful vegetable alkaloid, found, associated with strychnine, in the seeds of different species of Strychnos, especially in the Nux vomica. It is less powerful than strychnine. Called also brucia and brucina.
Badly: In a bad manner; poorly; not well; unskillfully; imperfectly; unfortunately; grievously; so as to cause harm; disagreeably; seriously.
Befog: To involve in a fog; -- mostly as a participle or part. adj.
Breastplate: A plate of metal covering the breast as defensive armor.
Biogenist: A believer in the theory of biogenesis.
Bioscope: A view of life; that which gives such a view.
Barbarea: a genus of biennial or perennial herbs of north temperate regions: winter cress.
buffoon: To act the part of a buffoon.
Bedstaff: “A wooden pin stuck anciently on the sides of the bedstead, to hold the clothes from slipping on either side.”
Burly: Having a large, strong, or gross body; stout; lusty; -- now used chiefly of human beings, but formerly of animals, in the sense of stately or beautiful, and of inanimate things that were huge and bulky.
Beluga: A cetacean allied to the dolphins.
Bloodwood: A tree having the wood or the sap of the color of blood.
Boltrope: A rope stitched to the edges of a sail to strengthen the sail.
Beccafico: A small bird. (Silvia hortensis), which is highly prized by the Italians for the delicacy of its flesh in the autumn, when it has fed on figs, grapes, etc.
Buttock: The part at the back of the hip, which, in man, forms one of the rounded protuberances on which he sits; the rump.  Often used in the plural -- see buttocks.
Boxhaul: To put (a vessel) on the other tack by veering her short round on her heel; -- so called from the circumstance of bracing the head yards abox (i. e., sharp aback, on the wind).
brassie: formerly a golfing wood with a face more elevated that a driver but less than a spoon.
Buscon: One who searches for ores; a prospector.
Bedchamber: A chamber for a bed; an apartment form sleeping in.
Brusqueness: Quality of being brusque; roughness joined with promptness; bluntness.
Bahrain: an island in the Persian Gulf.
Branchiogastropoda: Those Gastropoda that breathe by branchiæ, including the Prosobranchiata and Opisthobranchiata.
Broker: One who transacts business for another; an agent.
Bantingism: A method of reducing corpulence by avoiding food containing much farinaceous, saccharine, or oily matter; -- so called from William Banting of London.
Broken: Separated into parts or pieces by violence; divided into fragments; as, a broken chain or rope; a broken dish.
Bowdlerize: To expurgate, as a book, by omitting or modifying the parts considered offensive; to remove morally objectionable parts; -- said of literary texts.
bathysphere: a spherical deep diving apparatus (lowered by a cable) for underwater exploration; it is constructed with a strong steel shell to withstand high pressures at the ocean bottom.
Blote: To cure, as herrings, by salting and smoking them; to bloat.
Breast-deep: Deep as from the breast to the feet; as high as the breast.
budgie: small Australian parakeet (Melopsittacus undulatus) usually light green with black and yellow markings in the wild but bred in many colors.
baragnosis: the inability to estimate the weight of an object.
Bookkeeper: One who keeps accounts; one who has the charge of keeping the books and accounts in an office.
Booker: One who enters accounts or names, etc., in a book; a bookkeeper.
Bothy: A wooden hut or humble cot, esp. a rude hut or barrack for unmarried farm servants; a shepherd's or hunter's hut; a booth.
Bleachery: A place or an establishment where bleaching is done.
Bristly: Thick set with bristles, or with hairs resembling bristles; rough.
Bristle: To rise or stand erect, like bristles.
Bromine: One of the halogen elements, related in its chemical qualities to chlorine and iodine. Atomic weight 79.8.  Symbol Br.  It is a deep reddish brown liquid of a very disagreeable odor, emitting a brownish vapor at the ordinary temperature. In combination it is found in minute quantities in sea water, and in many saline springs. It occurs also in the mineral bromyrite.
bread-bin: a container used to store breads or cake, to keep them fresh.
Bowhead: The great Arctic or Greenland whale. (Balæna mysticetus). See Baleen, and Whale.
Bass viol: A stringed instrument of the viol family, used for playing bass. See 3d Bass, n., and Violoncello.
Break-circuit: A key or other device for breaking an electrical circuit.
Broadness: The condition or quality of being broad; breadth; coarseness; grossness.
Broaden: To make broad or broader; to render more broad or comprehensive.
B\u00eate noire: Something especially hated or dreaded; a bugbear.
Bechamel: A rich, white sauce, prepared with butter and cream.
Barmecide: One who proffers some illusory advantage or benefit. Also used as an adj.: Barmecidal.
Borecole: A brassicaceous plant of many varieties, cultivated for its leaves, which are not formed into a compact head like the cabbage, but are loose, and are generally curled or wrinkled; kale.
Brassia: a genus of tropical American epiphytic orchids having striking axillary racemes of yellow to green spiderlike flowers with long slender sepals and warty lips; the spider orchids.
Bureaucracy: A system of carrying on the business of government by means of departments or bureaus, each under the control of a chief, in contradiction to a system in which the officers of government have an associated authority and responsibility; also, government conducted on this system.
Baybolt: A bolt with a barbed shank.
Becuna: A fish of the Mediterranean (Sphyræna spet). See Barracuda.
Bushing: The operation of fitting bushes, or linings, into holes or places where wear is to be received, or friction diminished, as pivot holes, etc.
Barrenness: The condition of being barren; sterility; unproductiveness.
bathyscaph: navigable deep diving vessel for underwater exploration.
Bichir: A remarkable ganoid fish (Polypterus bichir) found in the Nile and other African rivers. See Brachioganoidei.
Balance: To have equal weight on each side; to be in equipoise; as, the scales balance.
Barrow: A large mound of earth or stones over the remains of the dead; a tumulus.
Bicycle: A light vehicle having two wheels one behind the other. It has a saddle seat and is propelled by the rider's feet acting on cranks or levers.
Boarfish: A Mediterranean fish (Capros aper), of the family Caproidæ; -- so called from the resemblance of the extended lips to a hog's snout.
Brachial: Pertaining or belonging to the arm; as, the brachial artery; the brachial nerve.
bigram: a word that is written with two letters in an alphabetic writing system.
Bottler: One who bottles wine, beer, soda water, etc.
Bookbinder: One whose occupation is to bind books.
Bitartrate: A salt of tartaric acid in which the base replaces but half the acid hydrogen; an acid tartrate, as cream of tartar.
Bon vivant: A good fellow; a jovial companion; a free liver.
Buckety: Paste used by weavers to dress their webs.
Blowball: The downy seed head of a dandelion, which children delight to blow away.
Bathos: A ludicrous descent from the elevated to the low, in writing or speech; anticlimax.
Barrigudo: A large, dark-colored, South American monkey, of the genus Lagothrix, having a long prehensile tail.
Believer: One who believes; one who is persuaded of the truth or reality of some doctrine, person, or thing.
Biblicality: The quality of being biblical; a biblical subject.
Beautifier: One who, or that which, beautifies or makes beautiful.
bastardized: deriving from more than one source or style.
Biorgan: A physiological organ; a living organ; an organ endowed with function; -- distinguished from idorgan.
Bathometer: An instrument for measuring depths, esp. one for taking soundings without a sounding line.
Bituminous: Having the qualities of bitumen; compounded with bitumen; containing bitumen.
Bishops cap: A plant of the genus Mitella; miterwort.
Bonne bouche: A delicious morsel or mouthful; a tidbit.
barbarization: the act or process of barbarizing; an act that makes people primitive and uncivilized.
BWR: a boiling water reactor; a type of nuclear reactor that uses water as a coolant and moderator; -- the steam produced can drive a steam turbine and produce electrical power.
Blasting: A blast; destruction by a blast, or by some pernicious cause.
By-passage: A passage different from the usual one; a byway.
Bipalmate: Palmately branched, with the branches again palmated.
Bailable: Having the right or privilege of being admitted to bail, upon bond with sureties; -- used of persons.
Barruly: Traversed by barrulets or small bars; -- said of the field.
Bombardier: One who used or managed a bombard; an artilleryman; a gunner.
Blastosphere: The hollow globe or sphere formed by the arrangement of the blastomeres on the periphery of an impregnated ovum.
blistering: harshly or corrosively critical in tone; -- of comments about people or their actions.
Beady: Resembling beads; small, round, and glistening.
Betulin: a term originally applied to a substance obtained as a resin or tar by extraction from the outer bark of the common European white birch (Betula alba); now referring to the chemical compound (C30H50O2) having a cyclopentanophenanthrene ring system, which is the main constituent of that extract, and which may be obtained crystalline; -- called also birch camphor.
Banshee: A supernatural being supposed to warn a family of the approaching death of one of its members, by wailing or singing in a mournful voice, as  under the windows of the house.
Bucket shop: An office or a place where facilities are given for betting small sums on current prices of stocks, petroleum, etc.
Bovril: an extract of beef (given to people who are ill).
Bill holder: A person who holds a bill or acceptance.
Bogie engine: A switching engine the running gear and driving gear of which are on a bogie, or truck.
bubbling: giving off bubbles; -- of a liquid.
Biggen: To make or become big; to enlarge.
Brutely: In a rude or violent manner.
Buccinum: A genus of large univalve mollusks abundant in the arctic seas.  It includes the common whelk (Buccinum undatum).
burgle: to commit a burglary; to enter and rob a dwelling.
Bird pepper: A species of capsicum (Capsicum baccatum), whose small, conical, coral-red fruit is among the most piquant of all red peppers.
Bedaff: To make a daff or fool of.
Botanist: One skilled in botany; one versed in the knowledge of plants.
Babbitt metal: A soft white alloy of variable composition (as a nine parts of tin to one of copper, or of fifty parts of tin to five of antimony and one of copper) used in bearings to diminish friction.
Bepowder: To sprinkle or cover with powder; to powder.
Bident: An instrument or weapon with two prongs.
Birds-mouth: An interior angle or notch cut across a piece of timber, for the reception of the edge of another, as that in a rafter to be laid on a plate; -- commonly called crow's-foot in the United States.
Bugloss: A plant of the genus Anchusa, and especially the Anchusa officinalis, sometimes called alkanet; oxtongue.
Banter: The act of bantering; joking or jesting; humorous or good-humored raillery; pleasantry.
Begrease: To soil or daub with grease or other oily matter.
Beghard: One of an association of religious laymen living in imitation of the Beguines. They arose in the thirteenth century, were afterward subjected to much persecution, and were suppressed by Innocent X. in 1650.  Called also Beguins.
Basutos: A warlike South African people of the Bantu stock, divided into many tribes, at one time subjected by the English. They formerly practiced cannibalism, but have now adopted many European customs.
bundled: sold together as a single item; -- usually done for related products which work or are used together.
Breeder: One who, or that which, breeds, produces, brings up, etc.
bomb calorimeter: a type of calorimeter made of a steel body which closes tightly and resists high pressure, designed for measuring the amount of heat developed durng chemical combustion of a quantity of combustible material in an oxygen atmosphere.
Bowse: A carouse; a drinking bout; a booze.
Borachte: A large leather bottle for liquors, etc., made of the skin of a goat or other animal. Hence: A drunkard.
bowdlerisation: the deletion of all passages considered to be indecent.
Berteroa: a genus of plants comprising the hoary alyssum.
Bloodless: Destitute of blood, or apparently so; as, bloodless cheeks; lifeless; dead.
Batting: The act of one who bats; the management of a bat in playing games of ball.
Baya: The East Indian weaver bird (Ploceus Philippinus).
Brunt: The heat, or utmost violence, of an onset; the strength or greatest fury of any contention; as, the brunt of a battle.
Barnburner: A member of the radical section of the Democratic party in New York, about the middle of the 19th century, which was hostile to extension of slavery, public debts, corporate privileges, etc., and supported Van Buren against Cass for president in 1848; -- opposed to Hunker.
bigeminate: Having a forked petiole, and a pair of leaflets at the end of each division; biconjugate; twice paired; -- said of a decompound leaf.
Broadbrim: A hat with a very broad brim, like those worn by men of the society of Friends.
Billion: According to the French and American method of numeration, a thousand millions, or 1,000,000,000; according to the English method, a million millions, or  1,000,000,000,000. See Numeration.
buffalofish: any of several large carplike North American fish.
Bandoline: A glutinous pomatum for the hair.
Bavin: A fagot of brushwood, or other light combustible matter, for kindling fires; refuse of brushwood.
Bambuseae: A tribe of plants comprising the bamboos.
Block system: A system by which the track is divided into short sections, as of three or four miles, and trains are so run by the guidance of electric, or combined electric and pneumatic, signals that no train enters a section or block until the preceding train has left it, as in absolute blocking, or that a train may be allowed to follow another into a block as long as it proceeds with excessive caution, as in permissive blocking.
Biting in: The process of corroding or eating into metallic plates, by means of an acid. See Etch.
Bahreini: a native or inhabitant of Bahrain.
bladderpod: a North American wild lobelia (Lobelia inflata) having small blue flowers and inflated capsules formerly used as an antispasmodic.
Byssolite: An olive-green fibrous variety of hornblende.
Becalm: To render calm or quiet; to calm; to still; to appease.
Bandy: Bent; crooked; curved laterally, esp. with the convex side outward; as, a bandy leg.
bottlegrass: a European foxtail naturalized in North America; it is often a troublesome weed.
Bladdery: Having bladders; also, resembling a bladder.
Bufflehead: One who has a large head; a heavy, stupid fellow.
Burnt: Consumed with, or as with, fire; scorched or dried, as with fire or heat; baked or hardened in the fire or the sun.
Befit: To be suitable to; to suit; to become.
Bent grass: Same as Bent, a kind of grass.
Bunch grass: A grass growing in bunches and affording pasture. In California, Atropis tenuifolia, Festuca scabrella, and several kinds of Stipa are favorite bunch grasses. In Utah, Eriocoma cuspidata is a good bunch grass.
Blackcap: A small European song bird (Sylvia atricapilla), with a black crown; the mock nightingale.
Bearer: One who, or that which, bears, sustains, or carries.
Bracer: That which braces, binds, or makes firm; a band or bandage.
Bryological: Relating to bryology; as, bryological studies.
Baby farming: The business of keeping a baby farm.
balsamroot: a plant of the genus Balsamorhiza having white-downy leaves in a basal rosette and yellow flowers and long balsam-scented taproots.
Brocket: A male red deer two years old; -- sometimes called brock.
brickfield: a place where bricks are made and sold.
By-dependence: An appendage; that which depends on something else, or is distinct from the main dependence; an accessory.
Bar\u00e6sthesiometer: An instrument for determining the delicacy of the sense of pressure.
Bascule: In mechanics, an apparatus on the principle of the seesaw, in which one end rises as the other falls.
Bebleed: To make bloody; to stain with blood.
Betacism: Excessive or extended use of the b sound in speech, due to conversion of other sounds into it, as through inability to distinguish them from  b, or because of difficulty in pronouncing them.
Bafta: A coarse stuff, usually of cotton, originally made in India.  Also, an imitation of this fabric made for export.
Bibliomaniacal: Pertaining to a passion for books; relating to a bibliomaniac.
Bowiea: a small genus of tropical African perennial bulbous herbs with deciduous twining stems; sometimes placed in family Hyacinthaceae.
Brahman: A person of the highest or sacerdotal caste among the Hindus.
Bosnia-Herzegovina: A country in the Balkan penninsula of southeastern Europe, formerly a part of Yugoslavia.
B\u00e6tulus: A meteorite, or similar rude stone artificially shaped, held sacred or worshiped as of divine origin.
balkline: line across a billiard table behind which the cue balls are placed at the start of a game.
Banding plane: A plane used for cutting out grooves and inlaying strings and bands in straight and circular work.
Besprinkler: One who, or that which, besprinkles.
Babiroussa: A large hoglike quadruped (Sus babirussa, syn. Porcus babirussa) of the East Indies, sometimes domesticated; the Indian hog.  Its upper canine teeth or tusks are large and recurved.
Black Rod: the usher to the Chapter of the Garter, so called from the black rod which he carries. He is of the king's chamber, and also usher to the House of Lords.
Barrio: In Spain and countries colonized by Spain, a village, ward, or district outside a town or city to whose jurisdiction it belongs; in Spanish-speaking areas of cities in the United States, it is a neighborhood, ward, or quarter inside a town.
B: is the second letter of the English alphabet. (See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 196, 220.) It is etymologically related to p, v, f, w, and m, letters representing sounds having a close organic affinity to its own sound; as in Eng. bursar and purser; Eng. bear and Lat. ferre; Eng. silver and Ger. silber; Lat. cubitum and It. gomito; Eng. seven, Anglo-Saxon seofon, Ger. sieben, Lat. septem, Gr."epta`, Sanskrit saptan.  The form of letter B is Roman, from the Greek B (Beta), of Semitic origin. The small b was formed by gradual change from the capital B.
Bowgrace: A frame or fender of rope or junk, laid out at the sides or bows of a vessel to secure it from injury by floating ice.
Blaberus: a genus of insects consisting of giant cockroaches.
Bogeyman: A goblin; a bugbear; a bogey{1}.  This is the form used by parents to frighten children; as, if you don't eat your vegetables, the bogeyman will get you.
boeuf: meat from an adult domestic bovine.
Bluebeard: The hero of a mediæval French nursery legend, who, leaving home, enjoined his young wife not to open a certain room in his castle. She entered it, and found the murdered bodies of his former wives. -- Also used adjectively of a subject which it is forbidden to investigate.
Biauriculate: Having two auricles, as the heart of mammals, birds, and reptiles.
Boyne: a battle in the War of the Grand Alliance in Ireland in 1690, where William III of England defeated the deposed James II and so ended Stuart Catholicism in England.
Baseboard: A board, or other woodwork, carried round the walls of a room and touching the floor, to form a base and protect the plastering; -- also called washboard (in England), mopboard, and scrubboard.
Breviloquence: A brief and pertinent mode of speaking.
Buttonmold: A disk of bone, wood, or other material, which is made into a button by covering it with cloth.
Bachelorhood: The state or condition of being a bachelor; bachelorship.
Bony: Consisting of bone, or of bones; full of bones; pertaining to bones.
Button: To be fastened by a button or buttons; as, the coat will not button.
Bay salt: Salt which has been obtained from sea water, by evaporation in shallow pits or basins, by the heat of the sun; the large crystalline salt of commerce.
bootlicking: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery.
Bookkeeping: The art of recording pecuniary or business transactions in a regular and systematic manner, so as to show their relation to each other, and the state of the business in which they occur; the art of keeping accounts. The books commonly used are a daybook, cashbook, journal, and ledger. See Daybook, Cashbook, Journal, and Ledger.
Bone: To sight along an object or set of objects, to see if it or they be level or in line, as in carpentry, masonry, and surveying.
Bond: In a state of servitude or slavery; captive.
Batterer: One who, or that which, batters.
Barway: A passage into a field or yard, closed by bars made to take out of the posts.
Balanoid: Resembling an acorn; -- applied to a group of barnacles having shells shaped like acorns. See Acornshell, and Barnacle.
Bibasic: Having to hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by positive or basic atoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of acids. See Dibasic.
Baroscope: Any instrument showing the changes in the weight of the atmosphere; also, less appropriately, any instrument that indicates or foreshadows changes of the weather, as a deep vial of liquid holding in suspension some substance which rises and falls with atmospheric changes.
Bridgepot: The adjustable socket, or step, of a millstone spindle.
Barrenwort: An herbaceous plant of the Barberry family (Epimedium alpinum), having leaves that are bitter and said to be sudorific.
Brank: To hold up and toss the head; -- applied to horses as spurning the bit.
Brand: To burn a distinctive mark into or upon with a hot iron, to indicate quality, ownership, etc., or to mark as infamous (as a convict).
Breech: To put into, or clothe with, breeches.
Biacid: Having two hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by negative atoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of bases. See Diacid.
Blackly: In a black manner; darkly, in color; gloomily; threateningly; atrociously.
Bewilderedness: The state of being bewildered; bewilderment.
Bijugate: Having two pairs, as of leaflets.
Blubber: To swell or disfigure (the face) with weeping; to wet with tears.
Bicyclism: The art of riding a bicycle.
Belaying pin: A strong pin in the side of a vessel, or by the mast, round which ropes are wound when they are fastened or belayed.
BUN: same as blood urea nitrogen; the concentration of nitrogen in blood present in the form of urea; -- used as a measure of kidney function.
Bandbox: A light box of pasteboard or thin wood, usually cylindrical, for holding ruffs (the bands of the 17th century), collars, caps, bonnets, etc.
Benzoin: A resinous substance, dry and brittle, obtained from the Styrax benzoin, a tree of Sumatra, Java, etc., having a fragrant odor, and slightly aromatic taste. It is used in the preparation of benzoic acid, in medicine, and as a perfume.
Birlaw: A law made by husbandmen respecting rural affairs; a rustic or local law or by-law.
Benzoic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, benzoin.
Breeches: A garment worn by men, covering the hips and thighs; smallclothes.
Bungalow: A thatched or tiled house or cottage, of a single story, usually surrounded by a veranda.
Boviform: Resembling an ox in form; ox-shaped.
Beavered: Covered with, or wearing, a beaver or hat.
Briny: Of or pertaining to brine, or to the sea; partaking of the nature of brine; salt; as, a briny taste; the briny flood.
Bring: To convey to the place where the speaker is or is to be; to bear from a more distant to a nearer place; to fetch.
Brine: To steep or saturate in brine.
Brink: The edge, margin, or border of a steep place, as of a precipice; a bank or edge, as of a river or pit; a verge; a border; as, the brink of a chasm. Also Fig.
Brotherliness: The state or quality of being brotherly.
Breastpin: A pin worn on the breast for a fastening, or for ornament; a brooch.
Board: To approach; to accost; to address; hence, to woo.
Bock beer: A strong beer, originally made in Bavaria.
Behen: The Centaurea behen, or saw-leaved centaury.
balalaika: a stringed instrument of Russian origin that has a triangular body and three strings.
Bailie: An officer in Scotland, whose office formerly corresponded to that of sheriff, but now corresponds to that of an English alderman.
Boutefeu: An incendiary; an inciter of quarrels.
Bindweed: A plant of the genus Convolvulus; as, greater bindweed (Convolvulus Sepium); lesser bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis); the white bindweed, the blue bindweed, the Syrian bindweed. The black bryony, or Tamus, is called black bindweed, and the Smilax aspera, rough bindweed.
Bishops length: A canvas for a portrait measuring 58 by 94 inches. The half bishop measures 45 by 56.
By-law: A local or subordinate law; a private law or regulation made by a corporation for its own government.
Boxen: Made of boxwood; pertaining to, or resembling, the box (Buxus).
backwash: The flow of water propelled backward by the propeller, paddle wheel, or oars of a boat.
Barge: A pleasure boat; a vessel or boat of state, elegantly furnished and decorated.
Beery: Of or resembling beer; affected by beer; maudlin.
baud: A unit of transmission speed for information conveyed over a digital communications channel, usually taken as equal to the number of bits of information transmitted per second.  The speed in bauds indicates the number of signalling events per second; however, since it is necessary in most cases to transmit control information along with the data, the data signalling rate may be smaller than the baud rate.
Bearberry: A trailing plant of the heath family (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi), having leaves which are tonic and astringent, and glossy red berries of which bears are said to be fond.
Belgravian: Belonging to Belgravia (a fashionable quarter of London, around Pimlico), or to fashionable life; aristocratic.
Bodian: A large food fish (Diagramma lineatum), native of the East Indies.
Baseless: Without a base; having no foundation or support.
blue jeans: a tight-fitting trousers made of blue denim or a similar fabric, designed originally to serve as inexpensive durable workclothes, and often having metal rivets for reinforcement.  They have become very popular as casual wear for all age groups, and more expensive and more carefully styled and tailored versions called designer jeanshave also become popular among girls and women.
Bitumen: Mineral pitch; a black, tarry substance, burning with a bright flame; Jew's pitch.  It occurs as an abundant natural product in many places, as on the shores of the Dead and Caspian Seas. It is used in cements, in the construction of pavements, etc. See Asphalt.
bare-breasted: wearing no covering for the breasts or featuring such nudity.
Basaltic: Pertaining to basalt; formed of, or containing, basalt; as basaltic lava.
Besetment: The act of besetting, or the state of being beset; also, that which besets one, as a sin.
Bridal: A nuptial festival or ceremony; a marriage.
Byzant: A gold coin, so called from being coined at Byzantium. See Bezant.
Barycentric: Of or pertaining to the center of gravity. See Barycentric calculus, under Calculus.
Bedight: To bedeck; to array or equip; to adorn.
Boraginaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants (Boraginaceæ) which includes the borage, heliotrope, beggar's lice, and many pestiferous plants.
base price: the initial price of something (goods or services) without the additional charges that may be added, such as handling or shipping charges, sales tax, optional equipment charges, etc.
Beroe: A small, oval, transparent jellyfish, belonging to the Ctenophora.
Burberry: a light gabardine raincoat of the type made by Burberry's of London.
borsh: a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.
Black vomit: A copious vomiting of dark-colored matter; or the substance so discharged; -- one of the most fatal symptoms in yellow fever.
Butt shaft: An arrow without a barb, for shooting at butts; an arrow.
Ballistic: Of or pertaining to the ballista, or to the art of hurling stones or missile weapons by means of an engine.
Byelorussian: a native or inhabitant of Byelorussia.
Berthing: The planking outside of a vessel, above the sheer strake.
Bells palsy: Paralysis of the facial nerve, producing distortion of one side of the face.
blowback: the backward escape of unburned gunpowder after a shot.
Basipterygium: A bar of cartilage at the base of the embryonic fins of some fishes. It develops into the metapterygium.
Bronzing: The act or art of communicating to articles in metal, wood, clay, plaster, etc., the appearance of bronze by means of bronze powders, or imitative painting, or by chemical processes.
Bronzine: A metal so prepared as to have the appearance of bronze.
boxed: enclosed in or set off by a border or box; as, boxed sections of the report; boxed announcements in the newspaper.
Beggarliness: The quality or state of being beggarly; meanness.
Belletristic: Occupied with, or pertaining to, belles-lettres.
Bootjack: A device for pulling off boots.
Bangladesh: An independent Asian country on teh Bay of Bengal that was once part of India and then part of Pakistan (called East Pakistan).
briary: having or covered with protective barbs or quills or spines or thorns etc.; -- of plants or animals.
Brandenburg: A kind of decoration for the breast of a coat, sometimes only a frog with a loop, but in some military uniforms enlarged into a broad horizontal stripe.
Blastophore: That portion of the spermatospore which is not converted into spermatoblasts, but carries them.
briard: an old French breed of large strong usually black dogs having a long tail and long wavy and slightly stiff coat.
Billposter: One whose occupation is to post handbills or posters in public places.
Broadbill: A wild duck (Aythya marila, or Fuligula marila), which appears in large numbers on the eastern coast of the United States, in autumn; -- called also bluebill, blackhead, raft duck, and scaup duck. See Scaup duck.
Bolty: An edible fish of the Nile (genus Chromis).
blithering: talking incoherently; as, a blithering idiot.
By-pass: A by-passage, for a pipe, or other channel, to divert circulation from the usual course.
Broom rape: A genus (Orobanche) of parasitic plants of Europe and Asia. They are destitute of chlorophyll, have scales instead of leaves, and spiked flowers, and grow attached to the roots of other plants, as furze, clover, flax, wild carrot, etc. The name is sometimes applied to other plants related to this genus, as Aphyllon uniflorumand Aphyllon Ludovicianum.
Brush turkey: A large, edible, gregarious bird of Australia (Talegalla Lathami) of the family Megapodidæ. Also applied to several allied species of New Guinea.
balkanize: to divide a territory into small, hostile states.
Baxter: A baker; originally, a female baker.
Buffel duck: A small duck (Charitonetta albeola); the spirit duck, or butterball.  The head of the male is covered with numerous elongated feathers, and thus appears large.  Called also bufflehead.
Bonze: A Buddhist or Fohist priest, monk, or nun.
Bruisewort: A plant supposed to heal bruises, as the true daisy, the soapwort, and the comfrey.
bungaloid: of or pertaining to a bungalow; similar to a bungalow.
Bookish: Given to reading; fond of study; better acquainted with books than with men; learned from books.
Boniness: The condition or quality of being bony.
back-to-back: occurring immediately one after the other; consecutive.
balanced: being in a state of proper balance or equilibrium; -- opposite of unbalanced.
Bloodthirsty: Eager to shed blood; cruel; sanguinary; murderous; having a bloodlust.
bookend: a support placed at the end of a row of books to keep them upright (on a shelf or table).
Brugmansia: a genus of plants of the nightshade family, including some plants often placed in the genus Datura, such as the angel's trumpets.
Becomingness: The quality of being becoming, appropriate, or fit; congruity; fitness.
Baseball: A game of ball, so called from the bases or bounds (four in number) which designate the circuit which each player must endeavor to make after striking the ball.
Blast: To be blighted or withered; as, the bud blasted in the blossom.
Bedevil: To throw into utter disorder and confusion, as if by the agency of evil spirits; to bring under diabolical influence; to torment.
box-number: the mailing address to which answers to a newspaper ad can be sent.
Boucherize: To impregnate with a preservative solution of copper sulphate, as timber, railroad ties, etc.
Belgic: Of or pertaining to the Belgæ, a German tribe who anciently possessed the country between the Rhine, the Seine, and the ocean.
Batavian: A native or inhabitant of Batavia or Holland.
Brose: Pottage made by pouring some boiling liquid on meal (esp. oatmeal), and stirring it. It is called beef brose, water brose, etc., according to the name of the liquid (beef broth, hot water, etc.) used.
Beadle: A messenger or crier of a court; a servitor; one who cites or bids persons to appear and answer; -- called also an apparitor or summoner.
Boundless: Without bounds or confines; illimitable; vast; unlimited.
Begum: In the East Indies, a princess or lady of high rank.
Bacterial: Of, pertaining to, or caused by bacteria.
Birthplace: The town, city, or country, where a person is born; place of origin or birth, in its more general sense.
Bicycling: The use of a bicycle; the act or practice of riding a bicycle.
Broomy: Of or pertaining to broom; overgrowing with broom; resembling broom or a broom.
Blas\u00e9: Having the sensibilities deadened by excess or frequency of enjoyment; sated or surfeited with pleasure; uninterested because of frequent exposure or indulgence; used up.
Beurr\u00e9: A beurré (or buttery) pear, one with the meat soft and melting; -- used with a distinguishing word; as, Beurré d'Anjou; Beurré Clairgeau.
Bull Moose: A follower of Theodore Roosevelt in the presidential campaign of 1912; -- a sense said to have originated from a remark made by  Roosevelt on a certain occasion that he felt “like a bull moose.”
Blister: To raise a blister or blisters upon.
Bibliotaph: One who hides away books, as in a tomb.
Bakehouse: A house for baking; a bakery.
Betrustment: The act of intrusting, or the thing intrusted.
Biodynamics: The doctrine of vital forces or energy.
Broadax: An ancient military weapon; a battle-ax.
Bertha: A kind of collar or cape worn by ladies.
blood-twig: a European deciduous shrub (Cornus sanguinea) turning red in autumn having dull white flowers.
Beadroll: A catalogue of persons, for the rest of whose souls a certain number of prayers are to be said or counted off on the beads of a chaplet; hence, a catalogue in general.
Bungee: a spring or other elastic device, especially one attached to a control to facilitate its manipulation.
Bole: Any one of several varieties of friable earthy clay, usually colored more or less strongly red by oxide of iron, and used to color and adulterate various substances. It was formerly used in medicine. It is composed essentially of hydrous silicates of alumina, or more rarely of magnesia. See Clay, and Terra alba.
Burl: A knot or lump in thread or cloth.
Bipupillate: Having an eyelike spot on the wing, with two dots within it of a different color, as in some butterflies.
Bolo: A kind of large knife resembling a machete.
Bemoan: To express deep grief for by moaning; to express sorrow for; to lament; to bewail; to pity or sympathize with.
Bouvines: the location where in 1214 the French under King Philip Augustus defeated a coalition formed against him in one of the greatest battles of the middle ages.
Becurl: To curl; to adorn with curls.
Bolt: A sieve, esp. a long fine sieve used in milling for bolting flour and meal; a bolter.
Bashi-bazouk: A soldier belonging to the irregular troops of the Turkish army.
Burr: To speak with burr; to make a hoarse or guttural murmur.
Balsamation: The act of imparting balsamic properties.
Bury: To cover out of sight, either by heaping something over, or by placing within something, as earth, etc.; to conceal by covering; to hide; as, to bury coals in ashes; to bury the face in the hands.
Brander: One who, or that which, brands; a branding iron.
Biennial: Something which takes place or appears once in two years; esp. a biennial examination.
Breakage: The act of breaking; a break; a breaking; also, articles broken.
Banishment: The act of banishing, or the state of being banished.
Block book: A book printed from engraved wooden blocks instead of movable types.
Booming: The act of producing a hollow or roaring sound; a violent rushing with heavy roar; as, the booming of the sea; a deep, hollow sound; as, the booming of bitterns.
Beauteous: Full of beauty; beautiful; very handsome.
Bludgeon: A short stick, with one end loaded, or thicker and heavier that the other, used as an offensive weapon.
Banderillero: One who thrusts in the banderillas in bullfighting.
Berg: A large mass or hill, as of ice.
Block chain: A chain in which the alternate links are broad blocks connected by thin side links pivoted to the ends of the blocks, used with sprocket wheels to transmit power, as in a bicycle.
Brillante: In a gay, showy, and sparkling style.
Berm: A narrow shelf or path between the bottom of a parapet and the ditch.
Beviled: Notched with an angle like that inclosed by a carpenter's bevel; -- said of a partition line of a shield.
Bunko: To swindle by a bunko game or scheme; to cheat or victimize in any similar way, as by a confidence game, passing a bad check, etc.
Barebacked: Having the back uncovered; as, a barebacked horse.
Brilliant: A diamond or other gem of the finest cut, formed into faces and facets, so as to reflect and refract the light, by which it is rendered more brilliant. It has at the middle, or top, a principal face, called the table, which is surrounded by a number of sloping facets forming a bizet; below, it has a small face or collet, parallel to the table, connected with the girdle by a pavilion of elongated facets. It is thus distinguished from the rose diamond, which is entirely covered with facets on the surface, and is flat below.
Benne: The name of two plants (Sesamum orientale and Sesamum indicum), originally Asiatic; -- also called oil plant. From their seeds an oil is expressed, called benne oil or sesame oil, used mostly for making soap. In the southern United States the seeds are used in candy.
Breaker: One who, or that which, breaks.
Browbeat: To depress or bear down with haughty, stern looks, or with arrogant speech and dogmatic assertions; to abash or disconcert by impudent or abusive words or looks; to bully; as, to browbeat witnesses.
Bambino: A child or baby; esp., a representation in art of the infant Christ wrapped in swaddling clothes.
Bathymetry: The art or science of sounding, or measuring depths in the sea.
bacterise: to subject to the action of bacteria.
Bonito: A large tropical fish (Orcynus pelamys) allied to the tunny.  It is about three feet long, blue above, with four brown stripes on the sides. It is sometimes found on the American coast.
Black box: any electronic instrument or part of an instrument whose function is defined, but which is treated as a unit without consideration of the internal mechanisms; broadly, any device whose internal workings are considered as incomprehensible or mysterious by the user; as, to treat the meter as a black box and take its readings on faith.
Beverage: Liquid for drinking; drink; -- usually applied to drink artificially prepared and of an agreeable flavor; as, an intoxicating beverage.
Biting: That bites; sharp; cutting; sarcastic; caustic.
Bushy: Thick and spreading, like a bush.
Brill: A fish allied to the turbot (Rhombus levis), much esteemed in England for food; -- called also bret, pearl, prill. See Bret.
bioengineering: biological science applied to the study the relation between workers and their environments.
Birostrate: Having a double beak, or two processes resembling beaks.
Baluster: A small column or pilaster, used as a support to the rail of an open parapet, to guard the side of a staircase, or the front of a gallery.  See Balustrade.
Beggars ticks: The bur marigold (Bidens) and its achenes, which are armed with barbed awns, and adhere to clothing and fleeces with unpleasant tenacity; -- also called beggar-ticks.
Bowable: Capable of being bowed or bent; flexible; easily influenced; yielding.
Biographic: Of or pertaining to biography; containing biography.
Beelzebub: The title of a heathen deity to whom the Jews ascribed the sovereignty of the evil spirits; hence, the Devil or a devil. See Baal.
Barad: The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as a unit of pressure.
Bechic: Pertaining to, or relieving, a cough.
Blastostyle: In certain hydroids, an imperfect zooid, whose special function is to produce medusoid buds. See Hydroidea, and Athecata.
Breech pin: A strong iron or steel plug screwed into the breech of a musket or other firearm, to close the bottom of the bore.
Barometrically: By means of a barometer, or according to barometric observations.
Bebung: A tremolo effect, such as that produced on the piano by vibratory repetition of a note with sustained use of the pedal.
Breviary: An abridgment; a compend; an epitome; a brief account or summary.
Bodice: A kind of under waist stiffened with whalebone, etc., worn esp. by women; a corset; stays.
Biogeography: The branch of biology which deals with the geographical distribution of animals and plants. It includes both zoögeography and phytogeography.
Bullary: A place for boiling or preparing salt; a boilery.
Bonus: A premium given for a loan, or for a charter or other privilege granted to a company; as the bank paid a bonus for its charter.
benni: an East Indian annual erect herb (Sesamum indicum); the source of sesame seed or benniseed and sesame oil.  Same as benne
Bantam: A variety of small barnyard fowl, with feathered legs, probably brought from Bantam, a district of Java.
biovular: derived from two separate ferilized ova; -- of twins; as, fraternal twins are biovular.  Antonym of identical.
Biochemistry: The chemistry of living organisms; the chemistry of the processes incidental to, and characteristic of, life.
Bluegown: One of a class of paupers or pensioners, or licensed beggars, in Scotland, to whim annually on the king's birthday were distributed certain alms, including a blue gown; a beadsman.
Bestraught: Out of one's senses; distracted; mad.
Bastardism: The state of being a bastard; bastardy.
bunji-bunji: an Australian timber tree (Flindersia schottiana) whose bark yields a poison.
Boughten: Purchased; not obtained or produced at home.
Book muslin: A kind of muslin used for the covers of books.
Broccoli: A plant of the Cabbage species (Brassica oleracea) of many varieties, resembling the cauliflower. The “curd,” or flowering head, is the part used for food.
Burggrave: Originally, one appointed to the command of a burg (fortress or castle); but the title afterward became hereditary, with a domain attached.
Besiegement: The act of besieging, or the state of being besieged.
Brahmo-somaj: A modern reforming theistic sect among the Hindus.
backswimmer: any of numerous predaceous aquatic insects of the family Notonectidae (such as Notonecta undulata) that swim on their backs and may inflict painful bites; -- also called boat bug.
Botchery: A botching, or that which is done by botching; clumsy or careless workmanship.
black-tie: requiring semiformal evening clothes, e. g. a black bowtie and a tuxedo or dinner jacket for men, and a formal dress for women; contrasted with white-tie, for a fully formal occasion, and with informal, and casual.
Benedictus: The song of Zacharias at the birth of John the Baptist (Luke i. 68); -- so named from the first word of the Latin version.
B\u00e9ton: The French name for concrete; hence, concrete made after the French fashion.
Bicarbureted: Containing two atoms or equivalents of carbon in the molecule.
Baraca: An international, interdenominational organization of Bible classes of young men; -- so named in allusion to the Hebrew word Berachah (Meaning blessing) occurring in 2 Chron. xx. 26 and 1 Chron. xii.
Bromeliaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, a family of endogenous and mostly epiphytic or saxicolous plants of which the genera Tillandsia and Billbergia are examples. The pineapple, though terrestrial, is also of this family.
Booster: An instrument for regulating the electro-motive force in an alternating-current circuit; -- so called because used to “boost”, or raise, the pressure in the circuit.
Battering-ram: An engine used in ancient times to beat down the walls of besieged places.
basidiosporous: of or pertaining to a basidiospore.
braincase: the part of the skull that encloses the brain.
Becripple: To make a cripple of; to cripple; to lame.
Bethlehemite: An inhabitant of Bethlehem in Judea.
blini: Russian pancakes of buckwheat flour and yeast, sometimes made from white flour; they are usually served folded over, with caviar and sour cream on the inside; -- properly, it is a plural word (from the Russian plural of blin) but in America, often used as singular; thus the common plural blinis.
Bower-Barff process: A certain process for producing upon articles of iron or steel an adherent coating of the magnetic oxide of iron (which is not liable to corrosion by air, moisture, or ordinary acids). This is accomplished by producing, by oxidation at about 1600° F. in a closed space, a coating containing more or less of the ferric oxide (Fe2O3) and the subsequent change of this in a reduced atmosphere to the magnetic oxide (Fe2O4).
Beduck: To duck; to put the head under water; to immerse.
Brushing: Constructed or used to brush with; as a brushing machine.
Burry: Abounding in burs, or containing burs; resembling burs; as, burry wool.
bowlful: the quantity contained in a bowl.
Bordello: a building where prostitutes are available for hire; a brothel.
Bedright: The duty or privilege of the marriage bed.
bisontine: of, relating to, or characteristic of bison.
Backed: Having a back; fitted with a back; as, a backed electrotype or stereotype plate.  Used in composition; as, broad-backed; hump-backed.
blastodisc: a disc-shaped layer of cells on the surface of the yolk mass of an egg (such as that of a bird) which develops to form the embryo.
Bonhomie: good nature; pleasant and easy manner.
Boat-tail: A large grackle or blackbird (Quiscalus major), found in the Southern United States.
Brochantite: A basic sulphate of copper, occurring in emerald-green crystals.
Bellicose: Inclined to war or contention; warlike; pugnacious.
Bonnyclabber: Coagulated sour milk; loppered milk; curdled milk; -- sometimes called simply clabber.
BASIC: an artificial computer language with a relatively simplified instruction set.
Buckler-headed: Having a head like a buckler.
Bedded: Provided with a bed; as, double-bedded room; placed or arranged in a bed or beds.
Brawl: A noisy quarrel; loud, angry contention; a wrangle; a tumult; as, a drunken brawl.
Blame: An expression of disapprobation fir something deemed to be wrong; imputation of fault; censure.
Ball-flower: An ornament resembling a ball placed in a circular flower, the petals of which form a cup round it, -- usually inserted in a hollow molding.
B\u00e9zique: A game at cards in which various combinations of cards in the hand, when declared, score points.
bitching: an informal intensifier; as, we had a bitching good time.
Boracic: Pertaining to, or produced from, borax; containing boron; boric; as, boracic acid.
Brutalize: To become brutal, inhuman, barbarous, or coarse and beasty.
Brachioganoidei: An order of ganoid fishes of which the bichir of Africa is a living example. See Crossopterygii.
bolographic: of or pertaining to a bolograph.
barrelfish: A blackish fish (Hyperglyphe perciformis) of New England waters.
Brevier: A size of type between bourgeois and minion.
Betulaceae: a natural family of monoecious trees and shrubs, including the  genera Betula; Alnus; Carpinus; Corylus; Ostrya; and Ostryopsis.
brainchild: a product of one's creative thinking and work; as, the project was the brainchild of the director.
Bibliopegic: Relating to the binding of books.
Bailys beads: A row of bright spots observed in connection with total eclipses of the sun. Just before and after a total eclipse, the slender, unobscured crescent of the sun's disk appears momentarily like a row of bright spots resembling a string of beads. The phenomenon (first fully described by Francis Baily, 1774 -- 1844) is thought to be an effect of irradiation, and of inequalities of the moon's edge.
Brachydiagonal: The shorter of the diagonals in a rhombic prism.
Bottom: To wind round something, as in making a ball of thread.
Bel-Merodach: (Babylonian) the chief Babylonian god; his consort was Sarpanitu.
Bark beetle: A small beetle of many species (family Scolytidæ), which in the larval state bores under or in the bark of trees, often doing great damage.
Bow-saw: A saw with a thin or narrow blade set in a strong frame.
Blackcoat: A clergyman; -- familiarly so called, as a soldier is sometimes called a redcoat or a bluecoat.
Bookplate: A label, placed upon or in a book, showing its ownership or its position in a library.
Baalist: A worshiper of Baal; a devotee of any false religion; an idolater.
Bay window: A window forming a bay or recess in a room, and projecting outward from the wall, either in a rectangular, polygonal, or semicircular form; -- often corruptly called a bow window.
Bivouac: To watch at night or be on guard, as a whole army.
Bulls-eye: A small circular or oval wooden block without sheaves, having a groove around it and a hole through it, used for connecting rigging.
Binarseniate: A salt having two equivalents of arsenic acid to one of the base.
bioreactor: an apparatus in which a suspension of microorganisms in a liquid are used to perform chemical reactions, as in synthesis of pharmaceutical agents or the conversion of harmful waste to less harmful substances.  The reactor consists of a vessel to contain the suspension of microorganisms, plus a variety of attached devices used to control the reaction.
Barbellate: Having short, stiff hairs, often barbed at the point.
Blandish: To flatter with kind words or affectionate actions; to caress; to cajole.
Bacchanal: A devotee of Bacchus; one who indulges in drunken revels; one who is noisy and riotous when intoxicated; a carouser.
Bassorin: A constituent part of a species of gum from Bassora, as also of gum tragacanth and some gum resins.  It is one of the amyloses.
Berlin: A four-wheeled carriage, having a sheltered seat behind the body and separate from it, invented in the 17th century, at Berlin.
Beam tree: A tree (Pyrus aria) related to the apple.
Biotic: Relating to life; as, the biotic principle.
Blue book: A parliamentary publication, so called from its blue paper covers.
Bel-esprit: A fine genius, or man of wit.
Balmoral: A long woolen petticoat, worn immediately under the dress.
Burmese: Of or pertaining to Burmah, or its inhabitants.
Biplane: Having, or consisting of, two superposed planes, aërocurves, or the like; of or pertaining to a biplane; as, a biplane rudder.
Bed rock: The solid rock underlying superficial formations.  Also Fig.
Backjoint: A rebate or chase in masonry left to receive a permanent slab or other filling.
Bubonic: Of or pertaining to a bubo or buboes; characterized by buboes.
Bescrawl: To cover with scrawls; to scribble over.
Bitter spar: A common name of dolomite; -- so called because it contains magnesia, the soluble salts of which are bitter. See Dolomite.
Beta: The second letter of the Greek alphabet, B, β. See B, and cf. etymology of Alphabet.
Bete: To better; to mend. See Beete.
Bitheism: Belief in the existence of two gods; dualism.
Berth: To give an anchorage to, or a place to lie at; to place in a berth; as, she was berthed stem to stern with the Adelaide.
Bomber jacket: a short men's jacket made of leather, having a zipper in front, knitted cuffs, and ribbed trim.
biogeny: the production of living organisms from other living organisms; same as biogenesis{1}.
Bufferhead: The head of a buffer, which recieves the concussion, in railroad carriages.
Browsing: Browse; also, a place abounding with shrubs where animals may browse.
Behead: To sever the head from; to take off the head of.
Bivalved: Having two valves, as the oyster and some seed pods; bivalve.
Bruise: An injury to the flesh of animals, or to plants, fruit, etc., with a blunt or heavy instrument, or by collision with some other body; a contusion; as, a bruise on the head; bruises on fruit.
Bournonite: A mineral of a steel-gray to black color and metallic luster, occurring crystallized, often in twin crystals shaped like cogwheels (wheel ore), also massive. It is a sulphide of antimony, lead, and copper.
Benefaction: The act of conferring a benefit.
Blancmanger: A sort of fricassee with white sauce, variously made of capon, fish, etc.
Better: One who bets or lays a wager.
Backsword: A sword with one sharp edge.
Black-letter: Written or printed in black letter; as, a black-letter manuscript or book.
Budorcas: a genus of mammals comprising the gnu goats.
Bigamy: The offense of marrying one person when already legally married to another.
Blacksalter: One who makes crude potash, or black salts.
Blastide: A small, clear space in the segments of the ovum, the precursor of the nucleus.
Blear-eyed: Having sore eyes; having the eyes dim with rheum; dim-sighted.
Bonesetter: One who sets broken or dislocated bones; -- commonly applied to one, not a regular surgeon, who makes an occupation of setting bones.
Brachypteres: A group of birds, including auks, divers, and penguins.
busker: a person who entertains people for money in public places (as by singing or dancing).
burrito: a flour tortilla folded around a filling.
Bombolo: A thin spheroidal glass retort or flask, used in the sublimation of camphor.
Barometric: Pertaining to the barometer; made or indicated by a barometer; as, barometric changes; barometrical observations.
benniseed: the small oval seed of the sesame plant.
Bubonocele: An inguinal hernia; esp. that incomplete variety in which the hernial pouch descends only as far as the groin, forming a swelling there like a bubo.
battleship: An armor-plated warship built of steel and heavily armed, generally having over ten thousand tons displacement, and intended to be fit to combat the heaviest enemy ships in line of battle; the most heavily armed and armored class of warship at any given time.
Bombycid: Like or pertaining to the genus Bombyx, or the family Bombycidæ.
Beguinage: A collection of small houses surrounded by a wall and occupied by a community of Beguines.
Brownie: An imaginary good-natured spirit, who was supposed often to perform important services around the house by night, such as thrashing, churning, sweeping.
Bipinnaria: The larva of certain starfishes as developed in the free-swimming stage.
baloney: nonsense; foolishness; bunk; -- also used as an interjection.
barbecuing: Roasting a large piece of meat on a grill or a revolving spit out of doors over an open fire.
Bergomask: A rustic dance, so called in ridicule of the people of Bergamo, in Italy, once noted for their clownishness.
bloodberry: A bushy houseplant (Rivina humilis) having white to pale pink flowers followed by racemes of scarlet berries; it is native to the tropical Americas.
Blankly: In a blank manner; without expression; vacuously; as, to stare blankly.
Bombyliidae: a natural family of dipterous insects comprising the bee flies.
Befall: To come to pass; to happen.
Bullate: Appearing as if blistered; inflated; puckered.
boneheaded: very stupid; -- used of people or actions.
Buntline: One of the ropes toggled to the footrope of a sail, used to haul up to the yard the body of the sail when taking it in.
Bleareye: A disease of the eyelids, consisting in chronic inflammation of the margins, with a gummy secretion of sebaceous matter.
Before: On the fore part; in front, or in the direction of the front; -- opposed to in the rear.
Boneset: A medicinal plant, the thoroughwort (Eupatorium perfoliatum). Its properties are diaphoretic and tonic.
broad-side: to collide with the broad side of.
Bean trefoil: A leguminous shrub of southern Europe, with trifoliate leaves (Anagyris foetida).
Bullfight: a sport of great antiquity, in which men torment, and fight with, a bull or bulls in an arena, for public amusement, -- still popular in Spain, Portugal and Latin American.  In the Spanish version a matador kills the bull with a sword after the bull has been weakened by wounds from small barbed rods, and after he has displayed courage and artistic skill in causing the bull to charge many times while he stands still or nearly still.  In some versions the bull is not killed.  Occasionally the matador is wounded or killed by the bull.
babysitter: A person engaged to care for children when the parents are not home.
Broggle: To sniggle, or fish with a brog.
biomedical engineering: The application of engineeering principles to solve problems in medicine, such as the design of artificial limbs or organs; -- called also bioengineering.
bandura: A traditional Ukrainian stringed musical instrument shaped like a lute, having many strings.
Bullfrog: A very large species of frog (Rana Catesbiana), found in North America; -- so named from its loud bellowing in spring.
Bhutani: a native or inhabitant of Bhutan.
backup: anything kept in reserve to serve as a substitute in case of failure or unavailability of the normal or primary object; -- used for devices, plans, people, etc.  Also used attributively; as, there was no backup for the electrical supply; a backup motor; a backup generator.
Blouse: A light, loose over-garment, like a smock frock, worn especially by workingmen in France; also, a loose coat of any material, as the undress uniform coat of the United States army.
Breech action: The breech mechanism in breech-loading small arms and certain special guns, as automatic and machine guns; -- used frequently in referring to the method by which the movable barrels of breech-loading shotguns are locked, unlocked, or rotated to loading position.
Bittern: The brine which remains in salt works after the salt is concreted, having a bitter taste from the chloride of magnesium which it contains.
backbench: any of the seats occupied by backbenchers in the House of Commons of Great Britain.
Birthday: Of or pertaining to the day of birth, or its anniversary; as, birthday gifts or festivities.
Boistous: Rough or rude; coarse; strong; violent; boisterous; noisy.
Bitters: A liquor, generally spirituous in which a bitter herb, leaf, or root is steeped.
Bayeux tapestry: A piece of linen about 1 ft. 8 in. wide by 213 ft. long, covered with embroidery representing the incidents of William the Conqueror's expedition to England, preserved in the town museum of Bayeux in Normandy. It is probably of the 11th century, and is attributed by tradition to Matilda, the Conqueror's wife.
Butcher: To kill or slaughter (animals) for food, or for market; as, to butcher hogs.
blucher: A kind of half boot, or high shoe, with laces over the tongue; -- named from the Prussian general Blücher.
Barbastel: A European bat (Barbastellus communis), with hairy lips.
Blockhouse: An edifice or structure of heavy timbers or logs for military defense, having its sides loopholed for musketry, and often an upper story projecting over the lower, or so placed upon it as to have its sides make an angle wit the sides of the lower story, thus enabling the defenders to fire downward, and in all directions; -- formerly much used in America and Germany.
barbarisation: the act or process of barbarizing; an act that makes people primitive and uncivilized.
Basifugal: Tending or proceeding away from the base; as, a basifugal growth.
borsht: a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.
Burghbote: A contribution toward the building or repairing of castles or walls for the defense of a city or town.
Barmy: Full of barm or froth; in a ferment.
Brompicrin: A pungent colorless explosive liquid, CNO2Br3, analogous to and resembling chlorpicrin.
Batfowler: One who practices or finds sport in batfowling.
Bemuddle: To muddle; to stupefy or bewilder; to confuse.
Brennage: A tribute which tenants paid to their lord, in lieu of bran, which they were obliged to furnish for his hounds.
birth control: the act or process of deliberately limiting the number of one's children born, especially by preventing conception.
backstroke: a swimming stroke that resembles the crawl except the swimmer lies on his or her back.  It is usually executed with backward-moving circular arm strokes and a flutter kick.
Bessemer steel: Steel made directly from cast iron, by burning out a portion of the carbon and other impurities that the latter contains, through the agency of a blast of air which is forced through the molten metal; -- so called from Sir Henry Bessemer, an English engineer, the inventor of the process.
Bullen-nail: A nail with a round head and short shank, tinned and lacquered.
Bushment: A thicket; a cluster of bushes.
Baculine: Of or pertaining to the rod or punishment with the rod.
Bowfin: A voracious ganoid fish (Amia calva) found in the fresh waters of the United States; the mudfish; -- called also Johnny Grindle, and dogfish.
Bloodbird: An Australian honeysucker (Myzomela sanguineolata); -- so called from the bright red color of the male bird.
beachhead: an area in hostile territory that has been occupied and is held to allow aditional troops and supplies to enter.
blintz: a thin wheat pancake folded around a filling (such as cheese or fruit) and sauteed, fried, or baked.
Bladed: Having a blade or blades; as, a two-bladed knife.
Bedlamite: An inhabitant of a madhouse; a madman.
Baboon: One of the Old World Quadrumana, of the genera Cynocephalus and Papio; the dog-faced ape. Baboons have dog-like muzzles and large canine teeth, cheek pouches, a short tail, and naked callosities on the buttocks. They are mostly African. See Mandrill, and Chacma, and Drill an ape.
Bryozoa: A class of Molluscoidea, including minute animals which by budding form compound colonies; -- called also Polyzoa.
Baroko: A form or mode of syllogism of which the first proposition is a universal affirmative, and the other two are particular negatives.
Bemuse: To muddle, daze, or partially stupefy, as with liquor.
Backlash: The distance through which one part of connected machinery, as a wheel, piston, or screw, can be moved without moving the connected parts, resulting from looseness in fitting or from wear; also, the jarring or reflex motion caused in badly fitting machinery by irregularities in velocity or a reverse of motion.
By-product: A secondary or additional product; something produced, as in the course of a manufacture, in addition to the principal product.
Biramous: Having, or consisting of, two branches.
Bowline: A rope fastened near the middle of the leech or perpendicular edge of the square sails, by subordinate ropes, called bridles, and used to keep the weather edge of the sail tight forward, when the ship is closehauled.
Bowling: The act of playing at or rolling bowls, or of rolling the ball at cricket; the game of bowls or of tenpins.
Baggage master: One who has charge of the baggage at a railway station or upon a line of public travel.
Beethoven: Ludwig van Beethoven, a renowned German composer, born 1770, died 1827.
Baggala: A two-masted Arab or Indian trading vessel, used in the Indian Ocean.
Blendous: Pertaining to, consisting of, or containing, blende.
bloodmobile: a motor vehicle equipped to collect blood donations.
Burgall: A small marine fish; -- also called cunner.
blackout: a suspension of radio or tv broadcasting.
