Blurt: To utter suddenly and unadvisedly; to divulge inconsiderately; to ejaculate; -- commonly with out.
briarroot: the hard woody root of the briar Erica arborea.
Bilalo: A two-masted passenger boat or small vessel, used in the bay of Manila.
Benefit society: A society or association formed for mutual insurance, as among tradesmen or in labor unions, to provide for relief in sickness, old age, and for the expenses of burial. Usually called friendly society in Great Britain.
Brucite: A white, pearly mineral, occurring thin and foliated, like talc, and also fibrous; a native magnesium hydrate.
Bat printing: A mode of printing on glazed ware.
blindside: to attack a person from his blind side; metaphorically, to give a person an unpleasant suprise.
Barkeeper: One who keeps or tends a bar for the sale of liquors.
Bird cherry: A shrub (Prunus Padus ) found in Northern and Central Europe. It bears small black cherries.
brittlebush: fragrant rounded shrub of SW US and adjacent Mexico having brittle stems and small crowded blue-green leaves and yellow flowers; produces a resin used in incense and varnish and in folk medicine.
Battle: To assail in battle; to fight.
blowby: the leakage of gases from the combustion cylinder of an internal combustion engine between the piston and cylinder wall into the crankcase.
Blackcock: The male of the European black grouse (Tetrao tetrix, Linn.); -- so called by sportsmen. The female is called gray hen. See Heath grouse.
Bicuspid: One of the two double-pointed teeth which intervene between the canines (cuspids) and the molars, on each side of each jaw. See Tooth, n.
Bluster: Fitful noise and violence, as of a storm; violent winds; boisterousness.
Bordel: A brothel; a bawdyhouse; a house devoted to prostitution.
bathtub: A relatively large tub used to take a bath, usually a permanent fixture in a bathroom; it is an open container that is filled with water, in which a person immerses himself for the purpose of washing the body.
Border: To make a border for; to furnish with a border, as for ornament; as, to border a garment or a garden.
Bitterwort: The yellow gentian (Gentiana lutea), which has a very bitter taste.
Burkism: The practice of killing persons for the purpose of selling their bodies for dissection.
Bastion: A work projecting outward from the main inclosure of a fortification, consisting of two faces and two flanks, and so constructed that it is able to defend by a flanking fire the adjacent curtain, or wall which extends from one bastion to another. Two adjacent bastions are connected by the curtain, which joins the flank of one with the adjacent flank of the other. The distance between the flanks of a bastion is called the gorge. A lunette is a detached bastion. See Ravelin.
Biolytic: Relating to the destruction of life.
Botryolite: A variety of datolite, usually having a botryoidal structure.
Broadcast: to cast or disperse in all directions, as seed from the hand in sowing; to diffuse widely.
biosystematy: use of data (e. g. cytogenetic or biochemical) to assess taxonomic relations especially within an evolutionary framework.
Betrayal: The act or the result of betraying.
biotope: a region uniform in its environmental conditions and in the types of plants and animals living in it.
Bohemianism: The characteristic conduct or methods of a Bohemian.
Butter: One who, or that which, butts.
Birdie: A pretty or dear little bird; -- a pet name.
Bluff-headed: Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
Bless: To make or pronounce holy; to consecrate
Banking: The business of a bank or of a banker.
browned: having a tan color from exposure to the sun; -- of skin color.
By-turning: An obscure road; a way turning from the main road.
Birectangular: Containing or having two right angles; as, a birectangular spherical triangle.
Blockheadism: That which characterizes a blockhead; stupidity.
Bronzewing: An Australian pigeon of the genus Phaps, of several species; -- so called from its bronze plumage.
breadline: a queue of people waiting for free food.
Bilobate: Divided into two lobes or segments.
Burgage: A tenure by which houses or lands are held of the king or other lord of a borough or city; at a certain yearly rent, or by services relating to trade or handicraft.
Brachyptera: A group of Coleoptera having short wings; the rove beetles.
Breastband: A band for the breast. Specifically: (Naut.) A band of canvas, or a rope, fastened at both ends to the rigging, to support the man who heaves the lead in sounding.
Battlement: One of the solid upright parts of a parapet in ancient fortifications.
beatified: proclaimed one of the blessed and thus worthy of veneration.
Bitten: Terminating abruptly, as if bitten off; premorse.
Bevy: A company; an assembly or collection of persons, especially of ladies.
Beach: To run or drive (as a vessel or a boat) upon a beach; to strand; as, to beach a ship.
Boskiness: Boscage; also, the state or quality of being bosky.
Birch: To whip with a birch rod or twig; to flog.
Bears-ear: A kind of primrose (Primula auricula), so called from the shape of the leaf.
Butyl: A compound radical, regarded as butane, less one atom of hydrogen.
Belemnoidea: an order of extinct dibranchiate cephalopods related to the surviving spirulas.
Binoxalate: A salt having two equivalents of oxalic acid to one of the base; an acid oxalate.
Boatman: A man who manages a boat; a rower of a boat.
bullpen: an open area in a baseball stadium, off the playing field, where pitchers may warm up by throwing a number of trial pitches before playing.
Blight: Mildew; decay; anything nipping or blasting; -- applied as a general name to various injuries or diseases of plants, causing the whole or a part to wither, whether occasioned by insects, fungi, or atmospheric influences.
Butter-scotch: A kind of candy, mainly composed of sugar and butter.
Balearic: Of or pertaining to the isles of Majorca, Minorca, Ivica, etc., in the Mediterranean Sea, off the coast of Valencia.
Bag net: A bag-shaped net for catching fish.
Beclap: To catch; to grasp; to insnare.
Bolshevik: of or pertaining to Bolsheviks or bolshevism.
Baggy: Resembling a bag; loose or puffed out, or pendent, like a bag; flabby; as, baggy trousers; baggy cheeks.
Brickfielder: Orig., at Sydney, a cold and violent south or southwest wind, rising suddenly, and regularly preceded by a hot wind from the north; -- now usually called southerly buster. It blew across the Brickfields, formerly so called, a district of Sydney, and carried clouds of dust into the city.
Brachiopod: One of the Brachiopoda, or its shell.
Backsettler: One living in the back or outlying districts of a community.
Burhel: The wild Himalayan, or blue, sheep (Ovis burrhel).
Becquerel rays: Radiations first observed by the French physicist Henri Becquerel, in working with uranium and its compounds. They consist of a mixture of alpha, beta, and gamma rays.
bonelet: a small bone; especially one in the middle ear.
Bemonster: To make monstrous or like a monster.
Bailor: One who delivers goods or money to another in trust.
Briticism: A word, phrase, or idiom peculiar to Great Britain; any manner of using a word or words that is peculiar to Great Britain.
Bossage: A stone in a building, left rough and projecting, to be afterward carved into shape.
Begonia: A genus of plants, mostly of tropical America, many species of which are grown as ornamental plants. The leaves are curiously one-sided, and often exhibit brilliant colors.
bouldered: abounding in large rocks or stones; as, bouldered fields.
ballistic missile: A rocket-propelled missile of long range which is guided only during the powered portion of its flight, which usually takes only a small part of the total flight time; -- contrasted with guided missile.
Betterness: The quality of being better or superior; superiority.
Blenk: To blink; to shine; to look.
Blend: To make blind, literally or figuratively; to dazzle; to deceive.
Borofluoride: A double fluoride of boron and hydrogen, or some other positive element, or radical; -- called also fluoboride, and formerly fluoborate.
Bleeding: A running or issuing of blood, as from the nose or a wound; a hemorrhage; the operation of letting blood, as in surgery; a drawing or running of sap from a tree or plant.
Boston: A game at cards, played by four persons, with two packs of fifty-two cards each; -- said to be so called from Boston, Massachusetts, and to have been invented by officers of the French army in America during the Revolutionary war.
Brow: To bound to limit; to be at, or form, the edge of.
Brog: To prod with a pointed instrument, as a lance; also, to broggle.
Brob: A peculiar brad-shaped spike, to be driven alongside the end of an abutting timber to prevent its slipping.
Bearhound: A hound for baiting or hunting bears.
bond-servant: A slave; one who is bound to service without wages.
Branchiferous: Having gills; branchiate; as, branchiferous gastropods.
bobfloat: a small float usually made of cork; attached to a fishing line.
Busybody: One who officiously concerns himself with the affairs of others; a meddling person.
Baconian: One who adheres to the philosophy of Lord Bacon.
Broncho-pneumonia: Inflammation of the bronchi and lungs; catarrhal pneumonia.
Bipennis: An ax with an edge or blade on each side of the handle.
Billhead: A printed form, used by merchants in making out bills or rendering accounts.
Blindness: State or condition of being blind, literally or figuratively.
bowed: bent over; -- used of back or head.
Blenny: A marine fish of the genus Blennius or family Blenniidæ; -- so called from its coating of mucus. The species are numerous.
Bloodstick: A piece of hard wood loaded at one end with lead, and used to strike the fleam into the vein.
Breakwater: Any structure or contrivance, as a mole, or a wall at the mouth of a harbor, to break the force of waves, and afford protection from their violence.
Biuret: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, C2O2N3H5, formed by heating urea. It is intermediate between urea and cyanuric acid.
battering: the act or process of subjecting to strong repeated blows.
Baal: The supreme male divinity of the Phoenician and Canaanitish nations.
Borele: The smaller two-horned rhinoceros of South Africa (Atelodus bicornis).
Bombacaceae: a natural family of tropical trees with large dry or fleshy fruit containing usually woolly seeds.
Band-Aid: An adhesive bandage, composed of a short ribbon of cloth or plastic with an adhesive coating on one side, and having a patch of gauze at the center.  It is used to cover small cuts, abrasions, or blisters on the skin, and may be easily applied to and removed from the skin with no additional material.  Originally a trademark, the term has been popularly used generically.
Birthdom: The land of one's birth; one's inheritance.
Bear-trap dam: A kind of movable dam, in one form consisting of two leaves resting against each other at the top when raised and folding down one over the other when lowered, for deepening shallow parts in a river.
Bow-pencil: Bow-compasses, one leg of which carries a pencil.
Butyric: Pertaining to, or derived from, butter.
Butyrin: A butyrate of glycerin; a fat contained in small quantity in milk, which helps to give to butter its peculiar flavor.
Bevelment: The replacement of an edge by two similar planes, equally inclined to the including faces or adjacent planes.
Bourgeoisie: The French middle class, particularly such as are concerned in, or dependent on, trade.
Broadside: The side of a ship above the water line, from the bow to the quarter.
Blandishment: The act of blandishing; a word or act expressive of affection or kindness, and tending to win the heart; soft words and artful caresses; cajolery; allurement.
Bindingness: The condition or property of being binding; obligatory quality.
Burglariously: With an intent to commit burglary; in the manner of a burglar.
ballyhoo: noisy or blatant advertizing or publicity.
Bulbul: The Persian nightingale (Pycnonotus jocosus). The name is also applied to several other Asiatic singing birds, of the family Timaliidæ. The green bulbuls belong to the Chloropsis and allied genera.
Braccate: Furnished with feathers which conceal the feet.
Bufonidae: a natural family comprising the true toads.
Bezel: The rim which encompasses and fastens a jewel or other object, as the crystal of a watch, in the cavity in which it is set.
Bitterwood: A West Indian tree (Picræna excelsa) from the wood of which the bitter drug Jamaica quassia is obtained.
barbell: A bar to which heavy discs are attached at each end; -- it is used for weightlifting exercises.
Bedpost: One of the four standards that support a bedstead or the canopy over a bedstead.
Bibber: One given to drinking alcoholic beverages too freely; a tippler; -- chiefly used in composition; as, winebibber.
Blackthorn: A spreading thorny shrub or small tree (Prunus spinosa), with blackish bark, and bearing little black plums, which are called sloes; the sloe.
Boost: A push from behind, as to one who is endeavoring to climb; help.
Barleybrake: An ancient rural game, commonly played round stacks of barley, or other grain, in which some of the party attempt to catch others who run from a goal.
Blonde: A person of very fair complexion, with light hair and light blue eyes.
Bombax: A genus of trees, called also the silkcotton tree; also, a tree of the genus Bombax.
Bear State: Arkansas; -- a nickname, from the many bears once inhabiting its forests.
Biophor: One of the smaller vital units of a cell, the bearer of vitality and heredity. See Pangen, in Supplement.
Big Board: The New York Stock Exchange; -- a nickname often used in financial reporting.
Balloonry: The art or practice of ascending in a balloon; an older term for ballooning.
Buoyage: Buoys, taken collectively; a series of buoys, as for the guidance of vessels into or out of port; the providing of buoys.
Brash: A rash or eruption; a sudden or transient fit of sickness.
Blackmailer: One who extorts, or endeavors to extort, money, by black mailing.
Brainy: Having an active or vigorous mind.
Bushido: The unwritten code of moral principles regulating the actions of the Japanese knighthood, or Samurai; the chivalry of Japan.
Blain: An inflammatory swelling or sore; a bulla, pustule, or blister.
Broil: To be subjected to the action of heat, as meat over the fire; to be greatly heated, or to be made uncomfortable with heat.
Brass: An alloy (usually yellow) of copper and zinc, in variable proportion, but often containing two parts of copper to one part of zinc. It sometimes contains tin, and rarely other metals.
Bilamellate: Formed of two plates, as the stigma of the Mimulus; also, having two elevated ridges, as in the lip of certain flowers.
Burrel shot: A mixture of shot, nails, stones, pieces of old iron, etc., fired from a cannon at short range, in an emergency.
Backfire: To have or experience a back fire or back fires; -- said of an internal-combustion engine.
Begnaw: To gnaw; to eat away; to corrode.
Bel-accoyle: A kind or favorable reception or salutation.
Bromide: A compound of bromine with a positive radical.
Beauship: The state of being a beau; the personality of a beau.
Bulldog: Characteristic of, or like, a bulldog; stubborn; as, bulldog courage; bulldog tenacity.
Brown bill: A bill or halberd of the 16th and 17th centuries. See 4th Bill.
Bird fancier: One who takes pleasure in rearing or collecting rare or curious birds.
Bindheimite: An amorphous antimonate of lead, produced from the alteration of other ores, as from jamesonite.
Breakneck: Producing danger of a broken neck; as, breakneck speed.
Baggager: One who takes care of baggage; a camp follower.
bullsnake: any of several large harmless rodent-eating North American burrowing snakes of the genus Pituophis.  They include the gopher snake and pine snake.
buckaroo: a cowboy, especially used of one who breaks broncos; --  used especially in California.
Bloody-minded: Having a cruel, ferocious disposition; bloodthirsty.
baseline: an imaginary line or standard by which things are measured or compared; as, they established a baseline for the budget.
Bluestocking: A literary lady; a female pedant.
Born: Brought forth, as an animal; brought into life; introduced by birth.
Bewray: To expose; to reveal; to disclose; to betray.
Bolthead: A long, straight-necked, glass vessel for chemical distillations; -- called also a matrass or receiver.
Britishism: an expression that is limited to English as spoken by Englishmen (especially as contrasted with American English).
Bedash: To wet by dashing or throwing water or other liquid upon; to bespatter.
Beadleship: The state of being, or the personality of, a beadle.
Billethead: A round piece of timber at the bow or stern of a whaleboat, around which the harpoon line is run out when the whale darts off.
Betroth: To contract to any one for a marriage; to engage or promise in order to marriage; to affiance; -- used esp. of a woman.
Branchiomerism: The state of being made up of branchiate segments.
Bicentenary: Of or pertaining to two hundred, esp. to two hundred years; as, a bicentenary celebration.
Brevity: Shortness of duration; briefness of time; as, the brevity of human life.
Beau ideal: A conception or image of consummate beauty, moral or physical, formed in the mind, free from all the deformities, defects, and blemishes seen in actual existence; an ideal or faultless standard or model.
black lung: the popular name for a form of the chronic lung disease pneumoconiosis which is observed among coal miners, and is caused by the inhalation of coal dust.  It is thus named because of the black appearance of the lungs (pneumomelanosis) of those affected with the disease. See also the related condition anthracosis.
buttoned-down: conservatively formal and businesslike in dress and manner.
Borstal: a British reform school for youths between 16 and 22.
Braiser: A kettle or pan for braising.
Bahrein: an island in the Persian Gulf; same as Bahrain.
Barefaced: With the face uncovered; not masked.
Bubbling Jock: The male wild turkey, the gobbler; -- so called in allusion to its notes.
Birds-foot: A papilionaceous plant, the Ornithopus, having a curved, cylindrical pod tipped with a short, clawlike point.
big bang: The explosive event marking the beginning of the known universe, according to big bang theory; the beginning of time.
Billy: A club; esp., a policeman's club.  Also called billy club
Burdensome: Grievous to be borne; causing uneasiness or fatigue; oppressive.
big band: A band that is the size of an orchestra, usually playing mostly jazz or swing music.  The big band typically features both ensemble and solo playing, sometimes has a lead singer, and is often located in a night club where the patrons may dance to its music.  The big bands were popular from the late 1920's to the 1940's.  Contrasted with combo, which has fewer players.
Bose-Einstein statistics: A law of statistical mechanics which is obeyed by a system of particles when interchange of two particles does not change the wave function.  Contrasted to Fermi-Dirac statistics.  See also boson.
Bothersome: Vexatious; causing bother; causing trouble or perplexity; troublesome.
Baldric: A broad belt, sometimes richly ornamented, worn over one shoulder, across the breast, and under the opposite arm; it is used to support a sword or bugle by the left hip; less properly, any belt.
Baldrib: A piece of pork cut lower down than the sparerib, and destitute of fat.
Backlog: A large stick of wood, forming the back of a fire on the hearth.  Contrasted to forestick.
Basal-nerved: Having the nerves radiating from the base; -- said of leaves.
Barbellulate: Barbellate with diminutive hairs or barbs.
Bishops-weed: An umbelliferous plant of the genus Ammi.
brakes: the combination of interacting parts that work to slow a moving vehicle.
bespangled: covered with beads or jewels or sequins.
barycenter: the point representing the mean position of the matter in a body.
brisling: a small fatty European fish; usually smoked or canned.
Butterfly: A general name for the numerous species of diurnal Lepidoptera.
Burhinidae: a natural family of large wading birds resembling the plovers; the stone curlews.
Bustle: A kind of pad or cushion worn on the back below the waist, by women, to give fullness to the skirts; -- called also bishop, and tournure.
Brachyural: Of, pertaining to, or belonging to the Brachyura.
Bonapartean: Of or pertaining to Napoleon Bonaparte or his family.
Bill: To advertise by a bill or public notice.
Bilk: A thwarting an adversary in cribbage by spoiling his score; a balk.
Bedspread: A bedquilt; a counterpane; a coverlet.
Businessman: a person employed in a business at a managerial level, especially an executive or proprietor.
Barometrograph: A form of barometer so constructed as to inscribe of itself upon paper a record of the variations of atmospheric pressure.
brotula: any fish of the family Brotulidae.
Barking irons: Instruments used in taking off the bark of trees.
Bullbeggar: Something used or suggested to produce terror, as in children or persons of weak mind; a bugbear.
blastomycosis: any of several fungal infections caused by blastomycetes; they are characterized by inflammatory lesions of skin and mucous membranes or internal organs.
Biopsychic: Pertaining to psychical phenomena in their relation to the living organism or to the general phenomena of life.
Belonite: Minute acicular or dendritic crystalline forms sometimes observed in glassy volcanic rocks.
Blunderbuss: A short gun or firearm, with a large bore, capable of holding a number of balls, and intended to do execution without exact aim.
Bristle-shaped: Resembling a bristle in form; as, a bristle-shaped leaf.
Billon: An alloy of gold and silver with a large proportion of copper or other base metal, used in coinage.
Bestow: To lay up in store; to deposit for safe keeping; to stow; to place; to put.
Billot: Bullion in the bar or mass.
Billow: To surge; to rise and roll in waves or surges; to undulate.
Borsholder: The head or chief of a tithing, or borough (see 2d Borough); the headborough; a parish constable.
Banderole: A little banner, flag, or streamer.
Blastematic: Connected with, or proceeding from, the blastema; blastemal.
beaten-up: worn by use into a deplorable condition.
Brit: The young of the common herring; also, a small species of herring; the sprat.
Brin: One of the radiating sticks of a fan. The outermost are larger and longer, and are called panaches.
Boracite: A mineral of a white or gray color occurring massive and in isometric crystals; in composition it is a magnesium borate with magnesium chloride.
Basify: To convert into a salifiable base.
Brig: On a United States man-of-war, the prison or place of confinement for offenders.
Bantam work: Carved and painted work in imitation of Japan ware.
Bouge: Bouche (see Bouche, 2); food and drink; provisions.
Binocular: A binocular glass, whether opera glass, telescope, or microscope.
Bushman: A woodsman; a settler in the bush.
Babyhouse: A place for children's dolls and dolls' furniture.
buckbean: A perennial plant (Menyanthes trifoliata)  of Europe and America which grows in moist and boggy places, having racemes of white, reddish,  or purplish flowers and intensely bitter trifoliate leaves, sometimes used in medicine; marsh trefoil; -- called also bog bean.  It often roots at the water margin and spreads across the surface.
Barysphere: The heavy interior portion of the earth, within the lithosphere.
Broken-backed: Having a broken back; as, a broken-backed chair.
Becchis test: A qualitative test for cottonseed oil, based on the fact this oil imparts a maroon color to an alcoholic solution of silver nitrate.
Beauish: Like a beau; characteristic of a beau; foppish; fine.
Bivial: Of or relating to the bivium.
Bluebottle: an annual Eurasian plant (Centaurea cyanus) which grows in grain fields; -- called also bachelor's button. It receives its name from its blue bottle-shaped flowers.  Varieties cultivated in North America have showy heads of blue or purple or pink or white flowers
Burinist: One who works with the burin.
Bey: A governor of a province or district in the Turkish dominions; also, in some places, a prince or nobleman; a beg; as, the bey of Tunis.
Bromalin: A colorless or white crystalline compound, (CH2)6N4C2H5Br, used as a sedative in epilepsy.
Bengal: A province in India, giving its name to various stuffs, animals, etc.
Brimstone: Made of, or pertaining to, brimstone; as, brimstone matches.
Bis-: A form of Bi-, sometimes used before s, c, or a vowel.
Bucentaur: A fabulous monster, half ox, half man.
Balance wheel: A wheel which regulates the beats or pulses of a watch or chronometer, answering to the pendulum of a clock; -- often called simply a balance.
Byssaceous: Byssuslike; consisting of fine fibers or threads, as some very delicate filamentous algæ.
Boldness: The state or quality of being bold.
Ballroom: A room for balls or dancing.
Baroness: A baron's wife; also, a lady who holds the baronial title in her own right; as, the Baroness Burdett-Coutts.
Bowssen: To drench; to soak; especially, to immerse (in water believed to have curative properties).
Borough-English: A custom, as in some ancient boroughs, by which lands and tenements descend to the youngest son, instead of the eldest; or, if the owner have no issue, to the youngest brother.
Botheration: The act of bothering, or state of being bothered; cause of trouble; perplexity; annoyance; vexation.
Bachelorism: Bachelorhood; also, a manner or peculiarity belonging to bachelors.
Buzzingly: In a buzzing manner; with a buzzing sound.
Bizet: The upper faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond, which projects from the setting and occupies the zone between the girdle and the table. See Brilliant, n.
Blite: A genus of herbs (Blitum) with a fleshy calyx. Blitum capitatum is the strawberry blite.
Bean caper: A deciduous plant of warm climates, generally with fleshy leaves and flowers of a yellow or whitish yellow color, of the genus Zygophyllum.
bimetal: a material made by bonding together sheets of two different metals.
Black Friday: Any Friday on which a public disaster has occurred, as: In England, December 6, 1745, when the news of the landing of the Pretender reached London, or May 11, 1866,  when a financial panic commenced. In the United States, September 24, 1869, and September 18, 1873, on which financial panics began.
Betel: A species of pepper (Piper betle), the leaves of which are chewed, with the areca or betel nut and a little shell lime, by the inhabitants of the East Indies. It is a woody climber with ovate many-nerved leaves.
Bulbous: Having or containing bulbs, or a bulb; growing from bulbs; bulblike in shape or structure.
Banns: Notice of a proposed marriage, proclaimed in a church, or other place prescribed by law, in order that any person may object, if he knows of just cause why the marriage should not take place.
blitz: a quick move by defensive players toward the passer on the offensive team, as soon as the ball is snapped; -- it is used when the defensive teams assumes that a pass will be attempted, and risks allowing substantial gains by the offensive team if other plays are in fact planned.
Badgering: The act of one who badgers.
Bar\u00e9ge: A gauzelike fabric for ladies' dresses, veils, etc. of worsted, silk and worsted, or cotton and worsted.
Bioplast: A tiny mass of bioplasm, in itself a living unit and having formative power, as a living white blood corpuscle; bioblast.
Bioplasm: A name suggested by Dr. Beale for the germinal matter supposed to be essential to the functions of all living beings; the material through which every form of life manifests itself; unaltered protoplasm.
Berna fly: A Brazilian dipterous insect of the genus Trypeta, which lays its eggs in the nostrils or in wounds of man and beast, where the larvæ do great injury.
Booking office: An office where passengers, baggage, etc., are registered for conveyance, as by railway or steamship.
Beetle-browed: Having prominent, overhanging brows; hence, lowering or sullen.
Bull fly: Any large fly troublesome to cattle, as the gadflies and breeze flies.
brunet: A girl or woman with a somewhat brown or dark complexion.
Blancher: One who, or that which, frightens away or turns aside.
Bricklaying: The art of building with bricks, or of uniting them by cement or mortar into various forms; the act or occupation of laying bricks.
Back: In, to, or toward, the rear; as, to stand back; to step back.
Balaam: A paragraph describing something wonderful, used to fill out a newspaper column; -- an allusion to the miracle of Balaam's ass speaking.
Biotaxy: The classification of living organisms according to their structural character; taxonomy.
Bipartition: The act of dividing into two parts, or of making two correspondent parts, or the state of being so divided.
buildup: the act of building up an accumulation.
Breathing: Respiration; the act of inhaling and exhaling air.
blockaded: having access obstructed by emplacement of a barrier, or by threat of force.
Breastknot: A knot of ribbons worn on the breast.
Brotulidae: a natural family of chiefly deep-sea fishes related to the Ophidiidae.
billyo: a large amount; British say "it rained like billyo" where Americans say "it rained like the devil".
Bawcock: A fine fellow; -- a term of endearment.
Boarder: One who has food statedly at another's table, or meals and lodgings in his house, for pay, or compensation of any kind.
benchmark: Any permanent mark to which other levels may be referred.
Bottle green: A dark shade of green, like that of bottle glass.
beachcomber: A vagrant seaman, usually of low character, who loiters about seaports, particularly on the shores and islands of the Pacific Ocean.
boards: the boarding that surrounds an ice hockey rink.
buffalo nickel: A United States five-cent coin minted from 1913 to 1937 having an image of an American bison (“buffalo”) on its reverse, and an American Indian on the obverse.
Bunsen burner: a kind of burner, invented by Professor Bunsen of Heidelberg, consisting of a straight tube, four or five inches in length, having small holes for the entrance of air at the bottom.  Illuminating gas being also admitted at the bottom, a mixture of gas and air is formed which burns at the top with a feebly luminous but intensely hot flame.
Bonbon: Sugar confectionery; a sugarplum; hence, any dainty.
Beagle: A small hound, or hunting dog, twelve to fifteen inches high, used in hunting hares and other small game.  See Illustration in Appendix.
Boatbill: A wading bird (Cancroma cochlearia) of the tropical parts of South America. Its bill is somewhat like a boat with the keel uppermost.
Basipterygoid: Applied to a protuberance of the base of the sphenoid bone.
B-52: A large long-range bomber airplane of the U. S. military aircraft fleet; B- stands for bomber.  It has the capability of delivering nuclear weapons.
Beast: Any living creature; an animal; -- including man, insects, etc.
Brewhouse: A house or building appropriated to brewing; a brewery.
Blackberry: The fruit of several species of bramble (Rubus); also, the plant itself. Rubus fruticosus is the blackberry of England; Rubus villosus and Rubus Canadensis are the high blackberry and low blackberry of the United States. There are also other kinds.
Branchless: Destitute of branches or shoots; without any valuable product; barren; naked.
Brangle: To wrangle; to dispute contentiously; to squabble.
Breezy: Characterized by, or having, breezes; airy.
Bordar: A villein who rendered menial service for his cottage; a cottier.
Be-all: The whole; all that is to be.
bullheadedness: resolute adherence to one's own ideas or desires.
Bullantic: Pertaining to, or used in, papal bulls.
Beethovenian: of or pertaining to Ludwig van Beethoven.
Body: To furnish with, or as with, a body; to produce in definite shape; to embody.
Buffer: An elastic apparatus or fender, for deadening the jar caused by the collision of bodies; as, a buffer at the end of a railroad car.
Blatterer: One who blatters; a babbler; a noisy, blustering boaster.
Buffet: To exercise or play at boxing; to strike; to smite; to strive; to contend.
Browed: Having (such) a brow; -- used in composition; as, dark-browed, stern-browed.
Bassariscidae: a division of mammals, in some classifications considered a separate family.
Brother: To make a brother of; to call or treat as a brother; to admit to a brotherhood.
Butment: A buttress of an arch; the supporter, or that part which joins it to the upright pier.
Brothel: A house of lewdness or ill fame; a house frequented by prostitutes; a bawdyhouse.
Breloque: A seal or charm for a watch chain.
Beguiling: Alluring by guile; deluding; misleading; diverting.
Bridler: One who bridles; one who restrains and governs, as with a bridle.
Bovinae: a term essentially coextensive with the genus Bos, including cattle, buffalo, and sometimes kudu; -- it is not used technically.
Blue-eyed grass: a grasslike plant (Sisyrinchium anceps), with small flowers of a delicate blue color.
Bellman: A man who rings a bell, especially to give notice of anything in the streets. Formerly, also, a night watchman who called the hours.
Bona fides: Good faith; honesty; freedom from fraud or deception.
banqueting: Eating an elaborate meal (often accompanied by entertainment).
Basisolute: Prolonged at the base, as certain leaves.
Bespit: To daub or soil with spittle.
Backdoor: Acting from behind and in concealment; backstairs; as, backdoor intrigues.
Breeding: The act or process of generating or bearing.
Beatify: To pronounce or regard as happy, or supremely blessed, or as conferring happiness.
butch: a lesbian who is noticeably masculine.
Beginning: The act of doing that which begins anything; commencement of an action, state, or space of time; entrance into being or upon a course; the first act, effort, or state of a succession of acts or states.
balls-up: something badly botched or muddled; a foul-up.
Benevolence: The disposition to do good; good will; charitableness; love of mankind, accompanied with a desire to promote their happiness.
Burette: An apparatus for delivering measured quantities of liquid or for measuring the quantity of liquid or gas received or discharged. It consists essentially of a graduated glass tube, usually furnished with a small aperture and stopcock.
Bloomer: A costume for women, consisting of a short dress, with loose trousers gathered round ankles, and (commonly) a broad-brimmed hat.
Brightly: Brilliantly; splendidly; with luster; as, brightly shining armor.
Blue Hen State: The State of Delaware; -- a popular sobriquet. It is said, though the story lacks proof, to have taken its origin from the insistence of a Delaware Revolutionary captain, named Caldwell, that no cock could be truly game unless the mother was a blue hen, whence Blue Hen's Chickens came to be a nickname for the people of Delaware.
Brawner: A boor killed for the table.
Burnettize: To subject (wood, fabrics, etc.) to a process of saturation in a solution of chloride of zinc, to prevent decay; -- a process invented by Sir William Burnett.
Bin-: A euphonic form of the prefix Bi-.
Bugler: One who plays on a bugle.
Blowfly: Any species of fly of the genus Musca that deposits its eggs or young larvæ (called flyblows and maggots) upon meat or other animal products.
Brevoortia: a genus of fishes consisting of the menhaden.
busybodied: intruding unasked into the affairs of others.
Basyle: A positive or nonacid constituent of compound, either elementary, or, if compound, performing the functions of an element.
Boric: Of, pertaining to, or containing, boron.
Berylloid: A solid consisting of a double twelve-sided pyramid; -- so called because the planes of this form occur on crystals of beryl.
Bevile: A chief broken or opening like a carpenter's bevel.
ballet slipper: a heelless slipper specifically designed to be worn by ballet dancers while dancing.
butanol: a flammable alcohol (C4H9.OH) derived from butane and used as a solvent.
Bridgeing: The system of bracing used between floor or other timbers to distribute the weight.
Bine: The winding or twining stem of a hop vine or other climbing plant.
Bugleweed: A plant of the Mint family and genus Lycopus; esp. Lycopus Virginicus, which has mild narcotic and astringent properties, and is sometimes used as a remedy for hemorrhage.
Bing: A heap or pile; as, a bing of wood.
Beflower: To besprinkle or scatter over with, or as with, flowers.
Burstwort: A plant (Herniaria glabra) supposed to be valuable for the cure of hernia or rupture.
Burrow: To excavate a hole to lodge in, as in the earth; to lodge in a hole excavated in the earth, as conies or rabbits.
Black book: One of several books of a political character, published at different times and for different purposes; -- so called either from the color of the binding, or from the character of the contents.
Bogberry: The small cranberry (Vaccinium oxycoccus), which grows in boggy places.
Breadfruit: The fruit of a tree (Artocarpus incisa)  found in the islands of the Pacific, esp. the South Sea islands. It is of a roundish form, from four to six or seven inches in diameter, and, when baked, somewhat resembles bread, and is eaten as food, whence the name.
bimli: a valuable fiber plant (Hibiscus cannabinus) of the East Indies now widespread in cultivation.
Bojanus organ: A glandular organ of bivalve mollusca, serving in part as a kidney.
Biographer: One who writes an account or history of the life of a particular person; a writer of lives, as Plutarch.
Broomstick: A stick used as a handle of a broom.
Blastogenesis: Multiplication or increase by gemmation or budding.
butadiene: a gaseous hydrocarbon C4H6; -- it is used as a monomer unit in making synthetic rubbers.
Baric: Of or pertaining to weight, esp. to the weight or pressure of the atmosphere as measured by the barometer.
Batman: A man who has charge of a bathorse and his load.
Bowery: Characteristic of the street called the Bowery, in New York city; swaggering; flashy.
Bacchus: The god of wine, son of Jupiter and Semele.
bloodbath: Indiscriminate slaughter; the killing of multiple persons.
Balize: A pole or a frame raised as a sea beacon or a landmark.
Braunite: A native oxide of manganese, of dark brownish black color. It was named from a Mr. Braun of Gotha.
Battening: Furring done with small pieces nailed directly upon the wall.
blastoff: the launching of a rocket, especially of a spacecraft, under its own power.
bosun: a petty officer on a merchant ship who controls the work of other seamen; a contraction of boatswain.
Battering train: A train of artillery for siege operations.
Bugle: A plant of the genus Ajuga of the Mint family, a native of the Old World.
Burschenschaft: In Germany, any of various associations of university students formed (the original one at Jena in 1815) to support liberal ideas, or the organization formed by the affiliation of the local bodies. The organization was suppressed by the government in 1819, but was secretly revived, and is now openly maintained as a social organization, the restrictive laws having been repealed prior to 1849.
booyong: large tree (Heritiera trifoliolata or Terrietia trifoliolata) of Australasia.
Beneficent: Doing or producing good; performing acts of kindness and charity; characterized by beneficence.
Bethumb: To handle; to wear or soil by handling; as books.
bath towel: a large towel used to dry oneself after a bath.
Bookbinding: The art, process, or business of binding books.
Bezonian: A low fellow or scoundrel; a beggar.
Bajocco: A small copper coin formerly current in the Roman States, worth about a cent and a half.
Bluets: A name given to several different species of plants having blue flowers, as the Houstonia cœrulea, the Centaurea cyanus or bluebottle, and the Vaccinium angustifolium.
Buchu: A South African shrub (Barosma) with small leaves that are dotted with oil glands; also, the leaves themselves, which are used in medicine for diseases of the urinary organs, etc. Several species furnish the leaves.
Basely: In a base manner; with despicable meanness; dishonorably; shamefully.
Beacon: To give light to, as a beacon; to light up; to illumine.
Bismuthyl: Hydrous carbonate of bismuth, an earthy mineral of a dull white or yellowish color.
Black-faced: Having a black, dark, or gloomy face or aspect.
Black Hand: A Spanish anarchistic society, many of the members of which were imprisoned in 1883.
Bubble shell: A marine univalve shell of the genus Bulla and allied genera, belonging to the Tectibranchiata.
bakshis: A relatively small amount of money given for services rendered (as by a waiter).  Same as Backsheesh.
Battable: Capable of cultivation; fertile; productive; fattening.
Bipeltate: Having a shell or covering like a double shield.
Buckram: To strengthen with buckram; to make stiff.
Buffa: The comic actress in an opera.
Beambird: A small European flycatcher (Muscicapa grisola), so called because it often nests on a beam in a building.
Brahmanist: An adherent of the religion of the Brahmans.
bakshish: A relatively small amount of money given for services rendered (as by a waiter).  Same as Backsheesh.
By-speech: An incidental or casual speech, not directly relating to the point.
bollock: one of the two male reproductive glands; a testis; -- usually spelled ballock, and usually used in the plural.
Bergschrund: The crevasse or series of crevasses, usually deep and often broad, frequently occurring near the head of a mountain glacier, about where the névé field joins the valley portion of the glacier.
Brahmanism: The religion or system of doctrines of the Brahmans; the religion of Brahma.
Biscutella: a genus off Eurasian herbs and small shrubs: buckler mustard.
Beriberi: An acute disease occurring in India, characterized by multiple inflammatory changes in the nerves, producing great muscular debility, a painful rigidity of the limbs, and cachexy.
Bastinado: To beat with a stick or cudgel, especially on the soles of the feet.
Bivalve: Having two shells or valves which open and shut, as the oyster and certain seed vessels.
Backwoods: The forests or partly cleared grounds on the frontiers.
biradial: showing both bilateral and radial symmetry.
Bending: The marking of the clothes with stripes or horizontal bands.
ballyrag: to be bossy towards; same as bullyrag.
bellboy: someone employed as an errand boy and luggage carrier around hotels.
Barcarolle: A popular song or melody sung by Venetian gondoliers.
Bergmeal: An earthy substance, resembling fine flour. It is composed of the shells of infusoria, and in Lapland and Sweden is sometimes eaten, mixed with flour or ground birch bark, in times of scarcity. This name is also given to a white powdery variety of calcite.
Black art: The art practiced by conjurers and witches; necromancy; conjuration; magic.
Bethink: To think; to recollect; to consider.
Brachycephaly: The state or condition of being brachycephalic; shortness of head.
Balustrade: A row of balusters topped by a rail, serving as an open parapet, as along the edge of a balcony, terrace, bridge, or the eaves of a building, or as a guard railing on a staircase; -- it serves as a guard to prevent people from falling.
Bloated: Distended beyond the natural or usual size, as by the presence of water, serum, etc.; turgid; swollen; as, a bloated face. Also, puffed up with pride; pompous.
Bubonic plague: a severe and often fatal disease caused by infection with the bacterium Yersinia pestis (formerly Pasteurella pestis), transmitted to man by the bite of fleas, themselves usually infected by biting infected rodents.  It is characterized by the formation of buboes, most notably on the groin and armpits, and accompanied by weakness and high fever.  The disease was known as the black death, and was responsible for several devastating plagues throughout the middle ages.  When lungs became infected, the disease was called the pneumonic plague.  It is still found occasionally in poor areas of undeveloped countries but is rare in developed countries.
brunch: a late breakfast or an early lunch.
Bloater: The common herring, esp. when of large size, smoked, and half dried; -- called also bloat herring.
Barocyclonometer: An aneroid barometer for use with accompanying graphic diagrams and printed directions designed to aid mariners to interpret the indications of the barometer so as to determine the existence of a violent storm at a distance of several hundred miles.
Bearing: The manner in which one bears or conducts one's self; mien; behavior; carriage.
Bricky: Full of bricks; formed of bricks; resembling bricks or brick dust.
bumper-to-bumper: moving slowly with little space between; -- used of road traffic.
Bribeless: Incapable of being bribed; free from bribes.
Bottled: Put into bottles; inclosed in bottles; pent up in, or as in, a bottle.
Bluestockingism: The character or manner of a bluestocking; female pedantry.
Black Flags: An organization composed originally of Chinese rebels that had been driven into Tonkin by the suppression of the Taiping rebellion, but later increased by bands of pirates and adventurers. It took a prominent part in fighting the French during their hostilities with Anam, 1873-85.
backdate: to make effective from an earlier date; to make retroactive.
Betime: In good season or time; before it is late; seasonably; early.
Beat: One that beats, or surpasses, another or others; as, the beat of him.
Beau: A man who takes great care to dress in the latest fashion; a dandy.
Besprinkling: The act of sprinkling anything; a sprinkling over.
Bear: Barley; the six-rowed barley or the four-rowed barley, commonly the former (Hordeum hexastichon or Hordeum vulgare).
Beal: To gather matter; to swell and come to a head, as a pimple.
Bean: A name given to the seed of certain leguminous herbs, chiefly of the genera Faba, Phaseolus, and Dolichos; also, to the herbs.
Beak: The bill or nib of a bird, consisting of a horny sheath, covering the jaws.  The form varies much according to the food and habits of the bird, and is largely used in the classification of birds.
Barbette: A mound of earth or a platform in a fortification, on which guns are mounted to fire over the parapet.
Boyishness: The manners or behavior of a boy.
Bargainor: One who makes a bargain, or contracts with another; esp., one who sells, or contracts to sell, property to another.
Blue-grass State: The Sate of Kentucky; -- a nickname alluding to the blue-grass region, where fine horses are bred.
Blackguardly: In the manner of or resembling a blackguard; abusive; scurrilous; ruffianly.
BC: before Christ; used in reckoning dates before the supposed year Christ was born, i.e. 1 a. d..
Bona fide: In or with good faith; without fraud or deceit; real or really; actual or actually; genuine or genuinely; as, you must proceed bona fide; a bona fide purchaser or transaction.
broadbean: an Old World upright plant grown esp. for its large flat edible seeds but also as fodder.
BW: biological warfare; the use of bacteria or viruses or toxins to destroy men and animals or food.
Battology: A needless repetition of words in speaking or writing.
Bannockburn: A battle in which the Scots under Robert the Bruce defeated the English and assured the independence of Scotland.
Be: To exist actually, or in the world of fact; to have existence.
Betoss: To put in violent motion; to agitate; to disturb; to toss.
Bronchus: One of the subdivisions of the trachea or windpipe; esp. one of the two primary divisions.
By: Out of the common path; aside; -- used in composition, giving the meaning of something aside, secondary, or incidental, or collateral matter, a thing private or avoiding notice; as, by-line, by-place, by-play, by-street. It was formerly more freely used in composition than it is now; as, by-business, by-concernment, by-design, by-interest, etc.
Bougie d\u00e9cimale: A photometric standard used in France, having the value of one twentieth of the Violle platinum standard, or slightly less than a British standard candle. Called also decimal candle.
Bull brier: A species of Smilax (Smilax Pseudo-China) growing from New Jersey to the Gulf of Mexico, which has very large tuberous and farinaceous rootstocks, formerly used by the Indians for a sort of bread, and by the negroes as an ingredient in making beer; -- called also bamboo brier and China brier.
boardinghouse: a private house that provides accommodations and meals for paying guests.
Bopeep: The act of looking out suddenly, as from behind a screen, so as to startle some one (as by children in play), or of looking out and drawing suddenly back, as if frightened.
Black-mouthed: Using foul or scurrilous language; slanderous.
Black comedy: a comedy that treats of morbid, tragic, gloomy, or grotesque situations as a major element of the plot.
Bicapsular: Having two capsules; as, a bicapsular pericarp.
Barth: A place of shelter for cattle.
Breach: To break the water, as by leaping out; -- said of a whale.
Binnacle: A case or box placed near the helmsman, containing the compass of a ship, and a light to show it at night.
Billabong: In Australia, a blind channel leading out from a river; -- sometimes called an anabranch. This is the sense of the word as used in the Public Works Department; but the term has also been locally applied to mere back-waters forming stagnant pools and to certain water channels arising from a source.
Bulk: A projecting part of a building.
Bladderwort: A genus (Utricularia) of aquatic or marshy plants, which usually bear numerous vesicles in the divisions of the leaves. These serve as traps for minute animals. See Ascidium.
Bunter: A woman who picks up rags in the streets; hence, a low, vulgar woman.
Bulb: To take the shape of a bulb; to swell.
Bobbinet: A kind of cotton lace which is wrought by machines, and not by hand.
Baseness: The quality or condition of being base; degradation; vileness.
Boozer: One who boozes; a toper; a guzzler of alcoholic liquors; a bouser.
Boswellian: Relating to, or characteristic of, Dr. Johnson's biographer, James Boswell, whose hero worship made his narrative a faithful but often uncritical record of details.
Black-browed: Having black eyebrows. Hence: Gloomy; dismal; threatening; forbidding.
Beakhead: An ornament used in rich Norman doorways, resembling a head with a beak.
Bespot: To mark with spots, or as with spots.
Backband: The band which passes over the back of a horse and holds up the shafts of a carriage.
Barnstorm: To travel from place to place, making brief stops.
Boulevardier: A frequenter of a city boulevard, esp. in Paris.
Bandelet: A small band or fillet; any little band or flat molding, compassing a column, like a ring, and usually at the top of the column; an annulet.
Bilection: That portion of a group of moldings which projects beyond the general surface of a panel; a bolection.
Botany: The science which treats of the structure of plants, the functions of their parts, their places of growth, their classification, and the terms which are employed in their description and denomination. See Plant.
Bulse: A purse or bag in which to carry or measure diamonds, etc.
Bail bond: A bond or obligation given by a prisoner and his surety, to insure the prisoner's appearance in court, at the return of the writ.
Bowls: See Bowl, a ball, a game.
barbershop: a shop where a barber works, especially one where men can get their hair cut.
Benzosol: Guaiacol benzoate, used as an intestinal antiseptic and as a substitute for creosote in phthisis. It is a colorless crystalline pewder.
Bow-bells: The bells of Bow Church in London; cockneydom.
Bordrag: An incursion upon the borders of a country; a raid.
Biradiate: Having two rays; as, a biradiate fin.
Blowpipe: A tube for directing a jet of air into a fire or into the flame of a lamp or candle, so as to concentrate the heat on some object.
Bullfinch: A bird of the genus Pyrrhula and other related genera, especially the Pyrrhula vulgaris or Pyrrhula rubicilla, a bird of Europe allied to the grosbeak, having the breast, cheeks, and neck, red.
baksheesh: A relatively small amount of money given for services rendered (as by a waiter).  Same as Backsheesh.
Bedwarf: To make a dwarf of; to stunt or hinder the growth of; to dwarf.
Byzantium: An ancient city on the Bosporus founded by the Greeks.  It was later renamed Constaninople in honor of the emperor Constantine, and renamed Istanbul by the Turks, which name it still retains.
Bladefish: A long, thin, marine fish of Europe (Trichiurus lepturus); the ribbon fish.
Besides: Over and above; separate or distinct from; in addition to; other than; else than. See Beside, prep., 3, and Syn. under Beside.
Boron: A nonmetallic element occurring abundantly in borax. It is reduced with difficulty to the free state, when it can be obtained in several different forms; viz., as a substance of a deep olive color, in a semimetallic form, and in colorless quadratic crystals similar to the diamond in hardness and other properties. It occurs in nature also in boracite, datolite, tourmaline, and some other minerals. Atomic number 5. Atomic weight 10.81. Symbol B.
Bottleneck: a location or situation in which otherwise rapid progress is impeded.
Bombardo: Originally, a deep-toned instrument of the oboe or bassoon family; thence, a bass reed stop on the organ. The name bombardon is now given to a brass instrument, the lowest of the saxhorns, in tone resembling the ophicleide.
belly laugh: a vigorous, loud laugh, expressing a strong amusement.
Beatification: The act of beatifying, or the state of being beatified; esp., in the R. C. Church, the act or process of ascertaining and declaring that a deceased person is one of “the blessed,” or has attained the second degree of sanctity, -- usually a stage in the process of canonization.
Bancal: An ornamental covering, as of carpet or leather, for a bench or form.
backstage: concealed from the public; in private.
Braggadocio: A braggart; a boaster; a swaggerer.
Bipartite: Being in two parts; having two correspondent parts, as a legal contract or writing, one for each party; shared by two; as, a bipartite treaty.
Basedows disease: A disease characterized by enlargement of the thyroid gland, prominence of the eyeballs, and inordinate action of the heart; -- called also exophthalmic goiter.
Bloodstone: A green siliceous stone sprinkled with red jasper, as if with blood; hence the name; -- called also heliotrope.
Bulrush: A kind of large rush, growing in wet land or in water.
Bailee: The person to whom goods are committed in trust, and who has a temporary possession and a qualified property in them, for the purposes of the trust.
Burnet: A genus of perennial herbs (Poterium); especially, Poterium Sanguisorba, the common, or garden, burnet.
Birdbolt: A short blunt arrow for killing birds without piercing them.
By-stroke: An accidental or a slyly given stroke.
Bailey: The outer wall of a feudal castle.
Bordman: A bordar; a tenant in bordage.
battleground: a region where a battle is fought; same as battlefield.
bacteriostasis: inhibition of the growth of bacteria, without outright killing of the organism.
Brinded: Of a gray or tawny color with streaks of darker hue; streaked; brindled.
Beshow: A large food fish (Anoplopoma fimbria) of the north Pacific coast; -- called also candlefish.
blacking: Any preparation for making things black; esp. one for giving a black luster to boots and shoes, or to stoves.
Butyrometer: An instrument for determining the amount of fatty matter or butter contained in a sample of milk.
Brimless: Having no brim; as, brimless caps.
Brew: The mixture formed by brewing; that which is brewed.
Bacillar: Shaped like a rod or staff.
Buchloe: a genus of grasses comprising buffalo grass.
Belecture: To vex with lectures; to lecture frequently.
Beechen: Consisting, or made, of the wood or bark of the beech; belonging to the beech.
Blushy: Like a blush; having the color of a blush; rosy.
Bell-faced: Having the striking surface convex; -- said of hammers.
Barbicel: One of the small hooklike processes on the barbules of feathers.
bimonthly: Occurring, done, or coming, once in two months; as, bimonthly visits; bimonthly publications.
Byway: A secluded, private, or obscure way; a path or road aside from the main one.
Bender: One who, or that which, bends.
Blende: A mineral, called also sphalerite, and by miners mock lead, false galena, and black-jack. It is a zinc sulphide, but often contains some iron. Its color is usually yellow, brown, or black, and its luster resinous.
Batis: A small genus of plants constituting the family Batidaceae: low straggling dioecious shrubs.
Bignoniaceae: a natural family comprising the trees or shrubs or woody vines or herbs having gourdlike or capsular fruit; the are sometimes placed in the order Scrophulariales.
brenschluss: the time at which the engines of a rocket stop firing; the termination of the firing of the rocket engines, whether due to intentional shutdown of the engines or exhaustion of the fuel.  This term was used mostly in the early days of rocketry when only one firing sequence occurred for rockets, which were used as ballistic missiles or for experiments in rocketry or atmospheric science.
Bigeye: A fish of the genus Priacanthus, remarkable for the large size of the eye.
Bronchitis: Inflammation, acute or chronic, of the bronchial tubes or any part of them.
Breedbate: One who breeds or originates quarrels.
Bronchitic: Of or pertaining to bronchitis; as, bronchitic inflammation.
Bishops-wort: Wood betony (Stachys betonica); also, the plant called fennel flower (Nigella Damascena), or devil-in-a-bush.
Beslime: To daub with slime; to soil.
Bassoon: A wind instrument of the double reed kind, furnished with holes, which are stopped by the fingers, and by keys, as in flutes. It forms the natural bass to the oboe, clarinet, etc.
Bookcase: A case with shelves for holding books, esp. one with glazed doors.
Bureaucratist: An advocate for, or supporter of, bureaucracy.
Breechloader: A firearm which receives its load at the breech.
Bibcock: A cock or faucet having a bent down nozzle.
Bombproof: Secure against the explosive force of bombs.
biotin: a B vitamin (C10H16N2O3S) that aids in body growth; -- called also vitamin H and coenzyme R.  It functions as a coenzyme in many carboxylation reactions.
blindfold: a flexible object placed over the eyes to prevent seeing; usually a strip of cloth wrapped around the head so as to cover the eyes.
Bacterioscopy: The application of a knowledge of bacteria for their detection and identification, as in the examination of polluted water.
Beguiler: One who, or that which, beguiles.
Barnyard: A yard belonging to a barn.
Blinder: One who, or that which, blinds.
bore-hole: a hole or passage made by a drill, especially one made for exploratory purposes.
brachytactyly: abnormal shortness of fingers and toes.
Borough: An association of men who gave pledges or sureties to the king for the good behavior of each other.
Blow-out: The cleaning of the flues of a boiler from scale, etc., by a blast of steam.
babbiting: lining a surface or bearing with babbitt metal.
Bemoil: To soil or encumber with mire and dirt.
Bootikin: A little boot, legging, or gaiter.
Boatable: Such as can be transported in a boat.
Burglary: Breaking and entering the dwelling house of another, in the nighttime, with intent to commit a felony therein, whether the felonious purpose be accomplished or not.
briefcase: a small suitcase with a handle; it is used for carrying papers or files or books.
Birds nest: The nest in which a bird lays eggs and hatches her young.
Bonne: A female servant charged with the care of a young child.
Boisterous: Rough or rude; unbending; unyielding; strong; powerful.
Bestowment: The act of giving or bestowing; a conferring or bestowal.
butter-print: tall annual herb or subshrub of tropical Asia having velvety leaves and yellow flowers and yielding a strong fiber; naturalized in SE Europe and US.
Bluethroat: A singing bird of northern Europe and Asia (Cyanecula Suecica), related to the nightingales; -- called also blue-throated robin and blue-throated warbler.
Barytes: Barium sulphate, generally called heavy spar or barite. See Barite.
Bitumen process: Any process in which  advantage is taken of the fact that prepared bitumen is rendered insoluble by exposure to light, as in photolithography.
Biscayan: Of or pertaining to Biscay in Spain.
Bilinear: Of, pertaining to, or included by, two lines; as, bilinear coördinates.
Brood: To sit over, cover, and cherish; as, a hen broods her chickens.
Bucks-horn: A plant with leaves branched somewhat like a buck's horn (Plantago Coronopus); also, Lobelia coronopifolia.
Besprinkle: To sprinkle over; to scatter over.
Blur: That which obscures without effacing; a stain; a blot, as upon paper or other substance.
baiting: harassment, especially of a tethered animal.
Basquish: Pertaining to the country, people, or language of Biscay; Basque
Beck: A significant nod, or motion of the head or hand, esp. as a call or command.
Buccal: Of or pertaining to the mouth or cheeks.
Buccan: To expose (meat) in strips to fire and smoke upon a buccan.
Bobfly: The fly at the end of the leader; an end fly.
Bobby: A nickname for a British policeman; -- from Sir Robert Peel, who remodeled the police force. See Peeler.
Billman: One who uses, or is armed with, a bill or hooked ax.
bankroll: To pay the costs of; as, Who will bankroll the restoration of the former East German economy?.
Biotite: Mica containing iron and magnesia, generally of a black or dark green color; -- a common constituent of crystalline rocks. See Mica.
Buhl: Decorative woodwork in which tortoise shell, yellow metal, white metal, etc., are inlaid, forming scrolls, cartouches, etc.
Boottopping: The act or process of daubing a vessel's bottom near the surface of the water with a mixture of tallow, sulphur, and resin, as a temporary protection against worms, after the slime, shells, etc., have been scraped off.
Barogram: A tracing, usually made by the barograph, showing graphically the variations of atmospheric pressure for a given time.
Berberine: An alkaloid obtained, as a bitter, yellow substance, from the root of the barberry, gold thread, and other plants.
Behave: To act; to conduct; to bear or carry one's self; as, to behave well or ill.
bodywork: the exterior body of a motor vehicle.
Bewash: To drench or souse with water.
Baptize: To administer the sacrament of baptism to.
bellybutton: The depression in the middle of the abdomen in humans left as a residue of the umbilical cord; the umbilicus; the navel{1}.
ballet mistress: a woman who trains ballet dancers.
breathalyze: to test the alcohol content of someone's blood by means of a breathalyzer.
Botocudos: A Brazilian tribe of Indians, noted for their use of poisons; -- also called Aymborés.
Blackness: The quality or state of being black; black color; atrociousness or enormity in wickedness.
Bishoplike: Resembling a bishop; belonging to a bishop.
Bridle iron: A strong flat bar of iron, so bent as to support, as in a stirrup, one end of a floor timber, etc., where no sufficient bearing can be had; -- called also stirrup and hanger.
Bacchius: A metrical foot composed of a short syllable and two long ones; according to some, two long and a short.
Butternut: An American tree (Juglans cinerea) of the Walnut family, and its edible fruit; -- so called from the oil contained in the latter. Sometimes called oil nut and white walnut.
Buffin: A sort of coarse stuff; as, buffin gowns.
Bung: To stop, as the orifice in the bilge of a cask, with a bung; to close; -- with up.
Bawn: An inclosure with mud or stone walls, for keeping cattle; a fortified inclosure.
Bunk: To go to bed in a bunk; -- sometimes with in.
Buddhist: Of or pertaining to Buddha, Buddhism, or the Buddhists.
Backpiece: A piece, or plate which forms the back of anything, or which covers the back.
Brachiopoda: A class of Molluscoidea having a symmetrical bivalve shell, often attached by a fleshy peduncle.
Buddhism: The religion based upon the doctrine originally taught by the Hindu sage Gautama Siddartha, surnamed Buddha, “the awakened or enlightened,” in the sixth century b. c., and adopted as a religion by the greater part of the inhabitants of Central and Eastern Asia and the Indian Islands. Buddha's teaching is believed to have been atheistic; yet it was characterized by elevated humanity and morality. It presents release from existence (a beatific enfranchisement, Nirvâna) as the greatest good. Buddhists believe in transmigration of souls through all phases and forms of life. Their number was estimated in 1881 at 470,000,000.
Birthing: Anything added to raise the sides of a ship.
Bilabiate: Having two lips, as the corols of certain flowers.
Baptistery: In early times, a separate building, usually polygonal, used for baptismal services.  Small churches were often changed into baptisteries when larger churches were built near.
Balefire: A signal fire; an alarm fire.
Bag lady: a homeless woman who carries all her possessions with her in bags.
Beech: A tree of the genus Fagus.
Bodyguard: A guard or group of guards to protect or defend the person; a lifeguard.
bittercress: any of various herbs of the genus Cardamine, having usually pinnate leaves and racemes of white, pink or purple flowers; cosmopolitan except in the Antarctic.
Bedaub: To daub over; to besmear or soil with anything thick and dirty.
Bellows fish: A European fish (Centriscus scolopax), distinguished by a long tubular snout, like the pipe of a bellows; -- called also trumpet fish, and snipe fish.
Bandanna: A species of silk or cotton handkerchief, having a uniformly dyed ground, usually of red or blue, with white or yellow figures of a circular, lozenge, or other simple form; -- it is often used as a neckerchief.  The term is also used for any large and brightly colored handkerchief.
Benthal: Relating to the deepest zone or region of the ocean.
biochemical: a chemical substance produced by a living organism, or such a substance produced synthetically.
Biography: The written history of a person's life.
beggar-lice: any of various Eurasian and North American plants having small prickly nutlets that stick to clothing.
Billiards: A game played with ivory balls o a cloth-covered, rectangular table, bounded by elastic cushions. The player seeks to impel his ball with his cue so that it shall either strike (carom upon) two other balls, or drive another ball into one of the pockets with which the table sometimes is furnished.
Bombardman: One who carried liquor or beer in a can or bombard.
butterflyfish: tropical gurnardlike fish with huge fanlike pectoral fins for underwater gliding; unrelated to searobins.
Beardlessness: The state or quality of being destitute of beard.
Bowsprit: A large boom or spar, which projects over the stem of a ship or other vessel, to carry sail forward.
Ballotade: A leap of a horse, as between two pillars, or upon a straight line, so that when his four feet are in the air, he shows only the shoes of his hind feet, without jerking out.
Buhrstone: A cellular, flinty rock, used for mill stones.
Birdcatching: The art, act, or occupation or catching birds or wild fowls.
Bagpipe: To make to look like a bagpipe.
Beggarhood: The condition of being a beggar; also, the class of beggars.
Bursch: A youth; especially, a student in a german university.
Bowne: To make ready; to prepare; to dress.
Bewailable: Such as may, or ought to, be bewailed; lamentable.
Batrachomyomachy: The battle between the frogs and mice; -- a Greek parody on the Iliad, of uncertain authorship.
bryophyte: any of numerous plants of the division Bryophyta.
Byelorussia: a European country east of Poland, formerly a part of the Soviet Union.  After the breakup of the Soviet Union the name was changed to Belarus.
Bell bearer: A Brazilian leaf hopper (Bocydium tintinnabuliferum), remarkable for the four bell-shaped appendages of its thorax.
Bronze: To give an appearance of bronze to, by a coating of bronze powder, or by other means; to make of the color of bronze; as, to bronze plaster casts; to bronze coins or medals.
Bank discount: A sum equal to the interest at a given rate on the principal (face) of a bill or note from the time of discounting until it becomes due.
Bulbar: Of or pertaining to bulb; especially, in medicine, pertaining to the bulb of the spinal cord, or medulla oblongata; as, bulbar paralysis.
Blennorrhea: An inordinate secretion and discharge of mucus.
Blood vessel: Any vessel or canal in which blood circulates in an animal, as an artery or vein.
borzoi: tall, slender fast-moving dog breed; called also Russian wolfhound.
Burrock: A small weir or dam in a river to direct the stream to gaps where fish traps are placed.
bountied: rewarded or rewardable by a bounty; as, a bountied animal pelt.
bam: An imposition; a cheat; a hoax.
Belle: A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsome lady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.
Bovid: Relating to that tribe of ruminant mammals of which the genus Bos is the type.
Besotted: Made sottish, senseless, or infatuated; characterized by drunken stupidity, or by infatuation; stupefied.
Bayberry: The fruit of the bay tree or Laurus nobilis.
Belly: To swell and become protuberant, like the belly; to bulge.
Butler: An officer in a king's or a nobleman's household, whose principal business it is to take charge of the liquors, plate, etc.; the head servant in a large house.
Bestir: To put into brisk or vigorous action; to move with life and vigor; -- usually with the reciprocal pronoun.
Biology: The science of life; that branch of knowledge which treats of living matter as distinct from matter which is not living; the study of living tissue. It has to do with the origin, structure, development, function, and distribution of animals and plants.
Blanket clause: A clause, as in a blanket mortgage or policy, that includes a group or class of things, rather than a number mentioned individually and having the burden, loss, or the like, apportioned among them.
Billet: A small stick of wood, as for firewood.
Basalt: A rock of igneous origin, consisting of augite and triclinic feldspar, with grains of magnetic or titanic iron, and also bottle-green particles of olivine frequently disseminated.
Bugbane: A perennial white-flowered herb of the order Ranunculaceæ and genus Cimiciguga; bugwort. There are several species.
Bleach: To grow white or lose color; to whiten.
Billed: Furnished with, or having, a bill, as a bird; -- used in composition; as, broad-billed.
Bardiglio: An Italian marble of which the principal varieties occur in the neighborhood of Carrara and in Corsica. It commonly shows a dark gray or bluish ground traversed by veins.
Boudoir: A small room, esp. if pleasant, or elegantly furnished, to which a lady may retire to be alone, or to receive intimate friends; a lady's bedroom; a lady's (or sometimes a gentleman's) private room.
Belate: To retard or make too late.
bevatron: a particle accelerator which is capable of accelerating protons up to 6 gigaeletron volts.
Brush: To move nimbly in haste; to move so lightly as scarcely to be perceived; as, to brush by.
Bricklayer: One whose occupation is to build with bricks.
Base-court: The secondary, inferior, or rear courtyard of a large house; the outer court of a castle.
Benumbment: Act of benumbing, or state of being benumbed; torpor.
burble: to to make a burbling sound; -- used of water, especially brooks.
Beautify: To become beautiful; to advance in beauty.
Ballproof: Incapable of being penetrated by balls from firearms; bulletproof.
Block signal: One of the danger signals or safety signals which guide the movement of trains in a block system. The signal is often so coupled with a switch that act of opening or closing the switch operates the signal also.
Bemire: To drag through, encumber with, or fix in, the mire; to soil by passing through mud or dirt.
Burseraceae: a natural family of resinous or aromatic chiefly tropical shrubs or trees.
Biliation: The production and excretion of bile.
Bairam: Either of two Mohammedan festivals, of which one (the Lesser Bairam) is held at the close of the fast called Ramadan, and the other (the Greater Bairam) seventy days after the fast.
Braveness: The quality of state or being brave.
Beckon: A sign made without words; a beck.
backrest: a support that you can lean against while sitting.
Benthamism: That phase of the doctrine of utilitarianism taught by Jeremy Bentham; the doctrine that the morality of actions is estimated and determined by their utility; also, the theory that the sensibility to pleasure and the recoil from pain are the only motives which influence human desires and actions, and that these are the sufficient explanation of ethical and jural conceptions.
Bordland: Either land held by a bordar, or the land which a lord kept for the maintenance of his board, or table.
Bouleversement: Complete overthrow; disorder; a turning upside down.
bureaucratese: the formal and often obscure style of writing characteristic of some government officials; officialese; -- it is characterized by euphemisms, circumlocutions, vague abstractions, and circumlocutions.
Boation: A crying out; a roaring; a bellowing; reverberation.
Boiling: The act of ebullition or of tumultuous agitation.
Bolden: To make bold; to encourage; to embolden.
Bronchophony: A modification of the voice sounds, by which they are intensified and heightened in pitch; -- observed in auscultation of the chest in certain cases of intro-thoracic disease.
Beadsman: A poor man, supported in a beadhouse, and required to pray for the soul of its founder; an almsman.
Bibliolatry: Book worship, esp. of the Bible; -- applied by Roman Catholic divines to the exaltation of the authority of the Bible over that of the pope or the church, and by Protestants to an excessive regard to the letter of the Scriptures.
Broncho: A native or a Mexican horse of small size.
Basilicon: An ointment composed of wax, pitch, resin, and olive oil, lard, or other fatty substance.
Blirt: A gust of wind and rain.
Balladry: Ballad poems; the subject or style of ballads.
Bhunder: An Indian monkey (Macacus Rhesus), protected by the Hindus as sacred. See Rhesus.
Binervate: Two-nerved; -- applied to leaves which have two longitudinal ribs or nerves.
Brush wheel: A wheel without teeth, used to turn a similar one by the friction of bristles or something brushlike or soft attached to the circumference.
Bondwoman: A woman who is a slave, or in bondage.
Beerhouse: A house where malt liquors are sold; an alehouse.
Bibacity: The practice or habit of drinking too much; tippling.
bandwidth: The maximum rate of information transfer (measured in bits/second) that can be carried by a communication channel.
Branch: To divide as into branches; to make subordinate division in.
Boilery: A place and apparatus for boiling, as for evaporating brine in salt making.
Batsman: The one who wields the bat in cricket, baseball, etc.; in baseball, the batsman is usually called the batter.
Boss: A master workman or superintendent; a director or manager; a political dictator.
Bosh: Empty talk; contemptible nonsense; trash; humbug.
break-in: an act of trespassing into a closed structure such as a house or place of busineess for an unlawful purpose, usually as part of a burglary.
Building: The act of constructing, erecting, or establishing.
Bowman: The man who rows the foremost oar in a boat; the bow oar.
Bifurcation: A forking, or division into two branches.
Biostatics: The physical phenomena of organized bodies, in opposition to their organic or vital phenomena.
boysenberry: a cultivated hybrid bramble of California having large dark wine-red fruit with a raspberrylike flavor.
Brachycatalectic: A verse wanting two syllables at its termination.
Bait: To flap the wings; to flutter as if to fly; or to hover, as a hawk when she stoops to her prey.
Beild: A place of shelter; protection; refuge.
Barker: One who strips trees of their bark.
Book: To enter, write, or register in a book or list.
Bissell truck: A truck for railroad rolling stock, consisting of two ordinary axle boxes sliding in guides attached to a triangular frame; -- called also pony truck.
Bendlet: A narrow bend, esp. one half the width of the bend.
Bail: A line of palisades serving as an exterior defense.
Beef: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, beef.
Broad: The broad part of anything; as, the broad of an oar.
Been: The past participle of Be. In old authors it is also the pr. tense plural of Be. See 1st Bee.
Beer: A fermented liquor made from any malted grain, but commonly from barley malt, with hops or some other substance to impart a bitter flavor.
Beet: A biennial plant of the genus Beta, which produces an edible root the first year and seed the second year.
Breastwheel: A water wheel, on which the stream of water strikes neither so high as in the overshot wheel, nor so low as in the undershot, but generally at about half the height of the wheel, being kept in contact with it by the breasting. The water acts on the float boards partly by impulse, partly by its weight.
Broadsword: A sword with a broad blade and a cutting edge; a claymore.
Blottesque: Characterized by blots or heavy touches; coarsely depicted; wanting in delineation.
Blessing: The act of one who blesses.
Bell jar: A glass vessel, varying in size, open at the bottom and closed at the top like a bell, and having a knob or handle at the top for lifting it. It is used for a great variety of purposes; as, with the air pump, and for holding gases, also for keeping the dust from articles exposed to view.
Basso: The bass or lowest part; as, to sing basso.
Boyish: Resembling a boy in a manners or opinions; belonging to a boy; childish; trifling; puerile.
burp: a reflex that expels wind noisily from the stomach through the mouth.
Breastheight: The interior slope of a fortification, against which the garrison lean in firing.
beer belly: a protruding potbelly caused by excessive drinking of beer.
Bilboquet: The toy called cup and ball.
Bridesmaid: A female friend who attends on a bride at her wedding.
Benefiter: One who confers a benefit; -- also, one who receives a benefit.
Belling: A bellowing, as of a deer in rutting time.
Byplay: Action carried on aside, and commonly in dumb show, while the main action proceeds.
Baker-legged: Having legs that bend inward at the knees.
Brainpan: The bones which inclose the brain; the skull; the cranium.
Bignoniaceous: Of pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of which the trumpet flower (also called trumpet creeper and trumpet vine) is an example.
Biventral: Having two bellies or protuberances; as, a biventral, or digastric, muscle, or the biventral lobe of the cerebellum.
bullethead: a head shaped like a bullet.
Backer: One who, or that which, backs; especially one who backs a person or thing in a contest.
Balsaminaceae: a natural family comprising the balsams, distinguished from the family Geraniaceae by the irregular flowers.
blewit: an edible agaric (Tricholoma personatum) that is pale lilac when young.
Bullition: The action of boiling; boiling. [Obs.] See Ebullition.
Bungee jump: an act of derring-do in which a person jumps from a high platform, such as a bridge, attached (usually by the legs) to a bungee cord, which is set to a length that will halt the drop before the person reaches the surface of the earth or the water.
Bramah press: A hydrostatic press of immense power, invented by Joseph Bramah of London. See under Hydrostatic.
bounds: the line or plane indicating the limit or extent of something; as, the fotball was caught out of bounds.
