Blindmans buff: A game in which one person is blindfolded, and tries to catch some one of the other players, and tell who it is.
Bankside: The slope of a bank, especially of the bank of a stream.
Bullish: Partaking of the nature of a bull, or a blunder.
bloodstained: stained with blood; as, a bloodstained shirt; a bloodstained carpet; a bloodstained sidewalk.
Bullist: A writer or drawer up of papal bulls.
Burghmote: A court or meeting of a burgh or borough; a borough court held three times yearly.
Biforine: An oval sac or cell, found in the leaves of certain plants of the order Araceæ. It has an opening at each end through which raphides, generated inside, are discharged.
Bodily: Corporeally; in bodily form; united with a body or matter; in the body.
Binbashi: A major in the Turkish army.
Bay State: Massachusetts, which had been called the Colony of Massachusetts Bay; -- a nickname.
Bullace: A small European plum (Prunus communis, var. insitita). See Plum.
Bundesrath: Lit., a federal council, esp. of the German Empire.  In the German Empire the legislative functions are vested in the Bundesrath and the Reichstag. The federal council of Switzerland is also so called.
Baneberry: A genus (Actæa) of plants, of the order Ranunculaceæ, native in the north temperate zone.  The red or white berries are poisonous.
baby-blue-eyes: delicate California annual having blue flowers marked with dark spots.
babysitting: the work of a baby sitter; caring for children when their parents are not home.
Berkeleian: Of or relating to Bishop Berkeley or his system of idealism; as, Berkeleian philosophy.
base pair: a unit of double-stranded DNA or RNA consisting of two complementary bases on opposing strands of the double-stranded polynucleotide, bound together by hydrogen bonds and other non-covalent chemical forces.  The bases comprising the base pairs are adenine, thymine, cytidine, and guanine.  In normal DNA, the base adenine on one strand of DNA pairs with thymine on the opposite strand, and cytosine on one strand pairs with guanine on the opposite strand.  The term base pair usually includes the sugar (ribose or deoxyribose) and the phosphate bound to each base to form a nucleotide unit.  One base pair is sometimes used as a unit of length or size for DNA, and in this usage is abbreviated bp; as, a 100-bp fragment of DNA.  A length of 1000 base pairs is a kilobase pair or kbp.
Bryopsida: the class of plants comprising the true mosses, having leafy rather than thalloid gametophytes; it comprises the orders Andreaeales; Bryales; Dicranales; Eubryales; and Sphagnales.
Buccinator: A muscle of the cheek; -- so called from its use in blowing wind instruments.
bomber: a military aircraft that drops bombs during flight.
bordered: having a border especially of a specified kind; sometimes used as a combining term; as, black-bordered handkerchief.  Antonym of unbordered.
Barry: Divided into bars; -- said of the field.
Bauxite: A ferruginous hydrate of alumina.  It is the most commonly used ore for the preparation of aluminum and alumina.  It is also used for the lining of furnaces which are exposed to intense heat.
Batrachoid: Froglike. Specifically: Of or pertaining to the Batrachidæ, a family of marine fishes, including the toadfish. Some have poisonous dorsal spines.
Burgess-ship: The state of privilege of a burgess.
Bursal: Of or pertaining to a bursa or to bursæ.
Bursar: A treasurer, or cash keeper; a purser; as, the bursar of a college, or of a monastery.
Basigynium: The pedicel on which the ovary of certain flowers, as the passion flower, is seated; a carpophore or thecaphore.
By-street: A separate, private, or obscure street; an out of the way or cross street.
Bicolligate: Having the anterior toes connected by a basal web.
Bed screw: A form of jack screw for lifting large bodies, and assisting in launching.
Bechuanas: A division of the Bantus, dwelling between the Orange and Zambezi rivers, supposed to be the most ancient Bantu population of South Africa. They are divided into totemic clans; they are intelligent and progressive.
Branchiostegal: Pertaining to the membrane covering the gills of fishes.
Batten: The movable bar of a loom, which strikes home or closes the threads of a woof.
Brewing: The act or process of preparing liquors which are brewed, as beer and ale.
Boutade: An outbreak; a caprice; a whim.
Batter: The one who wields the bat in baseball; the one whose turn it is at bat; formerly called the batsman.
Benzoyl: A compound radical, C6H5.CO-; the base of benzoic acid, of the oil of bitter almonds, and of an extensive series of compounds.
Bruiser: One who, or that which, bruises.
Bebeerine: An alkaloid got from the bark of the bebeeru, or green heart of Guiana (Nectandra Rodiœi). It is a tonic, antiperiodic, and febrifuge, and is used in medicine as a substitute for quinine.
bandwagon: A popular trend that attracts growing support.
Buckra: White; white man's; strong; good; as, buckra yam, a white yam.
Baffler: One who, or that which, baffles.
Bide: To encounter; to remain firm under (a hardship); to endure; to suffer; to undergo.
blue-green alga: any of a group of photosynthetic microorganisms possessing characteristics of both bacteria and plants.  When classed as bacteria, they are assigned to the Cyanobacteria; when classed as plants, they are assigned to the Cyanophyta.  They are now known to be prokaryotic, and are usually called cyanobacteria in technical contexts.  See cyanobacterium.
Bepinch: To pinch, or mark with pinches.
Bestead: To put in a certain situation or condition; to circumstance; to place.
bop: an early form of modern jazz (originating around 1940).
Besetting: Habitually attacking, harassing, or pressing upon or about; as, a besetting sin.
bunglesome: awkward to move or use especially because of shape; as, a load of bunglesome paraphernalia.
boo: to show displeasure (after a performance or speech) by making a prolonged sound of “boo”.
batboy: A boy who holds the bats and presents the bat to a batter when the batter is going to the batter's box to bat.  The batboy sometimes also keeps other team equipment.
Baldwin: A kind of reddish, moderately acid, winter apple.
bruised: suffering from emotional injury; as, a bruised ego.
Boragineous: Relating to the Borage tribe; boraginaceous.
Be-: A prefix, originally the same word as by;
Briefness: The quality of being brief; brevity; conciseness in discourse or writing.
Bloomy: Full of bloom; flowery; flourishing with the vigor of youth; as, a bloomy spray.
Banality: Something commonplace, hackneyed, or trivial; the commonplace, in speech.
Bolas: A kind of missile weapon consisting of one, two, or more balls of stone, iron, or other material, attached to the ends of a leather cord; -- used by the Gauchos of South America, and others, for hurling at and entangling an animal.
Bolar: Of or pertaining to bole or clay; partaking of the nature and qualities of bole; clayey.
Beryllium: A metallic element found in the beryl. See Glucinum.
bowdlerization: the deletion of all passages considered to be indecent.
Ben: An old form of the pl. indic. pr. of Be.
Bel: a unit of sound intensity equal to ten decibels.
Brat: A thin bed of coal mixed with pyrites or carbonate of lime.
Bray: A bank; the slope of a hill; a hill. See Brae, which is now the usual spelling.
Beg: To ask alms or charity, especially to ask habitually by the wayside or from house to house; to live by asking alms.
Bed: To go to bed; to cohabit.
Bee: An insect of the order Hymenoptera, and family Apidæ (the honeybees), or family Andrenidæ (the solitary bees.) See Honeybee.
Bonify: To convert into, or make, good.
Brae: A hillside; a slope; a bank; a hill.
Brad: A thin nail, usually small, with a slight projection at the top on one side instead of a head; also, a small wire nail, with a flat circular head; sometimes, a small, tapering, square-bodied finishing nail, with a countersunk head.
Bran: The broken coat of the seed of wheat, rye, or other cereal grain, separated from the flour or meal by sifting or bolting; the coarse, chaffy part of ground grain.
Bate: To steep in bate, as hides, in the manufacture of leather.
Bushfighting: Fighting in the bush, or from behind bushes, trees, or thickets.
Bookstall: A stall or stand where books are sold.
Bath: A city in the west of England, resorted to for its hot springs, which has given its name to various objects.
birthrate: the ratio of live births in an area to the population of that area; usually expressed as birthes per 1000 population per year.
Blissom: Lascivious; also, in heat; -- said of ewes.
Balata: A West Indian sapotaceous tree (Bumelia retusa).
Barbican: A tower or advanced work defending the entrance to a castle or city, as at a gate or bridge. It was often large and strong, having a ditch and drawbridge of its own.
Batz: A small copper coin, with a mixture of silver, formerly current in some parts of Germany and Switzerland. It was worth about four cents.
Bogle: A goblin; a specter; a frightful phantom; a bogy; a bugbear.
Brinjaree: A rough-haired East Indian variety of the greyhound.
Brioschi: a type of antacid sold over-the-counter.
battered: In deplorable condition; as, the battered old Ford station wagon.
Brewery: A brewhouse; the building and apparatus where brewing is carried on.
Bunny: A pet name for a rabbit or a squirrel.
Breastbeam: The front transverse beam of a locomotive.
Battalia: Order of battle; disposition or arrangement of troops (brigades, regiments, battalions, etc.), or of a naval force, for action.
Boa constrictor: A large and powerful serpent of tropical America, sometimes twenty or thirty feet long. See Illustration in Appendix.
Bond service: The condition of a bond servant; service without wages; slavery.
Bother: One who, or that which, bothers; state of perplexity or annoyance; embarrassment; worry; disturbance; petty trouble; as, to be in a bother.
Bedroom: A room or apartment intended or used for a bed; a lodging room.
blowlamp: A burner that produces a hot flame.
Bee-eater: A bird of the genus Merops, that feeds especially on bees. The European species (Merops apiaster) is remarkable for its brilliant colors.
Bracteal: Having the nature or appearance of a bract.
bottomland: low-lying alluvial land near a river.
Badminton: A game, similar to lawn tennis, played with shuttlecocks.
Banquetter: One who banquets; one who feasts or makes feasts.
Blender: One who, or that which, blends; an instrument, as a brush, used in blending.
Balaenoptera: the type genus of the Balaenopteridae.
Beneficially: In a beneficial or advantageous manner; profitably; helpfully.
Botryoid: Having the form of a bunch of grapes; like a cluster of grapes, as a mineral presenting an aggregation of small spherical or spheroidal prominences; as, botryoidal hematite.
Blastomere: One of the segments first formed by the division of the ovum.
Borate: A salt formed by the combination of boric acid with a base or positive radical.
Benign: Of a kind or gentle disposition; gracious; generous; favorable; benignant.
Biliary: Relating or belonging to bile; conveying bile; as, biliary acids; biliary ducts.
Beneficently: In a beneficent manner; with beneficence.
Belfry: A movable tower erected by besiegers for purposes of attack and defense.
Biprism: A prism whose refracting angle is very nearly 180 degrees.
Bow oar: The oar used by the bowman.
Basswood: The bass (Tilia) or its wood; especially, Tilia Americana. See Bass, the lime tree.
Beaker: A large drinking cup, with a wide mouth, supported on a foot or standard.
Botanic: Of or pertaining to botany; relating to the study of plants; as, a botanical system, arrangement, textbook, expedition.
Bridestake: A stake or post set in the ground, for guests at a wedding to dance round.
Bedazzle: To dazzle or make dim by a strong light.
Beaked: Having a beak or a beaklike point; beak-shaped.
Burmannia: the type genus of the Burmanniaceae; slender herbs of warm regions with leaves resembling scales and flowers with a 3-angled or 3-winged perianth.
buntal: a fine white Philippine fiber from the stalks of unopened leaves of talipot palms; used in making hats.
Ballooner: One who goes up in a balloon; an aëronaut.
Burgoo: A kind of oatmeal pudding, or thick gruel, used by seamen.
Barilla: A name given to several species of Salsola from which soda is made, by burning the barilla in heaps and lixiviating the ashes.
Banzai: Lit., May you live ten thousand years; -- used in salutation of the emperor and as a battle cry.
Bernese: Pertaining to the city or canton of Bern, in Switzerland, or to its inhabitants.
Bestrew: To strew or scatter over; to besprinkle.
Baize: A coarse woolen stuff with a long nap; -- usually dyed in plain colors.
Botargo: A sort of cake or sausage, made of the salted roes of the mullet, much used on the coast of the Mediterranean as an incentive to drink.
blitzkrieg: to fight a quick and surprising war.
Bibliopolism: The trade or business of selling books.
blastoporal: of or pertaining to a blastopore.
Brawny: Having large, strong muscles; muscular; fleshy; strong.
Blissful: Full of, characterized by, or causing, joy and felicity; happy in the highest degree.
Bake: The process, or result, of baking.
Belly-god: One whose great pleasure it is to gratify his appetite; a glutton; an epicure.
Black: That which is destitute of light or whiteness; the darkest color, or rather a destitution of all color; as, a cloth has a good black.
Baffy: A short wooden club having a deeply concave face, seldom used.
bare-bones: having only the absolute minimum necessary; having only the essential components.
Boddhisatva: a Buddhist, worthy of nirvana, who postpones it to help others.
Bundle: To prepare for departure; to set off in a hurry or without ceremony.
Burglarious: Pertaining to burglary; constituting the crime of burglary.
Backsheesh: In Egypt and the Turkish empire, a relatively small amount of money given for services rendered (as by a waiter); a gratuity; a “tip”.
Bell crank: A lever whose two arms form a right angle, or nearly a right angle, having its fulcrum at the apex of the angle. It is used in bell pulls and in changing the direction of bell wires at angles of rooms, etc., and also in machinery.
Blackburnian warbler: A beautiful warbler of the United States (Dendroica Blackburniæ). The male is strongly marked with orange, yellow, and black on the head and neck, and has an orange-yellow breast.
Baccalaureate: Pertaining to a bachelor of arts.
Backing: The act of moving backward, or of putting or moving anything backward.
Bookmark: Something placed in a book to guide in finding a particular page or passage; also, a label in a book to designate the owner; a bookplate.
Bagwig: A wig, in use in the 18th century, with the hair at the back of the head in a bag.
Bicalcarate: Having two spurs, as the wing or leg of a bird.
Ballade: A form of French versification, sometimes imitated in English, in which three or four rhymes recur through three stanzas of eight or ten lines each, the stanzas concluding with a refrain, and the whole poem with an envoy.
Box-iron: A hollow smoothing iron containing a heater within.
Beastliness: The state or quality of being beastly.
Bromol: A crystalline substance (chemically, tribromophenol, C6H2Br3OH), used as an antiseptic and disinfectant.
Brochure: A printed and stitched book containing only a few leaves; a pamphlet; a single sheet folded to make four pages.
Bolide: A kind of meteor; a bolis.
beth: the 2nd letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
Bon Sil\u00e8ne: A very fragrant tea rose with petals of various shades of pink.
Bindery: A place where books, or other articles, are bound; a bookbinder's establishment.
bustard: A bird of the genus Otis.
Belabor: To ply diligently; to work carefully upon.
Bridecake: Rich or highly ornamented cake, to be distributed to the guests at a wedding, or sent to friends after the wedding.
Bassetto: A tenor or small bass viol.
Bawdyhouse: A house of prostitution; a house of ill fame; a brothel.
beaner: a baseball deliberately thrown at the batter's head.
Blue bonnet: A broad, flat Scottish cap of blue woolen, or one wearing such cap; a Scotchman.
Broach: To spit; to pierce as with a spit.
Bubo: An inflammation, with enlargement, of a lymphatic gland, esp. in the groin, as in syphilis.
Broadleaf: A tree (Terminalia latifolia) of Jamaica, the wood of which is used for boards, scantling, shingles, etc; -- sometimes called the almond tree, from the shape of its fruit.
Barothermograph: An instrument for recording both pressure and temperature, as of the atmosphere.
Boding: A prognostic; an omen; a foreboding.
Bald eagle: The white-headed eagle (Haliæetus leucocephalus) of America. The young, until several years old, lack the white feathers on the head.
Bucolic: A pastoral poem, representing rural affairs, and the life, manners, and occupation of shepherds; as, the Bucolics of Theocritus and Virgil.
Blindage: A cover or protection for an advanced trench or approach, formed of fascines and earth supported by a framework.
Bib: To drink; to sip; to tipple.
Baptisia: A genus of North American plants with showy pealike flowers and an inflated pod.
Blastopore: The pore or opening leading into the cavity of invagination, or archenteron.
Bloodshedder: One who sheds blood; a manslayer; a murderer.
Beechnut: The nut of the beech tree.
Bellied: Having (such) a belly; puffed out; -- used in composition; as, pot-bellied; shad-bellied.
blurred: out of focus; not sharply defined.
barring: the act of excluding someone by a negative vote or veto.
Beating: The act of striking or giving blows; punishment or chastisement by blows.
Besiege: To beset or surround with armed forces, for the purpose of compelling to surrender; to lay siege to; to beleaguer; to beset.
basidiomycete: any of various fungi of the subdivision Basidiomycota.
Bromal: An oily, colorless fluid, CBr3.COH, related to bromoform, as chloral is to chloroform, and obtained by the action of bromine on alcohol.
Boomer: One who, or that which, booms.
Berbe: An African genet (Genetta pardina). See Genet.
Bucephalus: The celebrated war horse of Alexander the Great.
Bemol: The sign ♭; the same as B flat.
Basidiomycota: A large subdivision of the kingdom Fungi coextensive with the phylum Basidiomycetes, characterized by having the spores borne on a basidium. It embraces those fungi best known to the public, such as mushrooms, toadstools, etc.  Among the classes of the Basidiomycota are: Gasteromycetes (puffballs); Tiliomycetes (comprising the orders Ustilaginales (smuts) and Uredinales (rusts)); and Hymenomycetes (mushrooms; toadstools; agarics; bracket fungi).
bioactive: acting upon or influencing bodily functions; -- of chemical substances.
Bigoted: Obstinately and blindly attached to some creed, opinion practice, or ritual; unreasonably devoted to a system or party, and illiberal toward the opinions of others.
Belzebuth: A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Brazil.
Borax: A white or gray crystalline salt, with a slight alkaline taste, used as a flux, in soldering metals, making enamels, fixing colors on porcelain, and as a soap. It occurs native in certain mineral springs, and is made from the boric acid of hot springs in Tuscany. It was originally obtained from a lake in Thibet, and was sent to Europe under the name of tincal. Borax is a pyroborate or tetraborate of sodium, Na2B4O7.10H2O.
Bothrenchyma: Dotted or pitted ducts or vessels forming the pores seen in many kinds of wood.
Berceuse: A vocal or instrumental composition of a soft tranquil character, having a lulling effect; a cradle song.
Butterman: A man who makes or sells butter.
Brandied: Mingled with brandy; made stronger by the addition of brandy; flavored or treated with brandy; as, brandied peaches.
Bitterroot: A plant (Lewisia rediviva) allied to the purslane, but with fleshy, farinaceous roots, growing in the mountains of Idaho, Montana, etc. It gives the name to the Bitter Root mountains and river. The Indians call both the plant and the river Spæt'lum.
Blazonment: The act of blazoning; blazoning; emblazonment.
Bathe: The immersion of the body in water; as, to take one's usual bathe.
Blindworm: A small, burrowing, snakelike, limbless lizard (Anguis fragilis), with minute eyes, popularly believed to be blind; the slowworm; -- formerly a name for the adder.
Biffin: A sort of apple peculiar to Norfolk, Eng.
Basketball: A ball game, usually played indoors in an area called the basketball court, in which two opposing teams of five players each contest with each other to toss a large inflated ball (the basketball) into opposite goals (baskets) resembling baskets, each typically a cylindrical mesh suspended from a circular rim which is held ten feet above the court.  A goal scored by passing the basketball through the basket may count from one to three points, depending on the situation in which it was thrown.
Bescreen: To cover with a screen, or as with a screen; to shelter; to conceal.
bacitracin: a polypeptide antibacterial antibiotic of known chemical structure effective against several types of Gram-positive organisms, and usually used topically for superficial local infection.
Bad lands: Barren regions, especially in the western United States, where horizontal strata (Tertiary deposits) have been often eroded into fantastic forms, and much intersected by cañons, and where lack of wood, water, and forage increases the difficulty of traversing the country, whence the name, first given by the Canadian French, Mauvaises Terres (bad lands).
Besieger: One who besieges; -- opposed to the besieged.
Burgh: A borough or incorporated town, especially, one in Scotland. See Borough.
Baculometry: Measurement of distance or altitude by a staff or staffs.
Biophotophone: An instrument combining a cinematograph and a phonograph so that the moving figures on the screen are accompanied by the appropriate sounds; -- an archaic term replaced by movie projector.
Betrim: To set in order; to adorn; to deck, to embellish; to trim.
Bugaboo: Something frightful, as a specter; anything imaginary that causes needless fright; something used to excite needless fear; also, something really dangerous, or an imaginary monster, used to frighten children, etc.
Box kite: A kite, invented by Lawrence Hargrave, of Sydney, Australia, which consist of two light rectangular boxes, or cells open on two sides, and fastened together horizontally. Called also Hargrave kite, or cellular kite.
Bats-wing: Shaped like a bat's wing; as, a bat's-wing burner.
Blusterous: Inclined to bluster; given to blustering; blustering.
Balaena: type genus of the Balaenidae: Greenland whales.
Bafflement: The process or act of baffling, or of being baffled; frustration; check.
behaviorist: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of behaviorists or behaviorism.
basileus: a ruler of the eastern Roman Empire.
behaviorism: an approach to psychology that emphasizes observable measurable behavior.
Boxing: The act of fighting with the fist; a combat with the fist; sparring; pugilism.
Bo tree: The peepul tree; esp., the very ancient tree standing at Anurajahpoora in Ceylon, grown from a slip of the tree under which Gautama is said to have received the heavenly light and so to have become Buddha.
Banquet: To regale one's self with good eating and drinking; to feast.
Boat shell: A marine gastropod of the genus Crepidula. The species are numerous. It is so named from its form and interior deck.
Blemish: Any mark of deformity or injury, whether physical or moral; anything that diminishes beauty, or renders imperfect that which is otherwise well formed; that which impairs reputation.
Bleacher: One who whitens, or whose occupation is to whiten, by bleaching.
Backhanded: With the hand turned backward; as, a backhanded blow.
Bearing ring: In a balloon, the braced wooden ring attached to the suspension ropes at the bottom, functionally analogous to the keel of a ship.
Blind reader: A post-office clerk whose duty is to decipher obscure addresses.
Bubby: Bub; -- a term of familiar or affectionate address to a small boy.
Berserk: frenzied; crazed; usually in predicate position.
Breakdown: The act or result of breaking down, as of a carriage; downfall.
Benzoinated: Containing or impregnated with benzoin; as, benzoinated lard.
Betony: A plant of the genus Betonica (Linn.).
Bacchant: Bacchanalian; fond of drunken revelry; wine-loving; reveling; carousing.
Birds-beak: A molding whose section is thought to resemble a beak.
Barbarism: An uncivilized state or condition; rudeness of manners; ignorance of arts, learning, and literature; barbarousness.
Biometry: Measurement of life; calculation of the probable duration of human life.
Begone: Surrounded; furnished; beset; environed (as in woe-begone).
Belting: The material of which belts for machinery are made; also, belts, taken collectively.
Behavior: Manner of behaving, whether good or bad; mode of conducting one's self; conduct; deportment; carriage; -- used also of inanimate objects; as, the behavior of a ship in a storm; the behavior of the magnetic needle.
bullshot: vodka and beef bouillon or consomme.
Biconjugate: Twice paired, as when a petiole forks twice.
Bluffness: The quality or state of being bluff.
Breadroot: The root of a leguminous plant (Psoralea esculenta), found near the Rocky Mountains. It is usually oval in form, and abounds in farinaceous matter, affording sweet and palatable food.
bioremediation: the branch of biotechnology that uses biological processes to overcome environmental problems.
Bicostate: Having two principal ribs running longitudinally, as a leaf.
Biestings: The first milk given by a cow after calving.
Barley: A valuable grain, of the family of grasses, genus Hordeum, used for food, and for making malt, from which are prepared beer, ale, and whisky.
Botcher: One who mends or patches, esp. a tailor or cobbler.
Barometz: The woolly-skinned rhizoma or rootstock of a fern (Dicksonia barometz), which, when specially prepared and inverted, somewhat resembles a lamb; -- called also Scythian lamb.
Bartlett: A Bartlett pear, a favorite kind of pear, which originated in England about 1770, and was called Williams' Bonchrétien.  It was brought to America, and distributed by Mr. Enoch Bartlett, of Dorchester, Massachusetts.
Bandoleer: A broad leather belt formerly worn by soldiers over the right shoulder and across the breast under the left arm.  Originally it was used for supporting the musket and twelve cases for charges, but later only as a cartridge belt.
blastocoel: The cavity inside a blastula; -- also called segmentation cavity.
Boncilate: A substance composed of ground bone, mineral matters, etc., hardened by pressure, and used for making billiard balls, boxes, etc.
bettering: changing for the better; -- antonym of worsening.
birchbark: a canoe made with the bark of a birch tree.
Bedizen: To dress or adorn tawdrily or with false taste.
Boomdas: A small African hyracoid mammal (Dendrohyrax arboreus) resembling the daman.
Bluey: A bushman's blanket; -- named from its color.
Barbecue: To dry or cure by exposure on a frame or gridiron.
Bureaucratic: Of, relating to, or resembling, a bureaucracy.
Blow: A blowing, esp., a violent blowing of the wind; a gale; as, a heavy blow came on, and the ship put back to port.
Blot: An exposure of a single man to be taken up.
Bungarum: A venomous snake of India, of the genus Bungarus, allied to the cobras, but without a hood.
Brage: the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
Bracing: The act of strengthening, supporting, or propping, with a brace or braces; the state of being braced.
Blob: Something blunt and round; a small drop or lump of something viscid or thick; a drop; a bubble; a blister.
Basioccipital: Of or pertaining to the bone in the base of the cranium, frequently forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but usually distinct in the young.
Bragi: the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
Benet: To catch in a net; to insnare.
beefburger: a fried cake of minced beef served on a bun.
Busby: A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is of fur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment, hanging from the top over the right shoulder.
basidiolichen: a lichen in which the fungus component is a basidiomycete.
Baffle: A defeat by artifice, shifts, and turns; discomfiture.
Bablah: The rind of the fruit of several East Indian species of acacia; neb-neb. It contains gallic acid and tannin, and is used for dyeing drab.
Beneficial: Conferring benefits; useful; profitable; helpful; advantageous; serviceable; contributing to a valuable end; -- followed by to.
Bargemastter: The proprietor or manager of a barge, or one of the crew of a barge.
Brad awl: A straight awl with chisel edge, used to make holes for brads, etc.
Breastplow: A kind of plow, driven by the breast of the workman; -- used to cut or pare turf.
Branch pilot: A pilot who has a branch or commission, as from Trinity House, England, for special navigation.
bosomy: Characterized by recesses or sheltered hollows.
Billfish: A name applied to several distinct fishes
Beamy: Emitting beams of light; radiant; shining.
Bromic: Of, pertaining to, or containing, bromine; -- said of those compounds of bromine in which this element has a valence of five, or the next to its highest; as, bromic acid.
bucketful: a bucket filled with a substance, or the quantity which would fill a bucket.
Basseting: The upward direction of a vein in a mine; the emergence of a stratum at the surface.
Bunchiness: The quality or condition of being bunchy; knobbiness.
bottleneck: to become narrower as one approaches a point; -- said of roads; as, right by the bridge, the road bottlenecks.
bimillenial: of or pertaining to the bimillennium.
Bibulous: Readily imbibing fluids or moisture; spongy; as, bibulous blotting paper.
Blond: Of a fair color; light-colored; as, blond hair; a blond complexion.
Brooklime: A plant (Veronica Beccabunga), with flowers, usually blue, in axillary racemes. The American species is Veronica Americana.
Bulldoze: To intimidate; to restrain or coerce by intimidation or violence; -- used originally of the intimidation of negro voters, in Louisiana.
Boorish: Like a boor; clownish; uncultured; unmannerly.
Brewsterite: A rare zeolitic mineral occurring in white monoclinic crystals with pearly luster. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia, baryta, and strontia.
Browse: To feed on the tender branches or shoots of shrubs or trees, as do cattle, sheep, and deer.
Brantail: The European redstart; -- so called from the red color of its tail.
berkelium: a chemical element of the transuranic series.  Chemical symbol Bk; atomic number 97; atomic weight 247.  It is a radioactive element, with no stable isotopes; the longest-lived isotope is of mass number 247.07, decaying by alpha-emission with a half-life of 1,400 years.  The isotope with atomic weight 249 has a half-life of 314 days, and was isolated in weighable quantities.
Bleat: A plaintive cry of, or like that of, a sheep.
Bass horn: A modification of the bassoon, much deeper in tone.
Blear: To make somewhat sore or watery, as the eyes; to dim, or blur, as the sight. Figuratively: To obscure (mental or moral perception); to blind; to hoodwink.
Binturong: A small Asiatic civet of the genus Arctilis.
Brant-fox: A kind of fox found in Sweden (Vulpes alopex), smaller than the common fox (Vulpes vulgaris), but probably a variety of it.
Bleak: A small European river fish (Leuciscus alburnus), of the family Cyprinidæ; the blay.
blazing-star: any of various North American plants of the genus Liatris having racemes or panicles of small discoid flower heads.
Benumb: To make torpid; to deprive of sensation or sensibility; to stupefy; as, a hand or foot benumbed by cold.
Botfly: A dipterous insect of the family (Estridæ, of many different species, some of which are particularly troublesome to domestic animals, as the horse, ox, and sheep, on which they deposit their eggs. A common species is one of the botflies of the horse (Gastrophilus equi), the larvæ of which (bots) are taken into the stomach of the animal, where they live several months and pass through their larval states. In tropical America one species sometimes lives under the human skin, and another in the stomach. See Gadfly.
Boneblack: See Bone black, under Bone, n.
Bizarre: Odd in manner or appearance; fantastic; whimsical; extravagant; grotesque.
Bordage: The base or servile tenure by which a bordar held his cottage.
Bicaudal: Having, or terminating in, two tails.
Britisher: An Englishman; a subject or inhabitant of Great Britain, esp. one in the British military or naval service.
Brushwood: Brush; a thicket or coppice of small trees and shrubs.
Bakingly: In a hot or baking manner.
butterfingers: someone who drops things (especially one who cannot catch a ball); a person who is butter-fingered.
Berhyme: To mention in rhyme or verse; to rhyme about.
Biplicity: The state of being twice folded; reduplication.
Bassariscus: a genus comprising the cacomistles.  See bassarisk.
Brattice: A wall of separation in a shaft or gallery used for ventilation.
Brancard: A litter on which a person may be carried.
bellylaugh: to laugh a deep, hearty laugh.
blue-blindness: inability to distinguish blue and yellow.
Byronic: Pertaining to, or in the style of, Lord Byron.
Bulky: Of great bulk or dimensions; of great size; large; thick; massive; as, bulky volumes.
Boatful: The quantity or amount that fills a boat.
Bullirag: To intimidate by bullying; to rally contemptuously; to badger.
bilabial: a consonant that is articulated using both lips, as p or b or w.
birdbrain: a person with confused ideas; incapable of serious thought.
burbling: uttered with unrestrained enthusiasm; as, a novel told in burbly panting tones.
Brazenness: The quality or state of being brazen.
Budlet: A little bud springing from a parent bud.
Blennioid: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the blennies.
Boomslange: A large South African tree snake (Bucephalus Capensis). Although considered venomous by natives, it has no poison fangs.
bouffant: being puffed out; -- used mostly of hair style, and sometimes clothing; as, a bouffant hairdo; a bouffant skirt.
Big Apple: New York City; -- a nickname, usually written The Big Apple.
Belock: To lock, or fasten as with a lock.
Binny: A large species of barbel (Barbus bynni), found in the Nile, and much esteemed for food.
Beylic: The territory ruled by a bey.
Burin: The cutting tool of an engraver on metal, used in line engraving. It is made of tempered steel, one end being ground off obliquely so as to produce a sharp point, and the other end inserted in a handle; a graver; also, the similarly shaped tool used by workers in marble.
Bisque: A white soup made of crayfish.
Bougainvill\u00e6a: A genus of plants of the order Nyctoginaceæ, from tropical South America, having the flowers surrounded by large bracts.
Boatmanship: The art of managing a boat.
Bidding: Command; order; a proclamation or notifying.
Breve: A note or character of time, equivalent to two semibreves or four minims. When dotted, it is equal to three semibreves. It was formerly of a square figure (as thus: &unr_; ), but is now made oval, with a line perpendicular to the staff on each of its sides; -- formerly much used for choir service.
Bar: To fasten with a bar; as, to bar a door or gate.
Bay: To dam, as water; -- with up or back.
Bag: To swell or hang down like a full bag; as, the skin bags from containing morbid matter.
Bad: Wanting good qualities, whether physical or moral; injurious, hurtful, inconvenient, offensive, painful, unfavorable, or defective, either physically or morally; evil; vicious; wicked; -- the opposite of good; as, a bad man; bad conduct; bad habits; bad soil; bad air; bad health; a bad crop; bad news.
Bab: Lit., gate; -- a title given to the founder of Babism, and taken from that of Bab-ud-Din, assumed by him.
Bac: A broad, flat-bottomed ferryboat, usually worked by a rope.
Baa: The cry or bleating of a sheep; a bleat.
Ban: An ancient title of the warden of the eastern marches of Hungary; now, a title of the viceroy of Croatia and Slavonia.
Bah: An exclamation expressive of extreme contempt.
Bai: a language spoken in the Dali region of Yunnan.
Bugger: One guilty of buggery or unnatural vice; a sodomite.
Bloodily: In a bloody manner; cruelly; with a disposition to shed blood.
Brickbat: A piece or fragment of a brick. See 1st Bat, n. 4.
Baccivorous: Eating, or subsisting on, berries; as, baccivorous birds.
Box tail: In a flying machine, a tail or rudder, usually fixed, resembling a box kite.
Built: Formed; shaped; constructed; made; -- often used in composition and preceded by the word denoting the form; as, frigate-built, clipper-built, etc.
beret: a cap made of soft cloth with no brim or bill, widening somewhat outward from a close-fitting headband to a flat top, which often has a button or tab in its center.
Build: Form or mode of construction; general figure; make; as, the build of a ship; a great build on a man.
Bounder: One who, or that which, limits; a boundary.
Bulimia: A disease in which there is a perpetual and insatiable appetite for food; a diseased and voracious appetite.
Bellarmine: A stoneware jug of a pattern originated in the neighborhood of Cologne, Germany, in the 16th century. It has a bearded face or mask supposed to represent Cardinal Bellarmine, a leader in the Roman Catholic Counter Reformation, following the Reformation; -- called also graybeard, longbeard.
butterfingered: Apt to let things fall, or to let them slip away; not skillful in using the hands; slippery; careless.
bistro: a small informal restaurant, especially one serving alcoholic beverages.
Beseem: To seem; to appear; to be fitting.
Beefy: Having much beef; of the nature of beef; resembling beef; fleshy.
Binaural: Of or pertaining to, or used by, both ears.
Bicrenate: Twice crenated, as in the case of leaves whose crenatures are themselves crenate.
Badian: An evergreen Chinese shrub of the Magnolia family (Illicium anisatum), and its aromatic seeds; Chinese anise; star anise.
blossoming: the process of budding and unfolding of blossoms.
Buttonbush: A shrub (Cephalanthus occidentalis) growing by the waterside; -- so called from its globular head of flowers. See Capitulum.
Bandog: A mastiff or other large and fierce dog, usually kept chained or tied up.
Boniform: Sensitive or responsive to moral excellence.
Bubalus: a genus of ruminants which in some classification systems is included in the genus Bos; the water buffaloes.
buteonine: any hawk of the genus Buteo.
Bedcord: A cord or rope interwoven in a bedstead so as to support the bed.
Bermudian: a native or inhabitant of Bermuda.
beardown: devoting full strength and concentrated attention to.
baryon: any of the elementary particles having a mass equal to or greater than that of a proton and that participate in strong interactions; a hadron with a baryon number of +1.
Barricade: To fortify or close with a barricade or with barricades; to stop up, as a passage; to obstruct; as, the workmen barricaded the streets of Paris.
Basilican: Of, relating to, or resembling, a basilica; basilical.
Broken-winded: Having short breath or disordered respiration, as a horse.
Bouse: Drink, esp. alcoholic drink; also, a carouse; a booze.
bel canto: a cantabile style of operatic singing characterized by purity and evenness of tone, and a precise but brilliant vocal technique displaying ease and agility.
Blindstory: The triforium as opposed to the clearstory.
Binding screw: A set screw used to bind parts together, esp. one for making a connection in an electrical circuit.
Boud: A weevil; a worm that breeds in malt, biscuit, etc.
Breath: The air inhaled and exhaled in respiration; air which, in the process of respiration, has parted with oxygen and has received carbonic acid, aqueous vapor, warmth, etc.
Burundi: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Burundi; as, the Burundi capital.
Bluffy: Having bluffs, or bold, steep banks.
Barillet: A little cask, or something resembling one.
Bow hand: The hand that holds the bow, i. e., the left hand.
Beefsteak: A steak of beef; a slice of beef broiled or suitable for broiling.
Bedagat: The sacred books of the Buddhists in Burmah.
Bagnio: A house for bathing, sweating, etc.; -- also, in Turkey, a prison for slaves.
Bifold: Twofold; double; of two kinds, degrees, etc.
Bookstand: A place or stand for the sale of books in the streets; a bookstall.
Bromism: A diseased condition produced by the excessive use of bromine or one of its compounds. It is characterized by mental dullness and muscular weakness.
Babyhood: The state or period of infancy.
Bamboozler: A swindler; one who deceives by trickery.
Brickkiln: A kiln, or furnace, in which bricks are baked or burnt; or a pile of green bricks, laid loose, with arches underneath to receive the wood or fuel for burning them.
Backhandedness: State of being backhanded; the using of backhanded or indirect methods.
Belibel: To libel or traduce; to calumniate.
bodybuilding: exercise that builds muscles through tension.
Boehmeria: a genus comprising the false nettle.
Briefless: Having no brief; without clients; as, a briefless barrister.
Bolometer: An instrument for measuring minute quantities of radiant heat, especially in different parts of the spectrum; -- called also actinic balance, thermic balance.
Brougham: A light, enclosed carriage, with seats inside for two or four, and the fore wheels so arranged as to turn short.
Bygone: Something gone by or past; a past event.
Blotch: A blot or spot, as of color or of ink; especially a large or irregular spot. Also Fig.; as, a moral blotch.
Bosom: The breast of a human being; the part, between the arms, to which anything is pressed when embraced by them.
Beveled: Formed to a bevel angle; sloping; as, the beveled edge of a table.
Bay-antler: The second tine of a stag's horn. See under Antler.
bristlegrass: grasses of grasslands and woodlands having large gracefully arching spikes with long bristles beneath each spikelet.
Bedsore: A sore on the back or hips caused by lying for a long time in bed.
ball-hawking: skilled in stealing the ball or robbing a batter of a hit; -- used of a Baseball or basketball or football player.
Brickellia: genus of herbs of SW America having usually creamy florets followed by one-seeded fruits in a prominent bristly sheath.
Barium: One of the elements, belonging to the alkaline earth group; a metal having a silver-white color, and melting at a very high temperature. It is difficult to obtain the pure metal, from the facility with which it becomes oxidized in the air. Atomic weight, 137.  Symbol, Ba. Its oxide called baryta.
Black belt: a comedy that treats of morbid, tragic, gloomy, or grotesque situations as a major element of the plot.
beautification: the act of making something more beautiful.
Befrill: To furnish or deck with a frill.
Blackfeet: A tribe of North American Indians formerly inhabiting the country from the upper Missouri River to the Saskatchewan, but now much reduced in numbers.
blue-ribbon: selected or chosen for special qualifications; as, a blue-ribbon grand jury.
Bacterioscopic: Relating to bacterioscopy; as, a bacterioscopic examination.
Benedictory: Expressing wishes for good; as, a benedictory prayer.
Buckie: A large spiral marine shell, esp. the common whelk. See Buccinum.
Bordeller: A keeper or a frequenter of a brothel.
Bufo: A genus of Amphibia including various species of toads.
Bellows: An instrument, utensil, or machine, which, by alternate expansion and contraction, or by rise and fall of the top, draws in air through a valve and expels it through a tube for various purposes, as blowing fires, ventilating mines, or filling the pipes of an organ with wind.
Bracketing: A series or group of brackets; brackets, collectively.
bigential: Including two tribes or races of men.
Bowie knife: A knife with a strong blade from ten to fifteen inches long, and double-edged near the point; -- used as a hunting knife, and formerly as a weapon in the southwestern part of the United States. It was named from its inventor, Colonel James Bowie.  Also, by extension, any large sheath knife.
Bunsen cell: A zinc-carbon cell in which the zinc (amalgamated) is surrounded by dilute sulphuric acid, and the carbon by nitric acid or a chromic acid mixture, the two plates being separated by a porous cup.
Bennettitales: an order of fossil gymnospermous plans of the Carboniferous.
Befool: To fool; to delude or lead into error; to infatuate; to deceive.
Beleaguer: To surround with an army so as to preclude escape; to besiege; to blockade.
Benthic: of, pertaining to, or occurring at the bottom of a body of water, especially referring to the ocean depths.
Bogue: The boce; -- called also bogue bream. See Boce.
Bluntly: In a blunt manner; coarsely; plainly; abruptly; without delicacy, or the usual forms of civility.
Broking: Of or pertaining to a broker or brokers, or to brokerage.
Backhand: Sloping from left to right; -- said of handwriting.
Bleaching: The act or process of whitening, by removing color or stains; esp. the process of whitening fabrics by chemical agents.
Baselard: A short sword or dagger, worn in the fifteenth century.
Bald-faced: Having a white face or a white mark on the face, as a stag.
Basifier: That which converts into a salifiable base.
Benzamide: A transparent crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.NH2, obtained by the action of ammonia upon chloride of benzoyl, as also by several other reactions with benzoyl compounds.
Babyship: The quality of being a baby; the personality of an infant.
Bigamous: Guilty of bigamy; involving bigamy; as, a bigamous marriage.
Bellower: One who, or that which, bellows.
Booking clerk: A clerk who registers passengers, baggage, etc., for conveyance, as by railway or steamship, or who sells passage tickets at a booking office.
Brumaire: The second month of the calendar adopted by the first French republic. It began thirty days after the autumnal equinox. See Vendemiaire.
Biographize: To write a history of the life of.
Baby farmer: One who keeps a baby farm.
Borer: One that bores; an instrument for boring.
Burgundy: An old province of France (in the eastern central part).
Blockish: Like a block; deficient in understanding; stupid; dull.
Bittock: A small bit of anything, of indefinite size or quantity; a short distance.
boardroom: a room where a committee meets (such as the board of directors of a company).
brainstorm: to try to solve a problem by discussing it exhaustively in an intense group meeting encouraging uninhibited and spontaneous contributions from all members.
B-girl: a woman employed by a bar to act as a companion to men customers.
Boxthorn: A plant of the genus Lycium, esp. Lycium barbarum.
Bivalent: Equivalent in combining or displacing power to two atoms of hydrogen; dyad.
barrel cactus: any of several large cacti native to the southwestern U. S. and Mexico, having a short cylindrical form with deep vertical ribs and bearing sharp spines.  They are classed in the genera Ferocactus and Echinocactus.
Blue grass: A species of grass (Poa compressa) with bluish green stems, valuable in thin gravelly soils; wire grass.
blowjob: An act of fellatio, a form of oral sex; --  a slang term.  See blow{11}, v. i.
Bannock: A kind of cake or bread, in shape flat and roundish, commonly made of oatmeal or barley meal and baked on an iron plate, or griddle; -- used in Scotland and the northern counties of England.
Betty: A short bar used by thieves to wrench doors open.
Bobwhite: The common quail of North America (Colinus, or Ortyx, Virginianus); -- so called from its note.
Brocken specter: A mountain specter (which see), esp. that observed on the Brocken, in the Harz Mountains.
Bull trout: In England, a large salmon trout of several species, as Salmo trutta and Salmo Cambricus, which ascend rivers; -- called also sea trout.
Berain: To rain upon; to wet with rain.
Bestar: To sprinkle with, or as with, stars; to decorate with, or as with, stars; to bestud.
Basanite: Lydian stone, or black jasper, a variety of siliceous or flinty slate, of a grayish or bluish black color. It is employed to test the purity of gold, the amount of alloy being indicated by the color left on the stone when rubbed by the metal.
Burke: To murder by suffocation, or so as to produce few marks of violence, for the purpose of obtaining a body to be sold for dissection.
Butterine: A substance prepared from animal fat with some other ingredients intermixed, as an imitation of butter.
Breadstuff: Grain, flour, or meal of which bread is made.
Boy: To act as a boy; -- in allusion to the former practice of boys acting women's parts on the stage.
Blindmans holiday: The time between daylight and candle light.
Bosket: A grove; a thicket; shrubbery; an inclosure formed by branches of trees, regularly or irregularly disposed.
Breastfast: A large rope to fasten the midship part of a ship to a wharf, or to another vessel.
Bom: A large American serpent, so called from the sound it makes.
Bon: Good; valid as security for something.
Boa: A genus of large American serpents, including the boa constrictor, the emperor boa of Mexico (Boa imperator), and the chevalier boa of Peru (Boa eques).
Bob: To have a short, jerking motion; to play to and fro, or up and down; to play loosely against anything.
Bog: To sink, as into a bog; to submerge in a bog; to cause to sink and stick, as in mud and mire.
Barb: Armor for a horse. Same as 2d Bard, n., 1.
Bare: Bore; the old preterit of Bear, v.
Bard: The exterior covering of the trunk and branches of a tree; the rind.
Blackwater State: Nebraska; -- a nickname alluding to the dark color of the water of its rivers, due to the presence of a black vegetable mold in the soil.
Bark: The short, loud, explosive sound uttered by a dog; a similar sound made by some other animals.
Beehouse: A house for bees; an apiary.
Blowhole: A cavern in a cliff, at the water level, opening to the air at its farther extremity, so that the waters rush in with each surge and rise in a lofty jet from the extremity.
Barkentine: A threemasted vessel, having the foremast square-rigged, and the others schooner-rigged. [Spelled also barquentine, barkantine, etc.] See Illust. in Append.
Bennet: The common yellow-flowered avens of Europe (Geum urbanum); herb bennet. The name is sometimes given to other plants, as the hemlock, valerian, etc.
Blaze: To make public far and wide; to make known; to render conspicuous.
briquet: A block of compacted charcoal, coal dust, or peat, etc., used as a fuel.  Charcoal briquettes are a common fuel used for the outdoor barbecue grill.
breakstone: Any of various plants of the genus Saxifraga.
bored: tired of the world; bored with life.
Brisure: Any part of a rampart or parapet which deviates from the general direction.
Brutal: Of or pertaining to a brute; as, brutal nature.
Blamelessness: The quality or state of being blameless; innocence.
Brachypinacoid: A plane of an orthorhombic crystal which is parallel both to the vertical axis and to the shorter lateral (brachydiagonal) axis.
Buxus: the type genus of the Buxaceae.
Bezoartic: Having the qualities of an antidote, or of bezoar; healing.
Blackstrap: A mixture of spirituous liquor (usually rum) and molasses.
Babel: The city and tower in the land of Shinar, where the confusion of languages took place.
Barnacle: An instrument for pinching a horse's nose, and thus restraining him.
Barrier: A carpentry obstruction, stockade, or other obstacle made in a passage in order to stop an enemy.
Bombastry: Swelling words without much meaning; bombastic language; fustian.
Britzska: A long carriage, with a calash top, so constructed as to give space for reclining at night, when used on a journey.
Brassage: A sum formerly levied to pay the expense of coinage; -- now called seigniorage.
Baleful: Full of deadly or pernicious influence; destructive.
Babylonian: An inhabitant of Babylonia (which included Chaldea); a Chaldean.
Bowshot: The distance traversed by an arrow shot from a bow.
Bretwalda: The official title applied to that one of the Anglo-Saxon chieftains who was chosen by the other chiefs to lead them in their warfare against the British tribes.
Bulbel: A separable bulb formed on some flowering plants.
Bluebreast: A small European bird; the blue-throated warbler.
Bacteriological: Of or pertaining to bacteriology; as, bacteriological studies.
blinks: a typ of small Indian lettuce (Montia lamprosperma) of northern regions.
Blowy: Windy; as, blowy weather; a blowy upland.
bush baby: any of several agile long-tailed nocturnal African lemurlike primates of the genus Galago with dense woolly fur and large eyes and ears; -- called also galago.
Baunscheidtism: A form of acupuncture, followed by the rubbing of the part with a stimulating fluid.
Butteris: A steel cutting instrument, with a long bent shank set in a handle which rests against the shoulder of the operator. It is operated by a thrust movement, and used in paring the hoofs of horses.
Bayard: Properly, a bay horse, but often any horse. Commonly in the phrase blind bayard, an old blind horse.
Besmut: To blacken with smut; to foul with soot.
Bowwow: An onomatopoetic name for a dog or its bark.
Bimuscular: Having two adductor muscles, as a bivalve mollusk.
Bethrall: To reduce to thralldom; to inthrall.
Bridewell: A house of correction for the confinement of disorderly persons; -- so called from a hospital built in 1553 near St. Bride's (or Bridget's) well, in London, which was subsequently a penal workhouse.
Barefacedness: The quality of being barefaced; shamelessness; assurance; audaciousness.
Betaine: A nitrogenous base, C5H11NO2, produced artificially, and also occurring naturally in beet-root molasses and its residues, from which it is extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- called also lycine and oxyneurine. It has a sweetish taste.
Bockey: A bowl or vessel made from a gourd.
blacktopped: paved with a bituminous material; -- of roads or paths; as, a blacktopped driveway.
Bibliography: a history or description of books and manuscripts, with notices of the different editions, the times when they were printed, etc.
Bract: A leaf, usually smaller than the true leaves of a plant, from the axil of which a flower stalk arises.
Brach: A bitch of the hound kind.
Brace: To get tone or vigor; to rouse one's energies; -- with up.
Butty: One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.
Butylamine: A colorless liquid base, C4H9.NH2, of which there are four isomeric varieties.
Brocatel: A kind of coarse brocade, or figured fabric, used chiefly for tapestry, linings for carriages, etc.
Booby: Having the characteristics of a booby; stupid.
Butte: A detached low mountain, or high rising abruptly from the general level of the surrounding plain; -- applied to peculiar elevations in the Rocky Mountain region.
Breastrail: The upper rail of any parapet of ordinary height, as of a balcony; the railing of a quarter-deck, etc.
Brittle star: Any species of ophiuran starfishes. See Ophiuroidea.
bottleful: the quantity contained in a bottle.
Biscuit: A kind of unraised bread, of many varieties, plain, sweet, or fancy, formed into flat cakes, and bakes hard; as, ship biscuit.
Balsamous: Having the quality of balsam; containing balsam.
Boyer: A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end.
Balanoglossus: A peculiar marine worm. See Enteropneusta, and Tornaria.
Bombic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the silkworm; as, bombic acid.
Bipont: Relating to books printed at Deuxponts, or Bipontium (Zweibrücken), in Bavaria.
Boasting: The act of glorying or vaunting; vainglorious speaking; ostentatious display.
Blossom: To put forth blossoms or flowers; to bloom; to blow; to flower.
Beneficiary: A feudatory or vassal; hence, one who holds a benefice and uses its proceeds.
Breech-loading: Receiving the charge at the breech instead of at the muzzle.
Brisk: To make or become lively; to enliven; to animate; to take, or cause to take, an erect or bold attitude; -- usually with up.
Bacterium: A microscopic single-celled organism having no distinguishable nucleus, belonging to the kingdom Monera.  Bacteria have varying shapes, usually taking the form of a jointed rodlike filament, or a small sphere, but also in certain cases having a branched form.  Bacteria are destitute of chlorophyll, but in those members of the phylum Cyanophyta (the blue-green algae) other light-absorbing pigments are present.  They are the smallest of microscopic organisms which have their own metabolic processes carried on within cell membranes, viruses being smaller but not capable of living freely.  The bacteria are very widely diffused in nature, and multiply with marvelous rapidity, both by fission and by spores.  Bacteria may require oxygen for their energy-producing metabolism, and these are called aerobes; or may multiply in the absence of oxygen, these forms being anaerobes.  Certain species are active agents in fermentation, while others appear to be the cause of certain infectious diseases.  The branch of science with studies bacteria is bacteriology, being a division of microbiology.  See Bacillus.
bacteriemia: The presence of bacteria in the blood; same as bacteremia.
Benzole: An impure benzene, used in the arts as a solvent, and for various other purposes. See Benzene.
Bromanil: A substance analogous to chloranil but containing bromine in place of chlorine.
Blushing: The act of turning red; the appearance of a reddish color or flush upon the cheeks.
Bulletin: A brief statement of facts respecting some passing event, as military operations or the health of some distinguished personage, issued by authority for the information of the public.
blue-collar: of or designating work or workers in industry not requiring well-groomed appearance.
Bituminize: To prepare, treat, impregnate, or coat with bitumen.
Buckeye: A name given to several American trees and shrubs of the same genus (Æsculus) as the horse chestnut.
Bank book: A book kept by a depositor, in which an officer of a bank enters the debits and credits of the depositor's account with the bank.
brinkmanship: the policy or practise of pushing a dangerous situation to the brink of disaster (to the limits of safety), in order to achieve the most advantageous outcome; -- used especially of diplomatic maneuvers in crisis situations, and originally applied to the policies of John Foster Dulles under President Eisenhower.
Baum\u00e9: Designating or conforming to either of the scales used by the French chemist Antoine Baumé in the graduation of his hydrometers; of or relating to Baumé's scales or hydrometers.  There are two Baumé hydrometers.  One, which is used with liquids heavier than water, sinks to 0° in pure water, and to 15° in a 15 per cent salt solution; the other, for liquids lighter than water, sinks to 0° in a 10 per cent salt solution and to 10° in pure water.  In both cases the graduation, based on the distance between these fundamental points, is continued along the stem as far as desired.
Balkingly: In a manner to balk or frustrate.
Bleed: To let blood from; to take or draw blood from, as by opening a vein.
Boarding: The act of entering a ship, whether with a hostile or a friendly purpose.
Bepurple: To tinge or dye with a purple color.
Brasque: A paste made by mixing powdered charcoal, coal, or coke with clay, molasses, tar, or other suitable substance. It is used for lining hearths, crucibles, etc. Called also steep.
boom box: a large portable casette or compact disk player, usually having an integrated radio receiver.  It typically has two (stereophonic) speakers, and can be adjusted to play at a high sound intensity, from which the name comes.
Barbiers: A variety of paralysis, peculiar to India and the Malabar coast; -- considered by many to be the same as beriberi in a chronic form.
bacteriostatic: of or pertaining to bacteriostasis or a bacteriostat.
Beside: At the side of; on one side of.
bunce: a sudden unexpected piece of good fortune.
Buddha: The title of an incarnation of self-abnegation, virtue, and wisdom.
Blueberry: The berry of several species of Vaccinium, an ericaceous genus, differing from the American huckleberries in containing numerous minute seeds instead of ten nutlets.  The commonest species are Vaccinium Pennsylvanicum and Vaccinium vacillans.  Vaccinium corymbosum is the tall blueberry.
bacteremia: The presence of bacteria in the blood.
Benefactor: One who confers a benefit or benefits.
bull-necked: Having a short, thick and muscular neck like that of a bull.
Beaten: Made smooth by beating or treading; worn by use.
Bulge: To swell or jut out; to bend outward, as a wall when it yields to pressure; to be protuberant; as, the wall bulges.
Balder: The most beautiful and beloved of the gods; the god of peace; the son of Odin and Freya.
Blast lamp: A lamp provided with some arrangement for intensifying combustion by means of a blast.
Bulgy: Bulged; bulging; bending, or tending to bend, outward.
blindfolded: having a blindfold placed over the eyes; -- done to prevent the wearer from seeing.
Bearward: A keeper of bears. See Bearherd.
boys-and-girls: a Eurafrican annual (Mercurialis annua) naturalized in America as a weed; formerly dried for use as a purgative, diuretic or antisyphilitic.
Balloon: To go up or voyage in a balloon.
Batfish: A name given to several species of fishes:
burdened: bearing a heavy load; as, a hiker burdened with a heavy backpack.
Bee line: The shortest line from one place to another, like that of a bee to its hive when loaded with honey; an air line.
Brontotherium: A genus of large extinct mammals from the miocene strata of western North America. They were allied to the rhinoceros, but the skull bears a pair of powerful horn cores in front of the orbits, and the fore feet were four-toed. See Illustration in Appendix.
Bobbery: A squabble; a tumult; a commotion; a noisy disturbance; as, to raise a bobbery.
bleep: to to obscure or replace (an offensive word or phrase) by substituting a beeping sound while broadcasting.
Brookite: A mineral consisting of titanic oxide, and hence identical with rutile and octahedrite in composition, but crystallizing in the orthorhombic system.
Boatswain: An officer who has charge of the boats, sails, rigging, colors, anchors, cables, cordage, etc., of a ship, and who also summons the crew, and performs other duties.
Buffalo: A species of the genus Bos or Bubalus (Bubalus bubalus), originally from India, but now found in most of the warmer countries of the eastern continent.  It is larger and less docile than the common ox, and is fond of marshy places and rivers.
Blissus: a genus comprising the chinch bugs.  See chinch, 2.
Bluebill: A duck of the genus Fuligula.  Two American species (Fuligula marila and Fuligula affinis) are common. See Scaup duck.
Bowbell: One born within hearing distance of Bow-bells; a cockney.
Bottony: Having a bud or button, or a kind of trefoil, at the end; furnished with knobs or buttons.
Botchy: Marked with botches; full of botches; poorly done.
bundled-up: dressed warmly; as, bundled-up sailors and soldiers.
braced: held up by braces or buttresses.
Bayamo: A violent thunder squall occurring on the south coast of Cuba, esp. near Bayamo. The gusts, called bayamo winds, are modified foehn winds.
Branchiopoda: An order of Entomostraca; -- so named from the feet of branchiopods having been supposed to perform the function of gills. It includes the fresh-water genera Branchipus, Apus, and Limnadia, and the genus Artemia found in salt lakes. It is also called Phyllopoda. See Phyllopoda, Cladocera. It is sometimes used in a broader sense.
Bowenite: A hard, compact variety of serpentine found in Rhode Island. It is of a light green color and resembles jade.
Boning: The clearing of bones from fish or meat.
Birdwatcher: one who enjoys watching birds, especially to find and identify a variety of birds in their natural habitats; a birder{2}.
Bagman: A commercial traveler; one employed to solicit orders for manufacturers and tradesmen.
back-formation: a word invented (usually unwittingly by subtracting an affix) on the assumption that a familiar word derives from it, such as emote from emotion.
bell-ringer: a person who rings church bells (as for summoning the congregation).
Bordeaux: Pertaining to Bordeaux in the south of France.
Black lead: Plumbago; graphite. It leaves a blackish mark somewhat like lead. See Graphite.
Burton: A peculiar tackle, formed of two or more blocks, or pulleys, the weight being suspended to a hook block in the bight of the running part.
Barbarousness: The quality or state of being barbarous; barbarity; barbarism.
Butyrone: A liquid ketone obtained by heating calcium butyrate.
Begird: To bind with a band or girdle; to gird.
Braise: To stew or broil in a covered kettle or pan.
Book-learned: Versed in books; having knowledge derived from books.
bookable: subject to being reserved or booked.
Bijoutry: Small articles of virtu, as jewelry, trinkets, etc.
Burletta: A comic operetta; a music farce.
Borassus: a genus of palm trees including the palmyra (Borassus flabellifer, formerly Borassus flabelliformis).
Biconcave: Concave on both sides; as, biconcave vertebræ.
Blackpoll: A warbler of the United States (Dendroica striata).
Buzzardet: A hawk resembling the buzzard, but with legs relatively longer.
Blown: Opened; in blossom or having blossomed, as a flower.
Becker: A European fish (Pagellus centrodontus); the sea bream or braise.
Bleyme: An inflammation in the foot of a horse, between the sole and the bone.
Bedswerver: One who swerves from and is unfaithful to the marriage vow.
Bombard: To attack with bombards or with artillery; especially, to throw shells, hot shot, etc., at or into.
Batatas: An aboriginal American name for the sweet potato (Ipomæa batatas).
Bolis: A meteor or brilliant shooting star, followed by a train of light or sparks; esp. one which explodes.
Bimetallism: The legalized use of two metals (as gold and silver) in the currency of a country, at a fixed relative value; -- in opposition to monometallism.
Banco: A bank, especially that of Venice.
Bishop: To make seem younger, by operating on the teeth; as, to bishop an old horse or his teeth.
bladderwrack: similar to and found with black rockweed.
Boodle: The whole collection or lot; caboodle.
Brachycephalic: Having the skull short in proportion to its breadth; shortheaded; -- in distinction from dolichocephalic.
Buxom: Yielding; pliable or compliant; ready to obey; obedient; tractable; docile; meek; humble.
Blarney: To influence by blarney; to wheedle with smooth talk; to make or accomplish by blarney.
Blackboard: A broad board painted black, or any black surface on which writing, drawing, or the working of mathematical problems can be done with chalk or crayons. It is much used in schools.  In late 20th century similar boards of a green slate as well as some colored white became common; wrioting on the slate bioards may be done with chalk, but writing on the white boards is done with colored pens, such as grease pens, which leaves a trace that can be easily erased.  The newer boards, usualy called chalkboards are nevertheless still sometimes referred to as blackboards.
Breathlessness: The state of being breathless or out of breath.
Boltonite: A granular mineral of a grayish or yellowish color, found in Bolton, Massachusetts. It is a silicate of magnesium, belonging to the chrysolite family.
Bogartian: of or pertaining to Humphrey Bogart.
Balisaur: A badgerlike animal of India (Arctonyx collaris).
blastomycete: any of various yeastlike budding fungi of the genus Blastomyces; -- they may cause disease in humans and other animals.
Buttercup: A plant of the genus Ranunculus, or crowfoot, particularly Ranunculus bulbosus, with bright yellow flowers; -- called also butterflower, golden cup, and kingcup.  It is the cuckoobud of Shakespeare.
Batfowling: A mode of catching birds at night, by holding a torch or other light, and beating the bush or perch where they roost. The birds, flying to the light, are caught with nets or otherwise.
Braw: Well-dressed; handsome; smart; brave; -- used of persons or their clothing, etc.; as, a braw lad.
Begohm: A unit of resistance equal to one billion ohms, or one thousand megohms.
Bargecourse: A part of the tiling which projects beyond the principal rafters, in buildings where there is a gable.
Baignoire: A box of the lowest tier in a theater.
Binding post: A metallic post attached to electrical apparatus for convenience in making connections.
Brand spore: One of several spores growing in a series or chain, and produced by one of the fungi called brand.
Broadway: a street in Manhattan famous for its restaurants and its theaters in the Times Square area.  At its intersection with Seventh Avenue, it forms Times Square, an area with impressive displays of bright lights, particularly advertising; it is considered by some to be the cultural center of New York City.
Buoyancy: The property of floating on the surface of a liquid, or in a fluid, as in the atmosphere; specific lightness, which is inversely as the weight compared with that of an equal volume of water.
Bearishness: Behavior like that of a bear.
Branlin: A small red worm or larva, used as bait for small fresh-water fish; -- so called from its red color.
Birl: To pour (beer or wine); to ply with drink; to drink; to carouse.
Bryozoan: Of or pertaining to the Bryozoa.
Bakelite: a thermosetting plastic used in electric insulators and for making plastic ware and telephone receivers etc.
Burnoose: A cloaklike garment and hood woven in one piece, worn by Arabs.
Bilingual: Containing, or consisting of, two languages; expressed in two languages; as, a bilingual inscription; a bilingual dictionary.
Biliprasin: A dark green pigment found in small quantity in human gallstones.
Borosilicate: A double salt of boric and silicic acids, as in the natural minerals tourmaline, datolite, etc.
Boil: A hard, painful, inflamed tumor, which, on suppuration, discharges pus, mixed with blood, and discloses a small fibrous mass of dead tissue, called the core.
Base-burner: A furnace or stove in which the fuel is contained in a hopper or chamber, and is fed to the fire as the lower stratum is consumed.
Blighia: small genus of West African evergreen trees and shrubs bearing fleshy capsular three-seeded fruits edible when neither unripe nor overripe.
Bedstock: The front or the back part of the frame of a bedstead.
Badger game: The method of blackmailing by decoying a person into a compromising situation and extorting money by threats of exposure.
Bodle: A small Scotch coin worth about one sixth of an English penny.
Brownness: The quality or state of being brown.
Billbeetle: A weevil or curculio of various species, as the corn weevil.  See Curculio.
biosynthesis: production of a chemical compound by a living organism.
Butter and eggs: a name given to several perennial plants having showy flowers of two shades of yellow, or of yellow and orange, such as Narcissus incomparabilis in Europe, and the toadflax (Linaria vulgaris) in the United States; the latter is a naturalized weed in North America.
Bassinet: A wicker basket, with a covering or hood over one end, in which young children are placed as in a cradle.
Briarean: Pertaining to, or resembling, Briareus, a giant fabled to have a hundred hands; hence, hundred-handed or many-handed.
Butterfish: A name given to several different fishes, in allusion to their slippery coating of mucus, as the Stromateus triacanthus of the Atlantic coast, the Epinephelus punctatus of the southern coast, the rock eel, and the kelpfish of New Zealand.
Bilberry: The European whortleberry (Vaccinium myrtillus); also, its edible bluish black fruit.
Berthierite: A double sulphide of antimony and iron, of a dark steel-gray color.
busted: Inoperable due to damage; broken; -- of a machine; as, the coke machine is busted.
Bourr\u00e9e: An old French dance tune in common time.
Beaver: That piece of armor which protected the lower part of the face, whether forming a part of the helmet or fixed to the breastplate. It was so constructed (with joints or otherwise) that the wearer could raise or lower it to eat and drink.
Beaucatcher: A small flat curl worn on the temple by women.
Bench: To sit on a seat of justice.
Betrayer: One who, or that which, betrays.
bergall: a small wrasse (Tautogolabrus adspersus), common in north Atantic coastal waters of the U. S.; -- also called the cunner.
Bilge: To fracture the bilge of, or stave in the bottom of (a ship or other vessel).
Bilgy: Having the smell of bilge water.
Bituminate: To treat or impregnate with bitumen; to cement with bitumen.
Bursary: The treasury of a college or monastery.
Barbizon school: A French school of the middle of the 19th century centering in the village of Barbizon near the forest of Fontainebleau. Its members went straight to nature in disregard of academic tradition, treating their subjects faithfully and with poetic feeling for color, light, and atmosphere. It is exemplified, esp. in landscapes, by Corot, Rousseau, Daubigny, Jules Dupré, and Diaz. Associated with them are certain painters of animals, as Troyon and Jaque, and of peasant life, as Millet and Jules Breton.
Blunger: A wooden blade with a cross handle, used for mi&unr_;ing the clay in potteries; a plunger.
Bedizenment: That which bedizens; the act of dressing, or the state of being dressed, tawdrily.
Barrel process: A process of extracting gold or silver by treating the ore in a revolving barrel, or drum, with mercury, chlorine, cyanide solution, or other reagent.
Bollandists: The Jesuit editors of the “Acta Sanctorum”, or Lives of the Saints; -- named from John Bolland, who began the work.
Bolus: A rounded mass of anything, esp. a large pill.
brasilin: A substance, C16H14O5, extracted from brazilwood as a yellow crystalline powder which is white when pure. It is colored intensely red by alkalies on exposure to the air, being oxidized to bra*sil"e*in (&unr_;), C16H12O5, to which brazilwood owes its dyeing properties.
Butterwort: A genus of low herbs (Pinguicula) having simple leaves which secrete from their glandular upper surface a viscid fluid, to which insects adhere, after which the margin infolds and the insects are digested by the plant. The species are found mostly in the North Temperate zone.
Blolly: A shrub or small tree of southern Florida and the West Indies (Pisonia obtusata) with smooth oval leaves and a hard, 10-ribbed fruit.
Balcony: A platform projecting from the wall of a building, usually resting on brackets or consoles, and inclosed by a parapet; as, a balcony in front of a window. Also, a projecting gallery in places of amusement; as, the balcony in a theater.
Bonnaz: A kind of embroidery made with a complicated sewing machine, said to have been originally invented by a Frenchman of the name of Bonnaz. The work is done either in freehand or by following a perforated design.
Brogue: A stout, coarse shoe; a brogan.
Binotonous: Consisting of two notes; as, a binotonous cry.
Backwoodsman: A man living in the forest in or beyond the new settlements, especially on the western frontiers of the United States in former times.
Bestialize: To make bestial, or like a beast; to degrade; to brutalize.
Browbeating: The act of bearing down, abashing, or disconcerting, with stern looks, supercilious manners, or confident assertions.
Backcast: Anything which brings misfortune upon one, or causes failure in an effort or enterprise; a reverse.
By-lane: A private lane, or one opening out of the usual road.
B-horizon: that layer of soil in a well-developed soil lying immediately below the A-horizon, and which contains deposits of organic matter leached from surface soils.
Bucker: A horse or mule that bucks.
Bucket: To draw or lift in, or as if in, buckets; as, to bucket water.
bullying: Noisily domineering; tending to browbeat others.
beanfeast: (British) an annual dinner party given by an employer for the employees.
Beforehand: In comfortable circumstances as regards property; forehanded.
Breadthwise: In the direction of the breadth.
broomcorn: A tall variety of grass (Sorghum vulgare technicum), having a joined stem, like maize, rising to the height of eight or ten feet, and bearing its seeds on a panicle with long stiff branches, of which brooms are made.
Beguile: To delude by guile, artifice, or craft; to deceive or impose on, as by a false statement; to lure.
Brigue: To contend for; to canvass; to solicit.
Babillard: The lesser whitethroat of Europe; -- called also babbling warbler.
Businesslike: In the manner of one transacting business wisely and by right methods; practical and efficient.
Boastful: Given to, or full of, boasting; inclined to boast; vaunting; vainglorious; self-praising.
Brigade: To form into a brigade, or into brigades.
Bully tree: The name of several West Indian trees of the order Sapotaceæ, as Dipholis nigra and species of Sapota and Mimusops. Most of them yield a substance closely resembling gutta-percha.
backpacker: one who backpacks; as, two backpackers were mauled by bears in Yellowstone this week.
Bushel: To mend or repair, as men's garments; to repair garments.
Bostryx: A form of cymose inflorescence with all the flowers on one side of the rachis, usually causing it to curl; -- called also a uniparous helicoid cyme.
Basking shark: One of the largest species of sharks (Cetorhinus maximus), so called from its habit of basking in the sun; the liver shark, or bone shark.  It inhabits the northern seas of Europe and America, and grows to a length of more than forty feet. It is a harmless species.
Bechance: To befall; to chance; to happen to.
Blazoner: One who gives publicity, proclaims, or blazons; esp., one who blazons coats of arms; a herald.
Bude light: A light in which high illuminating power is obtained by introducing a jet of oxygen gas or of common air into the center of a flame fed with coal gas or with oil.
Bagatelle: A trifle; a thing of no importance.
Baker: One whose business it is to bake bread, biscuit, etc.
buttoned: furnished with buttons or something buttonlike.  Opposite of unbuttoned.
Brocaded: Woven or worked, as brocade, with gold and silver, or with raised flowers, etc.
Biquintile: An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each other by twice the fifth part of a great circle -- that is, twice 72 degrees.
burn-up: a high-speed motorcycle race on a public road.
Bain-marie: A vessel for holding hot water in which another vessel may be heated without scorching its contents; -- used for warming or preparing food or pharmaceutical preparations.
brooder: a box designed to maintain a constant temperature by the use of a thermostat; used for chicks or premature infants.
Burrower: One who, or that which, burrows; an animal that makes a hole under ground and lives in it.
Barghest: A goblin, in the shape of a large dog, portending misfortune.
befogged: confused and vague; used especially of thinking.
Bridgehead: A fortification commanding the extremity of a bridge nearest the enemy, to insure the preservation and usefulness of the bridge, and prevent the enemy from crossing; a tête-de-pont.
Bryony: The common name of several cucurbitaceous plants of the genus Bryonia.  The root of Bryonia alba (rough bryony or white bryony) and of Bryonia dioica is a strong, irritating cathartic.
Bonnet rouge: The red cap adopted by the extremists in the French Revolution, which became a sign of patriotism at that epoch; hence, a revolutionist; a Red Republican.
Bullfist: A kind of fungus. See Puffball.
