bum: To borrow without intention of returning; to cadge; as, to bum a cigarette; to bum a cup of coffee; -- usually with inexpensive items as the object.
Bimaculate: Having, or marked with, two spots.
brouhaha: the confused noise of many voices.
Benedictine: One of a famous order of monks, established by St. Benedict of Nursia in the sixth century. This order was introduced into the United States in 1846.
Brontozoum: An extinct animal of large size, known from its three-toed footprints in Mesozoic sandstone.
bioelectricity: electric phenomena in animals or plants.
Baryto-calcite: A mineral of a white or gray color, occurring massive or crystallized. It is a compound of the carbonates of barium and calcium.
Betray: To deliver into the hands of an enemy by treachery or fraud, in violation of trust; to give up treacherously or faithlessly; as, an officer betrayed the city.
Benting time: The season when pigeons are said to feed on bents, before peas are ripe.
Branchial: Of or pertaining to branchiæ or gills.
Betrap: To draw into, or catch in, a trap; to insnare; to circumvent.
Bibliographic: Pertaining to bibliography, or the history of books.
Babble: Idle talk; senseless prattle; gabble; twaddle.
Berthage: A place for mooring vessels in a dock or harbor.
Baresark: A Berserker, or Norse warrior who fought without armor, or shirt of mail. Hence, adverbially: Without shirt of mail or armor.
beachlike: having an extensive gently sloping area of sand or gravel; -- of a shore or shoreline.  Opposite of cliffy.
Billiard: Of or pertaining to the game of billiards.
Barmote: A court held in Derbyshire, in England, for deciding controversies between miners.
Barringout: The act of closing the doors of a schoolroom against a schoolmaster; -- a boyish mode of rebellion in schools.
Blockage: The act of blocking up; the state of being blocked up.
Barbate: Bearded; beset with long and weak hairs.
Black wash: A lotion made by mixing calomel and lime water.
Bothnian: Of or pertaining to Bothnia, a country of northern Europe, or to a gulf of the same name which forms the northern part of the Baltic sea.
Bronzist: One who makes, imitates, collects, or deals in, bronzes.
baked: dried out by heat or excessive exposure to sunlight.
Burgess: An inhabitant of a borough or walled town, or one who possesses a tenement therein; a citizen or freeman of a borough.
Basic steel: Steel produced by the basic process.
butylate: to introduce the butyl group into (a chemical compound).
Basaltiform: In the form of basalt; columnar.
batholite: A large mass of intrusive igneous rock believed to have solidified deep within the earth.
Bespatter: To soil by spattering; to sprinkle, esp. with dirty water, mud, or anything which will leave foul spots or stains.
batholith: A large mass of intrusive igneous rock believed to have solidified deep within the earth.
Boyishly: In a boyish manner; like a boy.
Brassicaceous: Related to, or resembling, the cabbage, or plants of the Cabbage family.
Bateau: A boat; esp. a flat-bottomed, clumsy boat used on the Canadian lakes and rivers.
Brachyceral: Having short antennæ, as certain insects.
Blow-off: A blowing off steam, water, etc.;
Brigadier general: An officer in rank next above a colonel, and below a major general. He commands a brigade, and is sometimes called, by a shortening of his title, simple a brigadier.
Blameless: Free from blame; without fault; innocent; guiltless; -- sometimes followed by of.
Banian: A Hindu trader, merchant, cashier, or money changer.
Bermuda lily: The large white lily (Lilium longiflorum eximium, syn. Lilium Harrisii) which is extensively cultivated in Bermuda.
Bell-shaped: Having the shape of a wide-mouthed bell; campanulate.
bobbysocks: a sock that reaches just above the ankle.
Bleared: Dimmed, as by a watery humor; affected with rheum.
bronchiolar: of or pertaining to a bronchiole.
Bathymetric: Pertaining to bathymetry; relating to the measurement of depths, especially of depths in the sea.
bassarisk: A raccoonlike omnivorous mammal (Bassariscus astutus) of Mexico and southwestern U. S. having a long bushy tail with black and white rings.
Beginner: One who begins or originates anything. Specifically: A young or inexperienced practitioner or student; a tyro.
Boor: A husbandman; a peasant; a rustic; esp. a clownish or unrefined countryman.
Boom: To cause to advance rapidly in price; as, to boom railroad or mining shares; to create a “boom” for; as to boom Mr. C. for senator.
Boon: The woody portion flax, which is separated from the fiber as refuse matter by retting, braking, and scutching.
Browpost: A beam that goes across a building.
Baldpate: Destitute of hair on the head; baldheaded.
Bachelors button: A plant with flowers shaped like buttons; especially, several species of Ranunculus, and the cornflower (Centaurea cyanus) and globe amaranth (Gomphrena).
Brahms: a famous German composer, b. 1833, d. 1897.
black and blue: the dark color of a bruise in the flesh, which is accompanied with a mixture of blue.
Brahma: The One First Cause; also, one of the triad of Hindu gods. The triad consists of Brahma, the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer.
Buccaneer: To act the part of a buccaneer; to live as a piratical adventurer or sea robber.
bandleader: The leader of a dance band.
Brackish: Saltish, or salt in a moderate degree, as water in saline soil.
Bezoardic: Pertaining to, or compounded with, bezoar.
Belooche Beloochee: Of or pertaining to Beloochistan, or to its inhabitants.
Bufferin: a brand of aspirin tablets coated with a substance capable of neutralizing acid (a “buffer”); -- sometimes applied generically to any buffered aspirin preparation.
Banana: A perennial herbaceous plant of almost treelike size (Musa sapientum); also, its edible fruit. See Musa.
Blackmail: To extort money from by exciting fears of injury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation, distress of mind, etc.; as, to blackmail a merchant by threatening to expose an alleged fraud.
Bestiary: A treatise on beasts; esp., one of the moralizing or allegorical beast tales written in the Middle Ages.
Boyar: A member of a Russian aristocratic order abolished by Peter the Great. Also, one of a privileged class in Roumania.
Boyau: A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication from one siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
Balbuties: The defect of stammering; also, a kind of incomplete pronunciation.
Bioluminescence: a type of luminescence produced by biological or biochemical processes, such as a glowworm glow or the action of luciferase on luciferin.  A well-known example is that of firefly luminescence.  See also luciferin.
Breachy: Apt to break fences or to break out of pasture; unruly; as, breachy cattle.
Beauseant: The black and white standard of the Knights Templars.
Beyond: Further away; at a distance; yonder.
Biome: a specific type of complex ecological community characterized by specific environmental conditions and a distinctive group of plants and animals, maintained in a relatively stable equilibrium, such as a rain forest biome or prairie biome.
Bitless: Not having a bit or bridle.
Bifilar: Two-threaded; involving the use of two threads; as, bifilar suspension; a bifilar balance.
Bayadere: A female dancer in the East Indies.
Brancher: That which shoots forth branches; one who shows growth in various directions.
Bleating: The cry of, or as of, a sheep.
Boulangism: The spirit or principles of a French political movement identified with Gen. Georges Boulanger (d. 1891), whose militarism and advocacy of revenge on Germany attracted to him a miscellaneous party of monarchists and Republican malcontents.
Bonfire: A large fire built in the open air, as an expression of public joy and exultation, or for amusement.
Bondsman: A slave; a villain; a serf; a bondman.
Beguine: A woman belonging to one of the religious and charitable associations or communities in the Netherlands, and elsewhere, whose members live in beguinages and are not bound by perpetual vows.
Boride: A binary compound of boron with a more positive or basic element or radical; -- formerly called boruret.
Bibulously: In a bibulous manner; with profuse imbibition or absorption.
Bagging: Reaping peas, beans, wheat, etc., with a chopping stroke.
Biparietal: Of or pertaining to the diameter of the cranium, from one parietal fossa to the other.
Barograph: An instrument for recording automatically the variations of atmospheric pressure.
Broad seal: The great seal of England; the public seal of a country or state.
Ballista: An ancient military engine, in the form of a crossbow, used for hurling large missiles.
Brie cheese: A kind of soft French cream cheese; -- so called from the district in France where it is made; it is milder than Camembert; -- called also fromage de Brie, Brie and brie (uncapitalized).
Blowzed: Having high color from exposure to the weather; ruddy-faced; blowzy; disordered.
Barracuda: Any of several voracious pikelike marine fishes allied to the gray mullets, constituting the genus Sphyræna and family Sphyrænidæ.  The great barracuda (Sphyræna barracuda) of the West Indies, Florida, etc., is often six feet or more long, and as dangerous as a shark.  In Cuba its flesh is reputed to be poisonous.  Sphyræna Argentea of the Pacific coast and Sphyræna sphyræna of Europe are smaller species, and are used as food.
Blanchimeter: An instrument for measuring the bleaching power of chloride of lime and potash; a chlorometer.
Bidentate: Having two teeth or two toothlike processes; two-toothed.
Barouche: A four-wheeled carriage, with a falling top, a seat on the outside for the driver, and two double seats on the inside arranged so that the sitters on the front seat face those on the back seat.
Benthos: The bottom of the sea, esp. of the deep oceans;
bachelor-at-arms: a knight of the lowest order; he was permitted to display only a pennon.
Bisulphate: A sulphate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid is replaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportion of the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in the normal sulphates; an acid sulphate.
bushwhack: to live in the bush as a fugitive or as a guerilla.
Berylline: Like a beryl; of a light or bluish green color.
Buddle: To wash ore in a buddle.
Benefit: To gain advantage; to make improvement; to profit; as, he will benefit by the change.
Ballahoo: A fast-sailing schooner, used in the Bermudas and West Indies.
Bedrench: To drench; to saturate with moisture; to soak.
Bisulphide: A sulphide having two atoms of sulphur in the molecule; a disulphide, as in iron pyrites, FeS2; -- less frequently called bisulphuret.
Bestial: A domestic animal; also collectively, cattle; as, other kinds of bestial.
Byssine: Made of silk; having a silky or flaxlike appearance.
Bogtrotter: One who lives in a boggy country; -- applied in derision to the lowest class of Irish.
Broiling: Excessively hot; as, a broiling sun.
Beatitude: Felicity of the highest kind; consummate bliss.
butcher bird: any species of shrike of the genus Lanius, so called because they impale their prey on thorns.
By-end: Private end or interest; secret purpose; selfish advantage.
Brelan carre: In French games, a double pair royal.
Baronetcy: The rank or patent of a baronet.
Breadwinner: The member of a family whose labor supplies the food of the family; one who works for his living.
Blackheart: A heart-shaped cherry with a very dark-colored skin.
breakability: the quality of being easily damaged or destroyed.
Bedeck: To deck, ornament, or adorn; to grace.
Boxhauling: A method of going from one tack to another. See Boxhaul.
Bourn: A bound; a boundary; a limit. Hence: Point aimed at; goal.
Breech sight: A device attached to the breech of a firearm, to guide the eye, in conjunction with the front sight, in taking aim.
Brontosaurus: A genus of large sauropod American dinosaurs of the jurassic era, or an individual of that genus. A length of sixty feet is believed to have been attained by these reptiles.  The genus is also called Apatosaurus, and individuals of the genus are also called brontosaurs.
Basihyal: Noting two small bones, forming the body of the inverted hyoid arch.
Bound: Ready or intending to go; on the way toward; going; -- with to or for, or with an adverb of motion; as, a ship is bound to Cadiz, or for Cadiz.
Bullcomber: A scaraboid beetle; esp. the Typhæus vulgaris of Europe.
busywork: active work of little value, performed merely to occupy time, avoid boredom, or to look busy; as, while he was waiting he filled the days with busywork.
Badderlocks: A large black seaweed (Alaria esculenta) sometimes eaten in Europe; -- also called murlins, honeyware, and henware.
Balsamine: The Impatiens balsamina, or garden balsam.
Brimful: Full to the brim; completely full; ready to overflow.
Blond metal: A variety of clay ironstone, in Staffordshire, England, used for making tools.
Bin: An old form of Be and Been.
Blotting paper: A kind of thick, bibulous, unsized paper, used to absorb superfluous ink from a freshly written manuscript, and thus prevent blots.
Boehmenism: the mystical theological doctrine of Jakob Boehme that influenced the Quakers.
Beaumontague: A cement used in making joints, filling cracks, etc.  For iron, the principal constituents are iron borings and sal ammoniac; for wood, white lead or litharge, whiting, and linseed oil.
Bit: 3d sing. pr. of Bid, for biddeth.
Bis: Twice; -- a word showing that something is, or is to be, repeated; as a passage of music, or an item in accounts.
Bridegroom: A man newly married, or just about to be married.
Batiste: Originally, cambric or lawn of fine linen; now applied also to cloth of similar texture made of cotton.
Bewitchery: The power of bewitching or fascinating; bewitchment; charm; fascination.
Boggle: To embarrass with difficulties; to make a bungle or botch of.
Bumpkin: An awkward, heavy country fellow; a clown; a country lout.
Bunchberry: The dwarf cornel (Cornus Canadensis), which bears a dense cluster of bright red, edible berries.
Buttermilk: The milk that remains after the butter is separated from the cream.
Brand-new: Quite new; bright as if fresh from the forge.
Bivium: One side of an echinoderm, including a pair of ambulacra, in distinction from the opposite side (trivium), which includes three ambulacra.
Barometer: An instrument for determining the weight or pressure of the atmosphere, and hence for judging of the probable changes of weather, or for ascertaining the height of any ascent.
Buncombe: Speech-making for the gratification of constituents, or to gain public applause; flattering talk for a selfish purpose; anything said for mere show.
Bootless: Unavailing; unprofitable; useless; without advantage or success.
Ballasting: That which is used for steadying anything; ballast.
Bondstone: A stone running through a wall from one face to another, to bind it together; a binding stone.
Bummalo: A small marine Asiatic fish (Saurus ophidon) used in India as a relish; -- called also Bombay duck.
Bay rum: A fragrant liquid, used for cosmetic and medicinal purposes.
bosn: a petty officer on a merchant ship who controls the work of other seamen.
Barley-bree: Liquor made from barley; strong ale.
bosa: A drink, used in the East. See Boza.
Buffoonery: The arts and practices of a buffoon, as low jests, ridiculous pranks, vulgar tricks and postures.
boffin: a scientist or technician, especially one engaged in military research.
Bisexual: Of both sexes; hermaphrodite; as a flower with stamens and pistil, or an animal having ovaries and testes.
Boroughmaster: The mayor, governor, or bailiff of a borough.
Burgomaster: A chief magistrate of a municipal town in Holland, Flanders, and Germany, corresponding to mayor in England and the United States; a burghmaster.
Barmaster: Formerly, a local judge among miners; now, an officer of the barmote.
Beggars lice: The prickly fruit or seed of certain plants (as some species of Echinospermum and Cynoglossum) which cling to the clothing of those who brush by them.
Betelguese: A bright star of the first magnitude, near one shoulder of Orion.
Bollworm: The larva of a moth (Heliothis armigera) which devours the bolls or unripe pods of the cotton plant, often doing great damage to the crops.
Bramble bush: The bramble, or a collection of brambles growing together.
bingo: a game commonly used for low-stakes gambling, in which numbered balls or slips are drawn at random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards, called Bingo cards, which have square arrangement of such numbers.  Each card has a different arrangement of the numbers, and the first player to cover all numbers in one row (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal) is the winner, usually announcing that fact by a cry of “Bingo!”
Bimetallic: Of or relating to, or using, a double metallic standard (as gold and silver) for a system of coins or currency.
Brachelytra: A group of beetles having short elytra, as the rove beetles.
Baffling: Frustrating; discomfiting; disconcerting; as, baffling currents, winds, tasks.
Bellwort: A genus of plants (Uvularia) with yellowish bell-shaped flowers.
Bicarinate: Having two keel-like projections, as the upper palea of grasses.
Barong: A kind of cutting weapon similar to a cleaver, with a thick back and thin razorlike edge, used by the Moros of the Philippine Islands.
Biarticulate: Having, or consisting of, tow joints.
Barbados: A West Indian island, giving its name to a disease, to a cherry, etc.
Barony: The fee or domain of a baron; the lordship, dignity, or rank of a baron.
Bisegment: One of tow equal parts of a line, or other magnitude.
Benedicite: An exclamation corresponding to Bless you !.
Buss: A small strong vessel with two masts and two cabins; -- used in the herring fishery.
Busk: To prepare; to make ready; to array; to dress.
Bush: To furnish with a bush, or lining; as, to bush a pivot hole.
Birds-nesting: Hunting for, or taking, birds' nests or their contents.
Breakaway: A wild rush of sheep, cattle, horses, or camels (especially at the smell or the sight of water); a stampede.
bacca: an indehiscent fruit derived from a single ovary having one or many seeds within a fleshy wall or pericarp: e. g. grape; tomato; cranberry.
Blenheim spaniel: A small variety of spaniel, kept as a pet.
Begrudge: To grudge; to envy the possession of.
Butyraceous: Having the qualities of butter; resembling butter.
boscage: A growth of trees or shrubs; underwood; a thicket; thick foliage; a wooded landscape.
Basketry: The art of making baskets; also, baskets, taken collectively.
Bitterness: The quality or state of being bitter, sharp, or acrid, in either a literal or figurative sense; implacableness; resentfulness; severity; keenness of reproach or sarcasm; deep distress, grief, or vexation of mind.
Blunging: The process of mixing clay in potteries with a blunger.
Birdcall: A sound made in imitation of the note or cry of a bird for the purpose of decoying the bird or its mate.
Bristol: A seaport city in the west of England.
Brackishness: The quality or state of being brackish, or somewhat salt.
Biquadrate: The fourth power, or the square of the square. Thus 4x4=16, the square of 4, and 16x16=256, the biquadrate of 4.
Baby jumper: A hoop suspended by an elastic strap, in which a young child may be held secure while amusing itself by jumping on the floor.
brontosaur: a dinosaur of the genus Brontosaurus; an individual may also be called a brontosaurus or an apatosaurus.
Bellycheat: An apron or covering for the front of the person.
Bidding prayer: The prayer for the souls of benefactors, said before the sermon.
Backslide: To slide back; to fall away; esp. to abandon gradually the faith and practice of a religion that has been professed.
Brininess: The state or quality of being briny; saltness; brinishness.
Blood money: Money paid to the next of kin of a person who has been killed by another.
Babish: Like a babe; a childish; babyish.
Babism: The doctrine of a modern religious pantheistical sect in Persia, which was founded, about 1844, by Mirza Ali Mohammed ibn Rabhik (1820 -- 1850), who assumed the title of Bab-ed-Din (Per., Gate of the Faith).  Babism is a mixture of Mohammedan, Christian, Jewish, and Parsi elements.  This doctrine forbids concubinage and polygamy, and frees women from many of the degradations imposed upon them among the orthodox Mohammedans.  Mendicancy, the use of intoxicating liquors and drugs, and slave dealing, are forbidden; asceticism is discountenanced.
Bench warrant: A process issued by a presiding judge or by a court against a person guilty of some contempt, or indicted for some crime; -- so called in distinction from a justice's warrant.
Bomb: To sound; to boom; to make a humming or buzzing sound.
Bunch-backed: Having a bunch on the back; crooked.
Bois durci: A hard, highly polishable composition, made of fine sawdust from hard wood (as rosewood) mixed with blood, and pressed.
Banyan: A tree of the same genus as the common fig, and called the Indian fig (Ficus Indica), whose branches send shoots to the ground, which take root and become additional trunks, until it may be the tree covers some acres of ground and is able to shelter thousands of men.
Bedquilt: A quilt for a bed; a coverlet.
blood-related: related by blood, i.e. by a common genetic heritage.
Burmese-Yi: a language spoken in Northern Burma and Yunnan.
Brushite: A white or gray crystalline mineral consisting of the acid phosphate of calcium.
broadcaster: someone who broadcasts on radio or television.
Beatific: Having the power to impart or complete blissful enjoyment; blissful.
Badger: To tease or annoy, as a badger when baited; to worry or irritate persistently.
beefalo: a hardy breed of beef cattle derived as a cross between the American bison and domestic cattle, usually being genetically 3/8 bison and 5/8 domestic bovine; -- it yields leaner beef than conventional breeds.
Blackfoot: Of or pertaining to the Blackfeet; as, a Blackfoot Indian.
backspace: In typing text, to press the backspace key so as to reposition the carriage or cursor on the previous space.
Brelan favori: In French games, a pair royal composed of 2 cards in the hand and the card turned.
Blocking: The act of obstructing, supporting, shaping, or stamping with a block or blocks.
Boatwoman: A woman who manages a boat.
Balsa: A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of South America.
Blet: To decay internally when overripe; -- said of fruit.
Blea: The part of a tree which lies immediately under the bark; the alburnum or sapwood.
Bucranium: A sculptured ornament, representing an ox skull adorned with wreaths, etc.
Bleb: A large vesicle or bulla, usually containing a serous fluid; a blister; a bubble, as in water, glass, etc.
Babbler: An idle talker; an irrational prater; a teller of secrets.
Bryology: That part of botany which relates to mosses.
budgerigar: small Australian parakeet (Melopsittacus undulatus) usually light green with black and yellow markings in the wild but bred in many colors.
Barcon: A vessel for freight; -- used in the Mediterranean.
Barramundi: A remarkable Australian fresh-water ganoid fish of the genus Ceratodus.
Bill broker: One who negotiates the discount of bills.
Bultel: A bolter or bolting cloth; also, bran.
Break: An opening made by fracture or disruption.
Bream: To clean, as a ship's bottom of adherent shells, seaweed, etc., by the application of fire and scraping.
Bread: To cover with bread crumbs, preparatory to cooking; as, breaded cutlets.
boogie-woogie: an instrumental version of the blues (especially for piano).
Bisectrix: The line bisecting the angle between the optic axes of a biaxial crystal.
Brevet: Taking or conferring rank by brevet; as, a brevet colonel; a brevet commission.
Bonnet: To take off the bonnet or cap as a mark of respect; to uncover.
burunduki: a terrestrial Siberian squirrel (Eutamius asiaticus or Eutamius sibiricus).
Betongue: To attack with the tongue; to abuse; to insult.
Borderer: One who dwells on a border, or at the extreme part or confines of a country, region, or tract of land; one who dwells near to a place or region.
Becuiba: The nut of the Brazilian tree Myristica Bicuhyba, which yields a medicinal balsam used for rheumatism.
bunkmate: someone who occupies the same sleeping quarters as oneself.
Basic slag: A by-product from the manufacture of steel by the basic process, used as a fertilizer. It is rich in lime and contains 14 to 20 per cent of phosphoric acid. Called also Thomas slag, phosphatic slag, and odorless phosphate.
breakaxe: a West Indian timber tree (Sloanea jamaicensis) having very hard wood.
Boast: Act of boasting; vaunting or bragging.
Bisect: To cut or divide into two parts.
Bulau: An East Indian insectivorous mammal (Gymnura Rafflesii), somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.
Bestick: To stick over, as with sharp points pressed in; to mark by infixing points or spots here and there; to pierce.
Biltong: Lean meat cut into strips and sun-dried.
Bettong: A small, leaping Australian marsupial of the genus Bettongia; the jerboa kangaroo.
Backsight: The reading of the leveling staff in its unchanged position when the leveling instrument has been taken to a new position; a sight directed backwards to a station previously occupied.  Cf. Foresight, n., 3.
Brownwort: A species of figwort or Scrophularia (Scrophularia vernalis), and other species of the same genus, mostly perennials with inconspicuous coarse flowers.
bird-on-the-wing: a common trailing perennial milkwort of eastern North America (Polygala paucifolia), having leaves like wintergreen and usually rosy-purple flowers with winged sepals.
Blooded: Having pure blood, or a large admixture or pure blood; of approved breed; of the best stock.
B\u0153otian: Of or pertaining to Bœotia; hence, stupid; dull; obtuse.
Brother german: A brother by both the father's and mother's side, in contradistinction to a uterine brother, one by the mother only.
Bushranger: One who roams, or hides, among the bushes; especially, in Australia, an escaped criminal living in the bush.
Brownstone: A dark variety of sandstone, much used for building purposes.
Bird of paradise: The name of several very beautiful birds of the genus Paradisea and allied genera, inhabiting New Guinea and the adjacent islands. The males have brilliant colors, elegant plumes, and often remarkable tail feathers.
Boroglyceride: A compound of boric acid and glycerin, used as an antiseptic.
Boredom: The state of being bored, or pestered; a state of ennui.
Bibliolater: A worshiper of books; especially, a worshiper of the Bible; a believer in its verbal inspiration.
betatron: a type of particle accelerator which accelerates a continuous beam of electrons to high speeds by means of the electric field produced by changing magnetic flux.
Batta: Rate of exchange; also, the discount on uncurrent coins.
Bluefish: A large voracious fish (Pomatomus saitatrix), of the family Carangidæ, valued as a food fish, and widely distributed on the American coast. On the New Jersey and Rhode Island coast it is called the horse mackerel, in Virginia saltwater tailor, or skipjack.
Bigly: In a tumid, swelling, blustering manner; haughtily; violently.
Bejewel: To ornament with a jewel or with jewels; to spangle.
Bubale: A large antelope (Alcelaphus bubalis) of Egypt and the Desert of Sahara, supposed by some to be the fallow deer of the Bible.
bacteriostat: a chemical or biological material that inhibits bacterial growth.
Bottomless: Without a bottom; hence, fathomless; baseless; as, a bottomless abyss.
backbencher: a member of the House of Commons of Great Britain who is not a party leader.
Brokenness: The state or quality of being broken; unevenness.
Barrister: Counselor at law; a counsel admitted to plead at the bar, and undertake the public trial of causes, as distinguished from an attorney or solicitor. See Attorney.
Bridgetree: The beam which supports the spindle socket of the runner in a grinding mill.
Bystander: One who stands near; a spectator; one who has no concern with the business transacting.
Bolero: A Spanish dance, or the lively music which accompanies it.
Buzzer: One who, or that which, buzzes; a whisperer; a talebearer.
beanbag: a small cloth bag filled with dried beans; it is thrown from person to person in games.
Bloodhound: A breed of large and powerful dogs, with long, smooth, and pendulous ears, and remarkable for acuteness of smell.  It is employed to recover game or prey which has escaped wounded from a hunter, and for tracking criminals.  Formerly it was used for pursuing runaway slaves.  Other varieties of dog are often used for the same purpose and go by the same name.  The Cuban bloodhound is said to be a variety of the mastiff.
Beefwood: An Australian tree (Casuarina), and its red wood, used for cabinetwork; also, the trees Stenocarpus salignus of New South Wales, and Banksia compar of Queensland.
Burglar: One guilty of the crime of burglary.
Bockelet: A kind of long-winged hawk; -- called also bockerel, and bockeret.
Bumbailiff: See Bound bailiff, under Bound, a.
Bachelorship: The state of being a bachelor.
Blazer: Anything that blazes or glows, as with heat or flame.
benzenoid: similar to benzene in structure or linkage; having an aromatic ring system.
Bilaminar: Formed of, or having, two laminæ, or thin plates.
brierwood: wood from the hard woody root of the briar Erica arborea; it is used to make tobacco pipes.  See also 2nd brier and brier root.
Beslaver: To defile with slaver; to beslobber.
Balistoid: Like a fish of the genus Balistes; of the family Balistidæ. See Filefish.
Barter: The act or practice of trafficking by exchange of commodities; an exchange of goods.
Burst: A sudden breaking forth; a violent rending; an explosion; as, a burst of thunder; a burst of applause; a burst of passion; a burst of inspiration.
butterfat: the fatty substance of milk from which butter is made.
Bursa: Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovial sacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposed between tendons and bony prominences.
Burse: A purse; also, a vesicle; a pod; a hull.
blast off: to begin ascending from the ground under rocket power; -- of a rocket.
Blindfish: A small fish (Amblyopsis spelæus) destitute of eyes, found in the waters of the Mammoth Cave, in Kentucky. Related fishes from other caves take the same name.
Buttweld: To unite by a butt weld.
Bordelais: Of or pertaining to Bordeaux, in France, or to the district around Bordeaux.
Bromoiodism: Poisoning induced by large doses of bromine and iodine or of their compounds.
Banderilla: A barbed dart carrying a banderole which the banderillero thrusts into the neck or shoulder of the bull in a bullfight.
Bezoar: A calculous concretion found in the intestines of certain ruminant animals (as the wild goat, the gazelle, and the Peruvian llama) formerly regarded as an unfailing antidote for poison, and a certain remedy for eruptive, pestilential, or putrid diseases. Hence: Any antidote or panacea.
Band fish: A small red fish of the genus Cepola; the ribbon fish.
bedground: an area on which a drove of cattle or sheep can sleep for a night.
Benefactress: A woman who confers a benefit.
Baltimore bird: A common bird (Icterus galbula) of eastern and central America and Canada, named after Lord Baltimore, because its colors (black and orange red) are like those of his coat of arms; -- called also golden robin.  It winters in the American tropics.
Boyhood: The state of being a boy; the time during which one is a boy.
Burning: The act of consuming by fire or heat, or of subjecting to the effect of fire or heat; the state of being on fire or excessively heated.
Blare: The harsh noise of a trumpet; a loud and somewhat harsh noise, like the blast of a trumpet; a roar or bellowing.
branched: resembling a fork; divided or separated into two branches; as, long branched hairs on its legs, on which pollen collects.
barnful: The quantity that a barn will hold.
Bosset: A rudimental antler of a young male of the red deer.
Broadseal: To stamp with the broad seal; to make sure; to guarantee or warrant.
Bedclothes: Blankets, sheets, coverlets, etc., for a bed.
Breasthook: A thick piece of timber in the form of a knee, placed across the stem of a ship to strengthen the fore part and unite the bows on each side.
Burgher: A freeman of a burgh or borough, entitled to enjoy the privileges of the place; any inhabitant of a borough.
Bombyx: A genus of moths, which includes the silkworm moth. See Silkworm.
Brideknot: A knot of ribbons worn by a guest at a wedding; a wedding favor.
Bejape: To jape; to laugh at; to deceive.
Blanket mortgage: One that covers a group or class of things or properties instead of one or more things mentioned individually, as where a mortgage secures various debts as a group, or subjects a group or class of different pieces of property to one general lien.
Blackbird: to engage in the slave trade.
boozing: the act of drinking alcoholic beverages to excess.
Batture: An elevated river bed or sea bed.
Baleen: Plates or blades of “whalebone,” from two to twelve feet long, and sometimes a foot wide, which in certain whales (Balænoidea) are attached side by side along the upper jaw, and form a fringelike sieve by which the food is retained in the mouth.
Boat bug: An aquatic hemipterous insect of the genus Notonecta; -- so called from swimming on its back, which gives it the appearance of a little boat. Called also boat fly, boat insect, boatman, and water boatman.
Bedote: To cause to dote; to deceive.
Burion: The red-breasted house sparrow of California (Carpodacus frontalis); -- called also crimson-fronted bullfinch.
Blasphemy: An indignity offered to God in words, writing, or signs; impiously irreverent words or signs addressed to, or used in reference to, God; speaking evil of God; also, the act of claiming the attributes or prerogatives of deity.
Besseya: a genus of North American spring wildflowers.
By-view: A private or selfish view; self-interested aim or purpose.
Bettongia: a genus of marsupials including the jerboa kangaroo, the bettong.
Bamboozle: To deceive by trickery; to cajole by confusing the senses; to hoax; to mystify; to humbug.
backgrounding: The execution of low priority programs while higher priority programs are not using the processing system.
Banana solution: A solution used as a vehicle in applying bronze pigments. In addition to acetote, benzine, and a little pyroxylin, it contains amyl acetate, which gives it the odor of bananas.
Bilin: A name applied to the amorphous or crystalline mass obtained from bile by the action of alcohol and ether. It is composed of a mixture of the sodium salts of the bile acids.
Bitterweed: A species of Ambrosia (Ambrosia artemisiæfolia); Roman worm wood.
Balaustine: The pomegranate tree (Punica granatum).  The bark of the root, the rind of the fruit, and the flowers are used medicinally.
Backworm: A disease of hawks.  See Filanders.
Barrulet: A diminutive of the bar, having one fourth its width.
Broad gauge: A wider distance between the rails than the “standard” gauge of four feet eight inches and a half. See Gauge.
Battery: The act of battering or beating.
Boce: A European fish (Box vulgaris), having a compressed body and bright colors; -- called also box, and bogue.
Bismuthous: Of, or containing, bismuth, when this element has its lower valence.
ballpoint: a pen which has a small metal ball as point of transfer of ink to paper, at the tip of a cylandrical and non-refillable reservoir of ink; -- short for ballpoint pen.
bolograph: a record or recording made by a bolometer.
Bigness: The state or quality of being big; largeness; size; bulk.
bobcat: small lynx (Lynx rufus) of North America.
Branchia: A gill; a respiratory organ for breathing the air contained in water, such as many aquatic and semiaquatic animals have.
black market: the illicit buying and selling of goods, in violation of price controls, rationing, tax laws, prohibition of sale, etc.
Bevel gear: A kind of gear in which the two wheels working together lie in different planes, and have their teeth cut at right angles to the surfaces of two cones whose apices coincide with the point where the axes of the wheels would meet.
Bardic: Of or pertaining to bards, or their poetry.
By-election: An election held by itself, not at the time of a general election.
backpedal: pedal backwards, as on a bicycle.
Brickyard: A place where bricks are made, especially an inclosed place.
Beholdingness: The state of being obliged or beholden.
Braky: Full of brakes; abounding with brambles, shrubs, or ferns; rough; thorny.
Beadlery: Office or jurisdiction of a beadle.
Burnish: The effect of burnishing; gloss; brightness; luster.
Brake: An instrument or machine to break or bruise the woody part of flax or hemp so that it may be separated from the fiber.
black out: to cause to become black, such as a stage, a computer screen, or a city.
Beasthood: State or nature of a beast.
Berrying: A seeking for or gathering of berries, esp. of such as grow wild.
Bob wig: A short wig with bobs or short curls; -- called also bobtail wig.
bennie: a slang name for Benzedrine, a trademark for one brand of amphetamine; -- also used generically for any brand of amphetamine.
Brutality: The quality of being brutal; inhumanity; savageness; pitilessness.
Blotter: One who, or that which, blots; esp. a device for absorbing superfluous ink.
Bull terrier: A breed of short-haired terrier dogs originated in England by crossing the bulldog and the terrier.
Bravado: Boastful and threatening behavior; a boastful menace.
Boardable: That can be boarded, as a ship.
Boisterousness: The state or quality of being boisterous; turbulence; disorder; tumultuousness.
Bibliomaniac: One who has a mania for books.
Bastardy: The state of being a bastard; illegitimacy.
budgerow: A large and commodious, but generally cumbrous and sluggish boat, used for journeys on the Ganges.
Bitts: A frame of two strong timbers fixed perpendicularly in the fore part of a ship, on which to fasten the cables as the ship rides at anchor, or in warping. Other bitts are used for belaying (belaying bitts), for sustaining the windlass (carrick bitts, winch bitts, or windlass bitts), to hold the pawls of the windlass (pawl bitts) etc.
Buccinoid: Resembling the genus Buccinum, or pertaining to the Buccinidæ, a family of marine univalve shells. See Whelk, and Prosobranchiata.
Biannual: Occurring twice a year; half-yearly; semiannual.
beaded: imp. & p. p. of bead, v. t. & i..
Breadcorn: Corn of grain of which bread is made, as wheat, rye, etc.
Begod: To exalt to the dignity of a god; to deify.
Blanchard lathe: A kind of wood-turning lathe for making noncircular and irregular forms, as felloes, gun stocks, lasts, spokes, etc., after a given pattern. The pattern and work rotate on parallel spindles in the same direction with the same speed, and the work is shaped by a rapidly rotating cutter whose position is varied by the pattern acting as a cam upon a follower wheel traversing slowly along the pattern.
Binomial: Consisting of two terms; pertaining to binomials; as, a binomial root.
Bryonin: A bitter principle obtained from the root of the bryony (Bryonia alba and Bryonia dioica).  It is a white, or slightly colored, substance, and is emetic and cathartic.
Bewitch: To gain an ascendency over by charms or incantations; to affect (esp. to injure) by witchcraft or sorcery.
Baroque: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, an artistic style common in the 17th century, characterized by the use of complex and elaborate ornamentation, curved rather than straight lines, and, in music a high degree of embellishment.
Boletus: A genus of fungi having the under side of the pileus or cap composed of a multitude of fine separate tubes. A few are edible, and others very poisonous.
Beteem: To give ; to bestow; to grant; to accord; to consent.
barretter: a resistor inserted into a circuit to compensate for changes (such as those arising from temperature fluctuations); a thermal cymoscope.
Bito: A small scrubby tree (Balanites Ægyptiaca) growing in dry regions of tropical Africa and Asia.
Broad Church: A portion of the Church of England, consisting of persons who claim to hold a position, in respect to doctrine and fellowship, intermediate between the High Church party and the Low Church, or evangelical, party. The term has been applied to other bodies of men holding liberal or comprehensive views of Christian doctrine and fellowship.
Bite: The act of seizing with the teeth or mouth; the act of wounding or separating with the teeth or mouth; a seizure with the teeth or mouth, as of a bait; as, to give anything a hard bite.
Buzzsaw: A circular saw; -- so called from the buzzing it makes when running at full speed.
Battue: The act of beating the woods, bushes, etc., for game.
Bitt: To put round the bitts; as, to bitt the cable, in order to fasten it or to slacken it gradually, which is called veering away.
Bouncing: Stout; plump and healthy; lusty; buxom.
Becoming: That which is becoming or appropriate.
Bromate: To combine or impregnate with bromine; as, bromated camphor.
Bold eagle: an Australian eagle (Aquila audax), which destroys lambs and even the kangaroo.
Boutonni\u00e8re: A bouquet worn in a buttonhole.
Bewildered: Greatly perplexed; as, a bewildered mind.
Bidale: An invitation of friends to drink ale at some poor man's house, and there to contribute in charity for his relief.
Bayman: In the United States navy, a sick-bay nurse; -- now officially designated as hospital apprentice.
Bermudas: a group of islands in the Atlantic off the Carolina coast; British colony; resort.
Bullheaded: Having a head like that of a bull. Fig.: Headstrong; obstinate; dogged.
Broadcloth: A fine smooth-faced woolen cloth for men's garments, usually of double width (i.e., a yard and a half); -- so called in distinction from woolens three quarters of a yard wide.
Bermudan: a native or inhabitant of Bermuda.
Benjamite: A descendant of Benjamin; one of the tribe of Benjamin.
Brasenia: a magnoliid genus; a genus of dicotyledonous flowering plants regarded as the most primitive of extant angiosperms; alternatively, a member of the family Nymphaeaceae.
Bepaint: To paint; to cover or color with, or as with, paint.
bosom: To inclose or carry in the bosom; to keep with care; to take to heart; to cherish.
benzocaine: a chemical substance obtainable as a white crystalline ester (H2N.C6H4.CO.O.C2H5) used as a local anesthetic.  Chemically, it is 4-aminobenzoic acid ethyl ester.
Buy: To negotiate or treat about a purchase.
Bacillus: A variety of bacterium; a microscopic, rod-shaped vegetable organism.
Bur: Any rough or prickly envelope of the seeds of plants, whether a pericarp, a persistent calyx, or an involucre, as of the chestnut and burdock; a seed vessel having hooks or prickles.  Also, any weed which bears burs.
bedsit: a furnished sitting room with sleeping accommodations (and some plumbing).
But: See Butt, v., and Abut, v.
Bun: any of a variety of slightly sweetened or plain raised cakes or bisquits, often having a glazing of sugar and milk on the top crust; as, a hot cross bun.
Bub: To throw out in bubbles; to bubble.
Bug: to annoy; to bother or pester.
Bud: To graft, as a plant with another or into another, by inserting a bud from the one into an opening in the bark of the other, in order to raise, upon the budded stock, fruit different from that which it would naturally bear.
Barbary: The countries on the north coast of Africa from Egypt to the Atlantic.
Butt joint: A joint in which the edges or ends of the pieces united come squarely together instead of overlapping. See 1st Butt, 8.
Banxring: An East Indian insectivorous mammal of the genus Tupaia.
Backside: The hinder part, posteriors, or rump of a person or animal.
Batlet: A short bat for beating clothes in washing them; -- called also batler, batling staff, batting staff.
Biternate: Doubly ternate, as when a petiole has three ternate leaflets.
Bade: A form of the past tense of Bid.
Barbara: The first word in certain mnemonic lines which represent the various forms of the syllogism. It indicates a syllogism whose three propositions are universal affirmatives.
Binominal: Of or pertaining to two names; binomial.
Balancer: One who balances, or uses a balance.
Bohea: Bohea tea, an inferior kind of black tea. See under Tea.
Blunge: To amalgamate and blend; to beat up or mix in water, as clay.
Bonbonni\u00e8re: A small fancy box or dish for bonbons.
Bimastism: The condition of having two mammæ or teats.
Benty: A bounding in bents, or the stalks of coarse, stiff, withered grass; as, benty fields.
Bulger: A driver or a brassy with a convex face.
Brotherhood: The state of being brothers or a brother.
Batrachia: The order of amphibians which includes the frogs and toads; the Anura. Sometimes the word is used in a wider sense as equivalent to Amphibia.
Bromogelatin: Designating or pertaining to, a process of preparing dry plates with an emulsion of bromides and silver nitrate in gelatin.
Bandeau: A narrow band or fillet, as for the hair, part of a headdress, etc.
Bellic: Of or pertaining to war; warlike; martial.
Biglandular: Having two glands, as a plant.
Blancard: A kind of linen cloth made in Normandy, the thread of which is partly blanches before it is woven.
Bellibone: A woman excelling both in beauty and goodness; a fair maid.
Bucking: The act or process of soaking or boiling cloth in an alkaline liquid in the operation of bleaching; also, the liquid used.
beatnik: a member of the Beat Generation; a nonconformist in dress and behavior.
Beseeching: Entreating urgently; imploring; as, a beseeching look.
Banker: One who conducts the business of banking; one who, individually, or as a member of a company, keeps an establishment for the deposit or loan of money, or for traffic in money, bills of exchange, etc.
Bitternut: The swamp hickory (Carya amara). Its thin-shelled nuts are bitter.
Brabble: A broil; a noisy contest; a wrangle.
bombsight: a sighting device in an aircraft for aiming bombs.
budgetary: of or pertaining to a budget; as, budgetary considerations.
Biblicist: One skilled in the knowledge of the Bible; a demonstrator of religious truth by the Scriptures.
Brutish: Pertaining to, or resembling, a brute or brutes; of a cruel, gross, and stupid nature; coarse; unfeeling; unintelligent.
Brutism: The nature or characteristic qualities or actions of a brute; extreme stupidity, or beastly vulgarity.
bellyacher: a person who complains habitually, usually about everyday minor problems.
Brave: To encounter with courage and fortitude; to set at defiance; to defy; to dare.
Bravo: Well done! excellent! an exclamation expressive of applause.
Broth: Liquid in which flesh (and sometimes other substances, as barley or rice) has been boiled; thin or simple soup.
bell-bottomed: having legs that flare at the bottom; -- of trousers.
Beadsnake: A small poisonous snake of North America (Elaps fulvius), banded with yellow, red, and black.
Batidaceae: a natural family coextensive with genus Batis; the saltworts.
Besom: To sweep, as with a besom.
Bagasse: Sugar cane, as it comes crushed from the mill. It is then dried and used as fuel. Also extended to the refuse of beetroot sugar.
Besot: To make sottish; to make dull or stupid; to stupefy; to infatuate.
Brick: To lay or pave with bricks; to surround, line, or construct with bricks.
Belted: Encircled by, or secured with, a belt; as, a belted plaid; girt with a belt, as an honorary distinction; as, a belted knight; a belted earl.
Borneol: A rare variety of camphor, C10H17.OH, resembling ordinary camphor, from which it can be produced by reduction. It is said to occur in the camphor tree of Borneo and Sumatra (Dryobalanops camphora), but the natural borneol is rarely found in European or American commerce, being in great request by the Chinese. Called also Borneo camphor, Malay camphor, and camphol.
Bacchanalianism: The practice of bacchanalians; bacchanals; drunken revelry.
biofeedback: a training program in which a person is given information about physiological processes (heart rate or blood pressure) that is not normally available with the goal of gaining conscious control of them.
Bdelloidea: The order of Annulata which includes the leeches. See Hirudinea.
balneotherapy: The treatment of disease by baths.
Blush: A suffusion of the cheeks or face with red, as from a sense of shame, confusion, or modesty.
boondocks: a remote and undeveloped area; -- sometimes used deprecatingly.
Battuta: The measuring of time by beating.
Barbarian: Of, or pertaining to, or resembling, barbarians; rude; uncivilized; barbarous; as, barbarian governments or nations.
Bignonia: A large genus of American, mostly tropical, climbing shrubs, having compound leaves and showy somewhat tubular flowers.  Bignonia capreolata is the cross vine of the Southern United States.  The trumpet creeper (also called the trumpet vine), with large red tubular flowers, was formerly considered to be of this genus, but is now classified as Campsis radicans.
Begirdle: To surround as with a girdle.
biomedicine: The application of the principles and techniques of the natural sciences, especially biology, to investigate and solve problems in clinical medicine.
Bowel: To take out the bowels of; to eviscerate; to disembowel.
bodikin: Same as bodkin; -- a variant spelling.
Blacklist: To put in a black list as deserving of suspicion, censure, or punishment; esp. to put in a list of persons stigmatized as insolvent or untrustworthy, -- as tradesmen and employers do for mutual protection; as, to blacklist a workman who has been discharged. See Black list, under Black, a.
Bower: A young hawk, when it begins to leave the nest.
Beshroud: To cover with, or as with, a shroud; to screen.
Bleeder: One who, or that which, draws blood.
Bigotedly: In the manner of a bigot.
Bushelage: A duty payable on commodities by the bushel.
Brazil nut: An oily, three-sided nut, the seed of the Bertholletia excelsa; the cream nut.
Billboard: A piece of thick plank, armed with iron plates, and fixed on the bow or fore channels of a vessel, for the bill or fluke of the anchor to rest on.
Boat: To go or row in a boat.
bladdernose: a medium-sized blackish-gray seal (Cystophora cristata) with a large inflatable sac on the head; of Arctic-Atlantic waters.
Bhutan: a principality in the Himalayas northeast of India.
Bocking: A coarse woolen fabric, used for floor cloths, to cover carpets, etc.; -- so called from the town of Bocking, in England, where it was first made.
Blowgun: A tube, as of cane or reed, sometimes twelve feet long, through which an arrow (sometimes poisoned) or other projectile may be impelled by the force of the breath. It is a weapon much used by certain Indians of America and the West Indies; -- called also blowpipe, and blowtube.  See Sumpitan.
Buttonhole: To hold at the button or buttonhole; to detain in conversation to weariness; to bore; as, he buttonholed me a quarter of an hour.
Boring: The act or process of one who, or that which, bores; as, the boring of cannon; the boring of piles and ship timbers by certain marine mollusks.
Bromlife: A carbonate of baryta and lime, intermediate between witherite and strontianite; -- called also alstonite.
Bracelet: An ornamental band or ring, for the wrist or the arm; in modern times, an ornament encircling the wrist, worn by women or girls.
bounded: having the limits or boundaries established.
Bashaw: A Turkish title of honor, now written pasha. See Pasha.
Brewer: One who brews; one whose occupation is to prepare malt liquors.
Binuclear: Having two nuclei; as, binucleate cells.
Brail: To haul up by the brails; -- used with up; as, to brail up a sail.
Blab: One who blabs; a babbler; a telltale.
Breed: A race or variety of men or other animals (or of plants), perpetuating its special or distinctive characteristics by inheritance.
Benzile: A yellowish crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.CO.C6H5, formed from benzoin by the action of oxidizing agents, and consisting of a doubled benzoyl radical.
Browspot: A rounded organ between the eyes of the frog; the interocular gland.
Beden: The Abyssinian or Arabian ibex (Capra Nubiana). It is probably the wild goat of the Bible.
Brazen: To carry through impudently or shamelessly; as, to brazen the matter through.
Bedew: To moisten with dew, or as with dew.
Butane: An inflammable gaseous saturated hydrocarbon, C4H10, of the marsh gas, or paraffin, series.
Blindfold: Having the eyes covered; blinded; having the mental eye darkened. Hence: Heedless; reckless; as, blindfold zeal; blindfold fury.
burned-out: drained of energy or effectiveness; driven to apathy by overwork or prolonged stress; -- of people.
Birdcatcher: One whose employment it is to catch birds; a fowler.
Belay: To lay on or cover; to adorn.
Batule: A springboard in a circus or gymnasium; -- called also batule board.
Binding: The act or process of one who, or that which, binds.
Bric-a brac: Miscellaneous curiosities and works of decorative art, considered collectively.
Blustering: Exhibiting noisy violence, as the wind; stormy; tumultuous.
Biscotin: A confection made of flour, sugar, marmalade, and eggs; a sweet biscuit.
Bickern: An anvil ending in a beak or point (orig. in two beaks); also, the beak or horn itself.
biosystematics: use of data (e. g. cytogenetic or biochemical) to assess taxonomic relations esp within an evolutionary framework.
bobbysoxer: an adolescent girl wearing bobby socks (common in the 1940s); -- sometimes used for any adolescent girl, especially one following the latest youthful fashion .
Boozy: A little intoxicated; fuddled; stupid with liquor; bousy.
Blowze: A ruddy, fat-faced woman; a wench.
Boll: To form a boll or seed vessel; to go to seed.
Blowzy: Coarse and ruddy-faced; fat and ruddy; high colored; frowzy.
Boiled: Dressed or cooked by boiling; subjected to the action of a boiling liquid; as, boiled meat; a boiled dinner; boiled clothes.
Bigha: A measure of land in India, varying from a third of an acre to an acre.
Buttery: An apartment in a house where butter, milk and other provisions are kept.
Bight: A corner, bend, or angle; a hollow; as, the bight of a horse's knee; the bight of an elbow.
Bigamist: One who is guilty of bigamy.
Boiler: A sunken reef; esp., a coral reef on which the sea breaks heavily.
Blindly: Without sight, discernment, or understanding; without thought, investigation, knowledge, or purpose of one's own.
Bandage: To bind, dress, or cover, with a bandage; as, to bandage the eyes.
bell-ringing: playing a set of bells that are (usually) hung in a tower.
Bank-sided: Having sides inclining inwards, as a ship; -- opposed to wall-sided.
Banquette: A raised way or foot bank, running along the inside of a parapet, on which musketeers stand to fire upon the enemy.
Bipectinate: Having two margins toothed like a comb.
Backstay: A rope or stay extending from the masthead to the side of a ship, slanting a little aft, to assist the shrouds in supporting the mast.
Beachy: Having a beach or beaches; formed by a beach or beaches; shingly.
Basque: One of a race, of unknown origin, inhabiting a region on the Bay of Biscay in Spain and France.
Bulls-nose: An external angle when obtuse or rounded.
Bossism: The rule or practices of bosses, esp. political bosses.
Bequote: To quote constantly or with great frequency.
Benghazi: One of the capital cities of Libya.
banding: A strip or stripe of a contrasting color or material.
bourtree: common black-fruited shrub or small tree (Sambucus nigra) of Europe and Asia; -- the fruit is used for wines and jellies.
Balayeuse: A protecting ruffle or frill, as of silk or lace, sewed close to the lower edge of a skirt on the inside.
Brachium: The upper arm; the segment of the fore limb between the shoulder and the elbow.
blue-blind: unable to see the color blue or to distinguish the colors blue and yellow.
bedsitter: a furnished sitting room with sleeping accommodations (and some plumbing).
Baff: To strike; to beat; to make a baff.
Bicipital: Having two heads or origins, as a muscle.
bondable: capable of being fastened or secured with a rope or bond.
bosomed: Having, or resembling, bosom; kept in the bosom; hidden.
Butea: a genus of East Indian trees or shrubs: dhak.
Botch: To mark with, or as with, botches.
Buteo: a genus of broad-winged soaring hawks.
Batty: Belonging to, or resembling, a bat.
Batteler: A student at Oxford who is supplied with provisions from the buttery; formerly, one who paid for nothing but what he called for, answering nearly to a sizar at Cambridge.
bridged-T: a circuit consisting of a T-network with an additional arm bridging the two series arms.
Bedung: To cover with dung, as for manuring; to bedaub or defile, literally or figuratively.
Boroughmonger: One who buys or sells the parliamentary seats of boroughs.
Binder: One who binds; as, a binder of sheaves; one whose trade is to bind; as, a binder of books.
Basilisk: A fabulous serpent, or dragon. The ancients alleged that its hissing would drive away all other serpents, and that its breath, and even its look, was fatal. See Cockatrice.
Bowing: The act or art of managing the bow in playing on stringed instruments.
Brickmaker: One whose occupation is to make bricks.
Bolsa: An exchange for the transaction of business.
Backsaw: A saw (as a tenon saw) whose blade is stiffened by an added metallic back.
Brownian: Pertaining to Dr. Robert Brown, who first demonstrated (about 1827) the commonness of the motion described below.
Bestud: To set or adorn, as with studs or bosses; to set thickly; to stud; as, to bestud with stars.
Basidium: A special oblong or pyriform cell, with slender branches, which bears the spores in that division of fungi called Basidiomycetes, of which the common mushroom is an example.
Bollard: An upright wooden or iron post in a boat or on a dock, used in veering or fastening ropes.
Benzoate: A salt formed by the union of benzoic acid with any salifiable base.
Bombazine: A twilled fabric for dresses, of which the warp is silk, and the weft worsted. Black bombazine has been much used for mourning garments.
Bedtick: A tick or bag made of cloth, used for inclosing the materials of a bed.
braided: adorned with braid; as, his braided collar.
Berretta: A square cap worn by ecclesiastics of the Roman Catholic Church. A cardinal's berretta is scarlet; that worn by other clerics is black, except that a bishop's is lined with green.
Baronet: A dignity or degree of honor next below a baron and above a knight, having precedency of all orders of knights except those of the Garter.  It is the lowest degree of honor that is hereditary. The baronets are commoners.
Boule: A legislative council of elders or chiefs; a senate.
Bulbil: A small or secondary bulb; hence, now almost exclusively: An aërial bulb or deciduous bud, produced in the leaf axils, as in the tiger lily, or relpacing the flowers, as in some onions, and capable, when separated, of propagating the plant; -- called also bulblet and brood bud.
blaring: harshly or unpleasantly loud (in sound intensity); -- used mostly of electronic entertainment devices, such as TV, radio, or phonograph.
Brightness: The quality or state of being bright; splendor; luster; brilliancy; clearness.
Biograph: An animated picture machine for screen projection; a cinematograph.
Block: To obstruct so as to prevent passage or progress; to prevent passage from, through, or into, by obstructing the way; -- used both of persons and things; -- often followed by up; as, to block up a road or harbor; to block an entrance.
Bell pepper: A species of Capsicum, or Guinea pepper (Capsicum annuum).  It is the red pepper of the gardens.
Biliteralism: The property or state of being biliteral.
Blusterer: One who, or that which, blusters; a noisy swaggerer.
Bewit: A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to a hawk's legs.
bootlicker: someone who humbles himself as a sign of respect; who behaves as he had no self-respect.
Bewig: To cover (the head) with a wig.
Backbiter: One who backbites; a secret calumniator or detractor.
Bumkin: A projecting beam or boom; as: (a) One projecting from each bow of a vessel, to haul the fore tack to, called a tack bumpkin. (b) One from each quarter, for the main-brace blocks, and called brace bumpkin. (c) A small outrigger over the stern of a boat, to extend the mizzen.
Barranca: A ravine caused by heavy rains or a watercourse.
Burbot: A fresh-water fish of the genus Lota, having on the nose two very small barbels, and a larger one on the chin.
Bavaroy: A kind of cloak or surtout.
Bossy: A cow or calf; -- familiarly so called.
Bevel: To deviate or incline from an angle of 90°, as a surface; to slant.
Beamed: Furnished with beams, as the head of a stag.
Beefeater: One who eats beef; hence, a large, fleshy person.
Burghership: The state or privileges of a burgher.
Bever: To take a light repast between meals.
Bearherd: A man who tends a bear.
Bluntness: Want of edge or point; dullness; obtuseness; lack of sharpness.
Barded: Accoutered with defensive armor; -- said of a horse.
Ballet: An artistic dance performed as a theatrical entertainment, or an interlude, by a number of persons, usually women. Sometimes, a scene accompanied by pantomime and dancing.
Beryl: A mineral of great hardness, and, when transparent, of much beauty. It occurs in hexagonal prisms, commonly of a green or bluish green color, but also yellow, pink, and white. It is a silicate of aluminum and beryllium. The aquamarine is a transparent, sea-green variety used as a gem. The emerald is another variety highly prized in jewelry, and distinguished by its deep color, which is probably due to the presence of a little oxide of chromium.
Brilliantine: An oily composition used to make the hair manageable and glossy.
Bihydroguret: A compound of two atoms of hydrogen with some other substance.
Bachelordom: The state of bachelorhood; the whole body of bachelors.
banjo: A stringed musical instrument having a head and neck like the guitar, and a circular body like a tambourine.  It has five strings, and is played with the fingers and hands.
Buckthorn: A genus (Rhamnus) of shrubs or trees. The shorter branches of some species terminate in long spines or thorns. See Rhamnus.
Benevolent: Having a disposition to do good; possessing or manifesting love to mankind, and a desire to promote their prosperity and happiness; disposed to give to good objects; kind; charitable.
Blockhead: A stupid fellow; a dolt; a person deficient in understanding.
Bathygraphic: Descriptive of the ocean depth; as, a bathygraphic chart.
Bloodletting: The act or process of letting blood or bleeding, as by opening a vein or artery, or by cupping or leeches; -- esp. applied to venesection.
Blackband: An earthy carbonate of iron containing considerable carbonaceous matter; -- valuable as an iron ore.
bureaucratism: nonelective government officials; same as bureaucracy.
Bogy: A specter; a hobgoblin; a bugbear.
Ballistics: The science or art of hurling missile weapons by the use of an engine.
Barmaid: A girl or woman who attends the customers of a bar, as in a tavern or beershop.
burn out: To burn till the fuel is exhausted; as, when the candle burned out the room was totally dark; the firefighters couldn't control the oil tank fire and had to let it burn out by itself.
Brevetcy: The rank or condition of a brevet officer.
Blackbirding: The kidnaping of negroes or Polynesians to be sold as slaves.
Bolting: A sifting, as of flour or meal.
Balachong: A condiment formed of small fishes or shrimps, pounded up with salt and spices, and then dried. It is much esteemed in China.
bellbottoms: trousers with legs that flare; commonly worn as part of a sailor's uniform; -- such absurdly wide hems were also fashionable in the 1960s.
Blacklead: To coat or to polish with black lead (graphite).
BM: an abbreviation for bowel movement; -- used as an informal euphemism, especially in hospitals.
bradykinin: a hypotensive tissue hormone (C50H73N15O11) which acts on smooth muscle, dilates peripheral vessels and increases capillary permeability.  It is formed locally in injured tissue and is believed to play a role in the inflammatory process.  It is a nonapeptide with the sequence: Arg-Pro-Pro-Gly-Phe-Ser-Pro-Phe-Arg.
bottlebrush: a cylindrical brush on a thin shaft that is used to clean bottles.
better-off: being in a more prosperous condition.
Berate: To rate or chide vehemently; to scold.
Battle range: The range within which the fire of small arms is very destructive. With the magazine rifle, this is six hundred yards.
Basommatophora: A group of Pulmonifera having the eyes at the base of the tentacles, including the common pond snails.
body shop: an establishment where the frame or outer body of a vehicle may be repaired or painted; -- contrasted with a mechanic, who repairs the motor and other working components.
Bepommel: To pommel; to beat, as with a stick; figuratively, to assail or criticise in conversation, or in writing.
Bouts-rim\u00e9s: Words that rhyme, proposed as the ends of verses, to be filled out by the ingenuity of the person to whom they are offered.
Benzine: A liquid consisting mainly of the lighter and more volatile hydrocarbons of petroleum or kerosene oil, used as a solvent and for cleansing soiled fabrics; -- called also petroleum spirit, petroleum benzine. Varieties or similar products are gasoline, naphtha, rhigolene, ligroin, etc.
Beau monde: The fashionable world; people of fashion and gayety.
Broken-hearted: Having the spirits depressed or crushed by grief or despair.
Blesbok: A South African antelope (Alcelaphus albifrons), having a large white spot on the forehead.
Bloody sweat: A sweat accompanied by a discharge of blood; a disease, called sweating sickness, formerly prevalent in England and other countries.
Balaenidae: a family comprising the right whales.
Bondar: A small quadruped of Bengal (Paradoxurus bondar), allied to the genet; -- called also musk cat.
bentgrass: grass for pastures and lawns esp bowling and putting greens.
Briskness: Liveliness; vigor in action; quickness; gayety; vivacity; effervescence.
Bo: An exclamation used to startle or frighten.
Bangladeshi: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Bangladesh.
Boomorah: A small West African chevrotain (Hyæmoschus aquaticus), resembling the musk deer.
Bierbalk: A church road (e. g., a path across fields) for funerals.
Bereavement: The state of being bereaved; deprivation; esp., the loss of a relative by death.
Bandore: A musical stringed instrument, similar in form to a guitar; a pandore.  It is now obsolete, but see  bandura.
By-bidder: One who bids at an auction in behalf of the auctioneer or owner, for the purpose of running up the price of articles.
Booty: That which is seized by violence or obtained by robbery, especially collective spoil taken in war; plunder; pillage.
Boots: A servant at a hotel or elsewhere, who cleans and blacks the boots and shoes.
Booth: A house or shed built of boards, boughs, or other slight materials, for temporary occupation.
Boothale: To forage for booty; to plunder.
Bedeguar: A gall produced on rosebushes, esp. on the sweetbrier or eglantine, by a puncture from the ovipositor of a gallfly (Rhodites rosæ). It was once supposed to have medicinal properties.
Bacharach: A kind of wine made at Bacharach on the Rhine.
Bungler: A clumsy, awkward workman; one who bungles.
Bedkey: An instrument for tightening the parts of a bedstead.
Bicorporate: Double-bodied, as a lion having one head and two bodies.
Black death: A pestilence which ravaged Europe and Asia in the fourteenth century.
brooding: the process of sitting on eggs so as to hatch them by the warmth of the body; -- mostly used of birds.
Boeotia: a district of ancient Greece northwest of Athens.
Black Hamburg: A sweet and juicy variety of European grape, of a dark purplish black color, much grown under glass in northern latitudes.
beano: a game in which numbered balls are drawn and random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards.
Balancement: The act or result of balancing or adjusting; equipoise; even adjustment of forces.
Bonitary: Beneficial, as opposed to statutory or civil; as, bonitary dominion of land.
Breechblock: The movable piece which closes the breech of a breech-loading firearm, and resists the backward force of the discharge. It is withdrawn for the insertion of a cartridge, and closed again before the gun is fired.
Bargainer: One who makes a bargain; -- sometimes in the sense of bargainor.
Burhinus: type genus of the Burhinidae, comprising the stone curlews.
Bold-faced: Somewhat impudent; lacking modesty; as, a bold-faced woman.
Buttons: A boy servant, or page, -- in allusion to the buttons on his livery.
Buttony: Ornamented with a large number of buttons.
Bargainee: The party to a contract who receives, or agrees to receive, the property sold.
Bell metal: A hard alloy or bronze, consisting usually of about three parts of copper to one of tin; -- used for making bells.
Balderdash: To mix or adulterate, as liquors.
Banstickle: A small fish, the three-spined stickleback.
Branchy: Full of branches; having wide-spreading branches; consisting of branches.
Brachydome: A dome parallel to the shorter lateral axis. See Dome.
biota: all the plant and animal life of a particular region.
blowhard: a very boastful and talkative person.
Babylonic: Pertaining to Babylon, or made there; as, Babylonic garments, carpets, or hangings.
Brontometer: An instrument for noting or recording phenomena attendant on thunderstorms.
Bunder: A boat or raft used in the East Indies in the landing of passengers and goods.
Beseechment: The act of beseeching or entreating earnestly.
Backs: Among leather dealers, the thickest and stoutest tanned hides.
Bottomry: A contract in the nature of a mortgage, by which the owner of a ship, or the master as his agent, hypothecates and binds the ship (and sometimes the accruing freight) as security for the repayment of money advanced or lent for the use of the ship, if she terminates her voyage successfully. If the ship is lost by perils of the sea, the lender loses the money; but if the ship arrives safe, he is to receive the money lent, with the interest or premium stipulated, although it may, and usually does, exceed the legal rate of interest. See Hypothecation.
brassavola: any of various tropical American orchids with usually solitary fleshy leaves and showy white to green nocturnally fragrant blossoms solitary or in racemes of up to 7.
Brachystochrone: A curve, in which a body, starting from a given point, and descending solely by the force of gravity, will reach another given point in a shorter time than it could by any other path. This curve of quickest descent, as it is sometimes called, is, in a vacuum, the same as the cycloid.
Blocage: The roughest and cheapest sort of rubblework, in masonry.
Bregma: The point of junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures of the skull.
Balneology: A treatise on baths; the science of bathing.
Bisector: One who, or that which, bisects; esp. (Geom.) a straight line which bisects an angle.
bonnet head: small harmless hammerhead shark (Sphyrna tiburio) of the southern United States and West Indies, having a spade-shaped head; abundant in bays and estuaries.
Barton: The demesne lands of a manor; also, the manor itself.
Bolection: A projecting molding round a panel. Same as Bilection.
Bricole: A kind of traces with hooks and rings, with which men drag and maneuver guns where horses can not be used.
Bovini: a term essentially coextensive with the genus Bos; -- it is not used technically.
Boza: An acidulated fermented drink of the Arabs and Egyptians, made from millet seed and various astringent substances; also, an intoxicating beverage made from hemp seed, darnel meal, and water.
Braiding: The act of making or using braids.
birdbath: an ornamental basin (usually in a garden) for birds to bathe in.
Beetle: To extend over and beyond the base or support; to overhang; to jut.
Bareheaded: Having the head uncovered; as, a bareheaded girl.
Bark louse: An insect of the family Coccidæ, which infests the bark of trees and vines.
beebalm: a perennial herb (Monarda fistulosa) of North America.
Ballast: To steady, as a vessel, by putting heavy substances in the hold.
Beard: To take by the beard; to seize, pluck, or pull the beard of (a man), in anger or contempt.
begrudging: being given reluctantly or with displeasure.
brut: very dry; -- used of wine or champagne.
buyout: the acquisition of ownership of a company by purchasing a controlling percentage of its stock.
Brabbler: A clamorous, quarrelsome, noisy fellow; a wrangler.
Bloat: To dry (herrings) in smoke. See Blote.
Backstitch: To sew with backstitches; as, to backstitch a seam.
Blacksmith: A smith who works in iron with a forge, and makes iron utensils, horseshoes, etc.
Barebone: A very lean person; one whose bones show through the skin.
Bell: To call or bellow, as the deer in rutting time; to make a bellowing sound; to roar.
Bethabara wood: A highly elastic wood, used for fishing rods, etc. The tree is unknown, but it is thought to be East Indian.
Blue-skylaw: A law enacted to provide for the regulation and supervision of investment companies in order to protect the public against companies that do not intend to do a fair and honest business and that offer investments that do not promise a fair return; -- so called because the promises made by some investment companies are as boundless or alluring as the blue sky, or, perhaps, because designed to clear away the clouds and fogs from the simple investor's horizon.
Bewitching: Having power to bewitch or fascinate; enchanting; captivating; charming.
Belt: To encircle with, or as with, a belt; to encompass; to surround.
Blasphemous: Speaking or writing blasphemy; uttering or exhibiting anything impiously irreverent; profane; as, a blasphemous person; containing blasphemy; as, a blasphemous book; a blasphemous caricature.
Bathyergus: a genus consisting of the mole rats.
briarwood: wood from the hard woody root of the briar Erica arborea; used to make tobacco pipes.
Bahaism: The religious tenets or practices of the Bahais.
Baccate: Pulpy throughout, like a berry; -- said of fruits.
Baking: The act or process of cooking in an oven, or of drying and hardening by heat or cold.
Bed steps: Steps for mounting a bed of unusual height.
bonding: the process of fastening firmly together.
Bouillon: A nutritious liquid food made by boiling beef, or other meat, in water; a clear soup or broth.
Burier: One who, or that which, buries.
Belligerent: A nation or state recognized as carrying on war; a person engaged in warfare.
barrelful: The quantity that a barrel (of any size) will hold.
Balsam: To treat or anoint with balsam; to relieve, as with balsam; to render balsamic.
Bitch: to complain in a whining or grumbling manner; to gripe.
Baneful: Having poisonous qualities; deadly; destructive; injurious; noxious; pernicious.
Barreled: Having a barrel; -- used in composition; as, a double-barreled gun.
Based: Having a base, or having as a base; supported; as, broad-based.
Bankrupt: To make bankrupt; to bring financial ruin upon; to impoverish.
Bologna: A city of Italy which has given its name to various objects.
Bumblebee: A large bee of the genus Bombus, sometimes called humblebee; -- so named from its sound.
Buckshot: A coarse leaden shot, larger than swan shot, used in hunting deer and large game.
Brainsick: Disordered in the understanding; giddy; thoughtless.
Boating: The act or practice of rowing or sailing, esp. as an amusement; carriage in boats.
Bureau: Originally, a desk or writing table with drawers for papers.
Basilar: Relating to, or situated at, the base.
Blood-boltered: Having the hair matted with clotted blood.
Belvedere: A small building, or a part of a building, more or less open, constructed in a place commanding a fine prospect.
blended: combined or mixed together so that the constituent parts are indistinguishable.  Antonym of unblended.
bullet-proof: Capable of resisting the force of a bullet; resistant to penetration by a bullet; armored; as, a bulletproof vest; a bulletproof window.
Bigotry: The state of mind of a bigot; obstinate and unreasoning attachment of one's own belief and opinions, with narrow-minded intolerance of beliefs opposed to them.
Bungle: A clumsy or awkward performance; a botch; a gross blunder.
Blackball: To vote against, by putting a black ball into a ballot box; to reject or exclude, as by voting against with black balls; to ostracize.
Boer: A colonist or farmer in South Africa of Dutch descent.
Backstaff: An instrument formerly used for taking the altitude of the heavenly bodies, but now superseded by the quadrant and sextant; -- so called because the observer turned his back to the body observed.
Besmear: To smear with any viscous, glutinous matter; to bedaub; to soil.
Biodynamic: Of or pertaining to biodynamics, or the doctrine of vital forces or energy.
batholithic: Of or pertaining to a batholith.
Bion: The physiological individual, characterized by definiteness and independence of function, in distinction from the morphological individual or morphon.
Brief: To make an abstract or abridgment of; to shorten; as, to brief pleadings.
Bedbug: A wingless, bloodsucking, hemipterous insect (Cimex Lectularius), sometimes infesting houses and especially beds.  See Illustration in Appendix.
Breasting: The curved channel in which a breast wheel turns. It is closely adapted to the curve of the wheel through about a quarter of its circumference, and prevents the escape of the water until it has spent its force upon the wheel. See Breast wheel.
buffeted: struck repeatedly; -- used especially of impact from winds, and sometimes metaphorically; as, buffeted by criticism.
Burghbrech: The offense of violating the pledge given by every inhabitant of a tithing to keep the peace; breach of the peace.
Behemoth: An animal, probably the hippopotamus, described in Job xl. 15-24.
broadtail: the fur of a very young karakul lamb.
Bushhammer: To dress with bushhammer; as, to bushhammer a block of granite.
Bloodsucker: Any animal that sucks blood; esp., the leech (Hirudo medicinalis), and related species.
Bluenose: A nickname for a Nova Scotian; also, a Nova Scotian ship (called also Blue"nos`er (&unr_;)); a Nova Scotian potato, etc.
Basset hound: A small kind of hound with a long body and short legs, used as an earth dog.
Bathing: Act of taking a bath or baths.
Bewrayer: One who, or that which, bewrays; a revealer.
Binary: That which is constituted of two figures, things, or parts; two; duality.
Bacillary: Of or pertaining to little rods; rod-shaped.
black-and-white: depicted only in black and white colors, or in shades of gray; also called monochromatic and monochrome; -- of images.  Opposite of color or in color, and contrasting with polychrome technicolor three-color; as, a black-and-white TV; black-and-white film; the movie “Schindler's List” was shot in black and white.
Brisket: That part of the breast of an animal which extends from the fore legs back beneath the ribs; also applied to the fore part of a horse, from the shoulders to the bottom of the chest.
Belgian block: A nearly cubical block of some tough stone, esp. granite, used as a material for street pavements. Its usual diameter is 5 to 7 inches.
