Brunonian: Pertaining to, or invented by, Brown; -- a term applied to a system of medicine promulgated in the 18th century by John Brown, of Scotland, the fundamental doctrine of which was, that life is a state of excitation produced by the normal action of external agents upon the body, and that disease consists in excess or deficiency of excitation.
Brown race: The Malay or Polynesian race; -- loosely so called.
brushwork: an artist's distinctive technique of applying paint with a brush.
Bronchial: Belonging to the bronchi and their ramifications in the lungs.
bacterize: to subject to the action of bacteria.
Bedchair: A chair with adjustable back, for the sick, to support them while sitting up in bed.
Besetter: One who, or that which, besets.
Bemaul: To maul or beat severely; to bruise.
Blizzard: A gale of piercingly cold wind, usually accompanied with fine and blinding snow; a furious blast.
Barbicanage: Money paid for the support of a barbican.
Botryogen: A hydrous sulphate of iron of a deep red color. It often occurs in botryoidal form.
Bewake: To keep watch over; to keep awake.
Bulkhead: A partition in a vessel, to separate apartments on the same deck.
booklouse: a minute wingless psocopterous insect (Liposcelis divinatorius) injurious to books and papers.
Bridoon: The snaffle and rein of a military bridle, which acts independently of the bit, at the pleasure of the rider. It is used in connection with a curb bit, which has its own rein.
Brogan: A stout, coarse shoe; a brogue.
burnup: the amount of fuel used up (as in a nuclear reactor).
Breathless: Spent with labor or violent action; out of breath.
Bicallose: Having two callosities or hard spots.
bonemeal: ground bones, used as a fertilizer or as a component in animal feed; -- it is high in phosphate content.
Barometry: The art or process of making barometrical measurements.
Bister: A dark brown pigment extracted from the soot of wood.
Butlerage: A duty of two shillings on every tun of wine imported into England by merchant strangers; -- so called because paid to the king's butler for the king.
Brioche: A light sweet pastry (cake, bun or roll) made with flour, butter, yeast, and eggs.
Befringe: To furnish with a fringe; to form a fringe upon; to adorn as with fringe.
Bacciform: Having the form of a berry.
Bootee: A half boot or short boot.
Booted: Wearing boots, especially boots with long tops, as for riding; as, a booted squire.
Boottree: An instrument to stretch and widen the leg of a boot, consisting of two pieces, together shaped like a leg, between which, when put into the boot, a wedge is driven.
Biliverdin: A green pigment present in the bile, formed from bilirubin by oxidation.
Breastsummer: A summer or girder extending across a building flush with, and supporting, the upper part of a front or external wall; a long lintel; a girder; -- used principally above shop windows.
Birr: A whirring sound, as of a spinning wheel.
Birt: A fish of the turbot kind; the brill.
Brassart: Armor for the arm; -- generally used for the whole arm from the shoulder to the wrist, and consisting, in the 15th and 16th centuries, of many parts.
Beggarly: In an indigent, mean, or despicable manner; in the manner of a beggar.
Brindled: Having dark streaks or spots on a gray or tawny ground; brinded.
Bradypodidae: a natural family comprising the true sloths.
Billard: An English fish, allied to the cod; the coalfish.
banknote: A promissory note issued by a bank or banking company, payable to the bearer on demand.  See also sense 4.
Bluefin: A species of whitefish (Coregonus nigripinnis) found in Lake Michigan.
biomedical: Pertaining to the biological and physiological aspects of medicine.
beady-eyed: having eyes that gleam with malice.
bumbling: not skillful in physical movement especially with the hands; as, a bumbling mechanic.
Bisaccate: Having two little bags, sacs, or pouches.
By-wash: The outlet from a dam or reservoir; also, a cut to divert the flow of water.
Barracoon: A slave warehouse, or an inclosure where slaves are quartered temporarily.
barbasco: a West Indian shrub or small tree (Jacquinia keyensis) having leathery saponaceous leaves and extremely hard wood.
Black Monday: Easter Monday, so called from the severity of that day in 1360, which was so unusual that many of Edward III.'s soldiers, then before Paris, died from the cold.
blacktop: a bituminous material used for providing a smooth paving to a road.
Bastardize: To make or prove to be a bastard; to stigmatize as a bastard; to declare or decide legally to be illegitimate.
bonobo: an anthropoid ape (Pan paniscus), resembling but smaller than the common chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes); -- called also pygmy chimpanzee.  It is found in the forests of Zaire.
Bearing cloth: A cloth with which a child is covered when carried to be baptized.
Bipolar: Doubly polar; having two poles; as, a bipolar cell or corpuscle.
Bocardo: A form of syllogism of which the first and third propositions are particular negatives, and the middle term a universal affirmative.
Bubble: To rise in bubbles, as liquids when boiling or agitated; to contain bubbles.
Beglerbeg: The governor of a province of the Ottoman empire, next in dignity to the grand vizier.
Blinker: One who, or that which, blinks.
breadbox: a container used to store breads or cake, to keep them fresh.
billfold: A small, thin, flat container, usually made of leather or imitation leather, having a pocket of a size just large enough to hold paper currency and folded over once to fit in the pocket of one's clothing; it is a type of wallet, but having fewer compartments than the typical wallet.
Baby: To treat like a young child; to keep dependent; to humor; to fondle.
Brokerage: The business or employment of a broker.
Bequest: To bequeath, or leave as a legacy.
Buckwheat: A plant (Fagopyrum esculentum) of the Polygonum family, the seed of which is used for food.
broker-dealer: a financial specialist who trades for his own account and so acts both as a broker and principal.
Bespurt: To spurt on or over; to asperse.
Brahmanic: Of or pertaining to the Brahmans or to their doctrines and worship.
Big-bellied: Having a great belly; as, a big-bellied man or flagon; advanced in pregnancy.
Baldness: The state or condition of being bald; as, baldness of the head; baldness of style.
boondoggle: to do useless, wasteful, or trivial work.
Belfast: the capital of Northern Ireland; -- the center of Irish Protestantism.
Beblood: To make bloody; to stain with blood.
baby-faced: having a face resembling that of a baby
Bestride: To stand or sit with anything between the legs, or with the legs astride; to stand over
brasserie: a small restaurant serving beer and wine as well as food; usually cheap.
Balaeniceps: type genus of the Balaenicipitidae: shoebills.
Borage: A mucilaginous plant of the genus Borago (B. officinalis), which is used, esp. in France, as a demulcent and diaphoretic.
Bedabble: To dabble; to sprinkle or wet.
Backset: To plow again, in the fall; -- said of prairie land broken up in the spring.
Blastment: A sudden stroke or injury produced by some destructive cause.
Boomerang: A very singular missile weapon used by the natives of Australia and in some parts of India. It is usually a curved stick of hard wood, from twenty to thirty inches in length, from two to three inches wide, and half or three quarters of an inch thick. When thrown from the hand with a quick rotary motion, it describes very remarkable curves, according to the shape of the instrument and the manner of throwing it, often moving nearly horizontally a long distance, then curving upward to a considerable height, and finally taking a retrograde direction, so as to fall near the place from which it was thrown, or even far in the rear of it.
Bellow: A loud resounding outcry or noise, as of an enraged bull; a roar.
burrfish: any of several fishes having rigid flattened spines.
blin: a thin buckwheat pancake made with yeast and usually filled with sour cream and folded over.  See also blini.
blip: a spot of light on a radar screen, showing the  position of a reflecting surface, such as an airplane or ship.
Bogsucker: The American woodcock; -- so called from its feeding among the bogs.
By-blow: A side or incidental blow; an accidental blow.
Bead proof: Among distillers, a certain degree of strength in alcoholic liquor, as formerly ascertained by the floating or sinking of glass globules of different specific gravities thrown into it; now ascertained by more accurate meters.
bogbean: a perennial plant of Europe and America (Menyanthes trifoliata) having racemes of white or purplish flowers and intensely bitter trifoliate leaves; often rooting at the water margin and spreading across the surface; -- called also bog myrtle, water shamrock and marsh trefoil.
Barology: The science of weight or gravity.
Breccia: A rock composed of angular fragments either of the same mineral or of different minerals, etc., united by a cement, and commonly presenting a variety of colors.
bagel: a glazed leavened doughnut-shaped roll with a hard crust.
Bunodonta: A division of the herbivorous mammals including the hogs and hippopotami; -- so called because the teeth are tuberculated.
borshch: a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.
Brocade: Silk stuff, woven with gold and silver threads, or ornamented with raised flowers, foliage, etc.; -- also applied to other stuffs thus wrought and enriched.
Ballooning spider: A spider which has the habit of rising into the air.  Many kinds (esp. species of Lycosa) do this while young by ejecting threads of silk until the force of the wind upon them carries the spider aloft.
Biconvex: Convex on both sides; as, a biconvex lens.
Bent: A reedlike grass; a stalk of stiff, coarse grass.
Bene: A hoglike mammal of New Guinea (Porcula papuensis).
Biform: Having two forms, bodies, or shapes.
Besit: To suit; to fit; to become.
bulging: curving or bulging outward.  Opposite of concave.
butene: any of three isomeric singly unsaturated hydrocarbons C4H8; all are used in making synthetic rubbers; -- called also butylene.
Barbarous: Being in the state of a barbarian; uncivilized; rude; peopled with barbarians; as, a barbarous people; a barbarous country.
Bengali: Of or pertaining to the Bengali language; as, Bengali poetry.
Baccara: A French game of cards, played by a banker and punters.
Baccare: Stand back! give place! -- a cant word of the Elizabethan writers, probably in ridicule of some person who pretended to a knowledge of Latin which he did not possess.
Burrel fly: The botfly or gadfly of cattle (Hypoderma bovis). See Gadfly.
Beath: To bathe; also, to dry or heat, as unseasoned wood.
Babul: Any one of several species of Acacia, esp. Acacia Arabica, which yelds a gum used as a substitute for true gum arabic.
bunsen: same as bunsen burner; a gas burner used in laboratories; has an air valve to regulate the mixture of gas and air.
Bodhisat: One who has reached the highest degree of saintship, so that in his next incarnation he will be a Buddha, or savior of the world.
Bractlet: A bract on the stalk of a single flower, which is itself on a main stalk that support several flowers.
Busy: To make or keep busy; to employ; to engage or keep engaged; to occupy; as, to busy one's self with books.
bust-up: a serious quarrel (especially one that ends a friendship).
Bruneian: of or pertaining to Brunei; as, Bruneian oil production.
bacteriophage: a virus which infects bacteria; -- also colloquially called phage in laboratory jargon.
Ballad: To make mention of in ballads.
Bernardine: Of or pertaining to St. Bernard of Clairvaux, or to the Cistercian monks.
Bidigitate: Having two fingers or fingerlike projections.
Benzal: A compound radical, C6H5.CH=, of the aromatic series, related to benzyl and benzoyl; -- used adjectively or in combination.
Bittering: A bitter compound used in adulterating beer; bittern.
Blancmange: A preparation for desserts, etc., made from isinglass, sea moss, cornstarch, or other gelatinous or starchy substance, with mild, usually sweetened and flavored, and shaped in a mold.
Bering Sea Controversy: A controversy (1886 -- 93) between Great Britain and the United States as to the right of Canadians not licensed by the United States to carry on seal fishing in the Bering Sea, over which the United States claimed jurisdiction as a mare clausum. A court of arbitration, meeting in Paris in 1893, decided against the claim of the United States, but established regulations for the preservation of the fur seal.
Bulwark: To fortify with, or as with, a rampart or wall; to secure by fortification; to protect.
Bewitchment: The act of bewitching, or the state of being bewitched.
Blebby: Containing blebs, or characterized by blebs; as, blebby glass.
Beta rays: a form of ionizing radiation emitted by radioactive substances (such as radium), more penetrating than alpha rays, and consisting of negatively charged electrons. The electrons are the same kind of particle as those of cathode rays, but have much higher velocities (about 35,000 to 180,000 miles per second).  They are readily deflected by a magnetic or electric field.
Bell-mouthed: Expanding at the mouth; as, a bell-mouthed gun.
Bobstay: A rope or chain to confine the bowsprit of a ship downward to the stem or cutwater; -- usually in the pl.
bronc: an unbroken or imperfectly broken mustang.
Bump: The noise made by the bittern.
Betrothal: The act of betrothing, or the fact of being betrothed; a mutual promise, engagement, or contract for a future marriage between the persons betrothed; betrothment; affiance.
Begrimer: One who, or that which, begrimes.
Bewildering: Causing bewilderment or great perplexity; as, bewildering difficulties.
Boundary: That which indicates or fixes a limit or extent, or marks a bound, as of a territory; a bounding or separating line; a real or imaginary limit.
Beleave: To leave or to be left.
Bewilder: To lead into perplexity or confusion, as for lack of a plain path; to perplex with mazes; or in general, to perplex or confuse greatly.
Broad-leaved: Having broad, or relatively broad, leaves, in contrast to needlelike or scalelike leaves.
Bambocciade: A representation of a grotesque scene from common or rustic life.
Backhouse: A building behind the main building.
Begoniaceae: a natural family of monoecious succulent herbs or shrubs of tropical and warm regions especially America.
Bellerophon: A genus of fossil univalve shells, believed to belong to the Heteropoda, peculiar to the Paleozoic age.
bottlefeed: to feed with a bottle; -- of infants or baby animals.
Besmirch: To smirch or soil; to discolor; to obscure. Hence: To dishonor; to sully.
Baobab: A gigantic African tree (Adansonia digitata), also naturalized in India. See Adansonia.
Balefulness: The quality or state of being baleful.
bedder: an ornamental plant suitable for planting in a flowerbed.
Bielid: See Andromede and cf. Biela's comet.
Benzene: A volatile, very inflammable liquid, C6H6, contained in the naphtha produced by the destructive distillation of coal, from which it is separated by fractional distillation. The name is sometimes applied also to the impure commercial product or benzole, and also, but rarely, to a similar mixed product of petroleum.
Benzonaphthol: A white crystalline powder used as an intestinal antiseptic; beta-naphthol benzoate.
Bristletail: An insect of the genera Lepisma, Campodea, etc., belonging to the Thysanura.
Bivector: A term made up of the two parts &unr_; + &unr_;1 &unr_;-1, where &unr_; and &unr_;1  are vectors.
Bangle: An ornamental circlet, of glass, gold, silver, or other material, worn mostly by women, upon the wrist or ankle; a ring bracelet.  It differs from other bracelets in being rigid and not articulated, in contrast to bracelets made of links.
Baculite: A cephalopod of the extinct genus Baculites, found fossil in the Cretaceous rocks. It is like an uncoiled ammonite.
Bontebok: The pied antelope of South Africa (Alcelaphus pygarga). Its face and rump are white. Called also nunni.
Bunkbed: A type of multiple bed in which the individual beds are arranged one above the other.  It is used to save space in crowded quarters.
Beguilement: The act of beguiling, or the state of being beguiled.
Bushiness: The condition or quality of being bushy.
Brazos: a North American river, flowing into the Gulf of Mexico.
Billyboy: A flat-bottomed river barge or coasting vessel.
Bombylious: Buzzing, like a bumblebee; as, the bombylious noise of the horse fly.
Behalf: Advantage; favor; stead; benefit; interest; profit; support; defense; vindication.
Bloody hand: A hand stained with the blood of a deer, which, in the old forest laws of England, was sufficient evidence of a man's trespass in the forest against venison.
Bailment: The action of bailing a person accused.
Baby farm: A place where the nourishment and care of babies are offered for hire.
Bridge-ward: A bridge keeper; a warden or a guard for a bridge.
Bonasus: The aurochs or European bison. See Aurochs.
Bonder: A freeholder on a small scale.
Bestiality: The state or quality of being bestial.
Black-jack: A name given by English miners to sphalerite, or zinc blende; -- called also false galena. See Blende.
Bultow: A trawl; a boulter; the mode of fishing with a boulter or spiller.
Bonded: Placed under, or covered by, a bond, as for the payment of duties, or for conformity to certain regulations.
biologism: use of biological principles in explaining human behavior, especially social behavior.
Bottom fermentation: A slow alcoholic fermentation during which the yeast cells collect at the bottom of the fermenting liquid. It takes place at a temperature of 4° - 10° C. (39° - 50°F.). It is used in making lager beer and wines of low alcohol content but fine bouquet.
backroom: the meeting place of a group of leaders who make their decisions via private negotiations.
Bertillon system: A system for the identification of persons by a physical description based upon anthropometric measurements, notes of markings, deformities, color, impression of thumb lines, etc.
Bescumber: To discharge ordure or dung upon.
Brevipennate: Short-winged; -- applied to birds which can not fly, owing to their short wings, as the ostrich, cassowary, and emu.
Barwood: A red wood of a leguminous tree (Baphia nitida), from Angola and the Gabon in Africa.  It is used as a dyewood, and also for ramrods, violin bows and turner's work.
blastocoelic: of or pertaining to a blastocoel.
Bitangent: Possessing the property of touching at two points.
Blithe: Gay; merry; sprightly; joyous; glad; cheerful; as, a blithe spirit.
Belial: An evil spirit; a wicked and unprincipled person; the personification of evil.
Bantu: Of or pertaining to the Bantu language group Bantu (definition 2); as, Bantu languages.
Binate: Double; growing in pairs or couples.
Bombardment: An attack upon a fortress or fortified town, with shells, hot shot, rockets, etc.; the act of throwing bombs and shot into a town or fortified place.
Baguet: A small molding, like the astragal, but smaller; a bead.
bleary-eyed: having eyes sore or unfocused, due to weariness or excessive drinking; same as blear-eyed{1}.
Beninese: a native or inhabitant of Benin.
Black pudding: A kind of sausage made of blood, suet, etc., thickened with meal.
Bunting: A thin woolen stuff, used chiefly for flags, colors, and ships' signals.
Begrime: To soil with grime or dirt deeply impressed or rubbed in.
Bilirubin: A reddish yellow pigment present in human bile, and in that from carnivorous and herbivorous animals; the normal biliary pigment.
biotype: a group of organisms sharing the same genotype.
Blushingly: In a blushing manner; with a blush or blushes; as, to answer or confess blushingly.
Brigandish: Like a brigand or freebooter; robberlike.
Bonanza: In mining, a rich mine or vein of silver or gold; hence, anything which is a mine of wealth or yields a large income.
Butcherly: Like a butcher; without compunction; savage; bloody; inhuman; fell.
Baphomet: An idol or symbolical figure which the Templars were accused of using in their mysterious rites.
Bottlehead: A cetacean allied to the grampus; -- called also bottle-nosed whale.
Biblical: Pertaining to, or derived from, the Bible; as, biblical learning; biblical authority.
Bird-eyed: Quick-sighted; catching a glance as one goes.
Belowt: To treat as a lout; to talk abusively to.
Backstop: In baseball, a fence, prop. at least 90 feet behind the home base, to stop the balls that pass the catcher; also, the catcher himself.
Brutify: To make like a brute; to make senseless, stupid, or unfeeling; to brutalize.
Bencher: One of the senior and governing members of an Inn of Court.
Bilateral: Having two sides; arranged upon two sides; affecting two sides or two parties.
Ballad monger: A seller or maker of ballads; a poetaster.
Bibelot: A small decorative object without practical utility.
Blemishment: The state of being blemished; blemish; disgrace; damage; impairment.
Bluepoll: A kind of salmon (Salmo Cambricus) found in Wales.
Basipodite: The basal joint of the legs of Crustacea.
Boggy: Consisting of, or containing, a bog or bogs; of the nature of a bog; swampy; as, boggy land.
Batoidei: The division of fishes which includes the rays and skates.
bebeeru: A tropical South American tree (Nectandra Rodiœi), the bark of which yields the alkaloid bebeerine, and the wood of which is known as green heart.
Barratry: The practice of exciting and encouraging lawsuits and quarrels.
Bungee cord: a strong elastic cord, usually with a hook at each end, used as a shock-absorbing device or to bind packages together, as on a dolly or handcart.
Bustling: Agitated; noisy; tumultuous; characterized by confused activity; as, a bustling crowd.
Burner: One who, or that which, burns or sets fire to anything.
Bombazet Bombazette: A sort of thin woolen cloth. It is of various colors, and may be plain or twilled.
Bobbin: A small pin, or cylinder, formerly of bone, now most commonly of wood, used in the making of pillow lace. Each thread is wound on a separate bobbin which hangs down holding the thread at a slight tension.
Bemuffle: To cover as with a muffler; to wrap up.
Balm: To anoint with balm, or with anything medicinal.
Ball: A social assembly for the purpose of dancing; -- usually applied to an occasion lavish or formal.
Balk: To indicate to fishermen, by shouts or signals from shore, the direction taken by the shoals of herring.
Beastly: Pertaining to, or having the form, nature, or habits of, a beast.
Bibliomancy: A kind of divination, performed by selecting passages of Scripture at hazard, and drawing from them indications concerning future events.
Bald: Destitute of the natural or common covering on the head or top, as of hair, feathers, foliage, trees, etc.; as, a bald head; a bald oak.
Blue jay: The common jay of the United States (Cyanocitta, or Cyanura, cristata). The predominant color is bright blue.
Bourgeois: A man of middle rank in society; one of the shopkeeping class.
Balas ruby: A variety of spinel ruby, of a pale rose red, or inclining to orange. See Spinel.
bratwurst: a small pork sausage seasoned with spices and herbs, and usually served broiled or sauteed.
Boreas: The north wind; -- usually a personification.
bee fly: any dipterous insect of the family Bombyliidae, which eat nectar and in some cases resemble bees.  Their larvae are parasitic on the larvae of bees and other insects.
Buxine: An alkaloid obtained from the Buxus sempervirens, or common box tree. It is identical with bebeerine; -- called also buxina.
Boreal: Northern; pertaining to the north, or to the north wind; as, a boreal bird; a boreal blast.
Brandish: A flourish, as with a weapon, whip, etc.
Bears-paw: A large bivalve shell of the East Indies (Hippopus maculatus), often used as an ornament.
Bilious: Of or pertaining to the bile.
Battailous: Arrayed for battle; fit or eager for battle; warlike.
boardwalk: a walkway made of wooden boards; usually at a seaside.  The more elaborate boardwalks at shore resorts are lined with many commercial retail establishments, on the side of the walk opposite the ocean.
buffo: The comic actor in an opera.
Bimana: Animals having two hands; -- a term applied by Cuvier to man as a special order of Mammalia.
Bromatologist: One versed in the science of foods.
Blastoidea: One of the divisions of Crinoidea found fossil in paleozoic rocks; pentremites. They are so named on account of their budlike form.
Brother-in-law: The brother of one's husband or wife; also, the husband of one's sister; sometimes, the husband of one's wife's sister.
Bedraggle: To draggle; to soil, as garments which, in walking, are suffered to drag in dust, mud, etc.
Banner: A kind of flag attached to a spear or pike by a crosspiece, and used by a chief as his standard in battle.
Bergamot: A tree of the Orange family (Citrus bergamia), having a roundish or pear-shaped fruit, from the rind of which an essential oil of delicious odor is extracted, much prized as a perfume. Also, the fruit.
Biceps: A muscle having two heads or origins; -- applied particularly to a flexor in the arm, and to another in the thigh.
Bichromate: A salt containing two parts of chromic acid to one of the other ingredients; as, potassium bichromate; -- called also dichromate.
Bireme: An ancient galley or vessel with two banks or tiers of oars.
Branny: Having the appearance of bran; consisting of or containing bran.
Bod veal: Veal too immature to be suitable for food.
Booser: A toper; a guzzler. See Boozer.
Biliteral: Consisting of two letters; as, a biliteral root of a Sanskrit verb.
Bogart: Humphrey DeForest Bogart, famous movie actor; most commonly called Humphrey Bogart; b. 1899, d. 1957.
Boatage: Conveyance by boat; also, a charge for such conveyance.
bereaved: mourning due to the death of a loved one.
